[image]
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Interpretations
1-1-5: Code Alteration
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Board of Trustees this Village Code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the official Village Code of the Village of
Forest View. This Village Code of Ordinances shall be known and cited as the
Forest View Municipal Code, and it is hereby published by authority of the
Board of Trustees and shall be kept up to date as provided in Section
1-1-3 of this Chapter under the direction of the Village Attorney, acting for
said Village Board of Trustees. Any reference to the number of any Section
contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same
number, its appropriate Chapter and Title heading, and to the general penalty
clause relating thereto, as well as to the Section itself, when reference is
made to this Village Code by title in any legal document. (1971 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Village Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative
tribunals of this State as the ordinances of the Village of general and
permanent effect, except the excluded ordinances enumerated in Section
1-2-1 of this Title 1 . (1971 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-6.
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Village Code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Village Code. All
such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this Village Code. Each such replacement page
shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of
the Village Code within thirty (30) days from the date of its final passage.
(1971 Code)
1-1-4: INTERPRETATIONS:
In the determination of the provisions of each section of this Code the
following rules shall be observed:
   (A)   Intent To Defraud: Whenever an intent to defraud is required in order
to constitute an offense, it shall be sufficient if an intent appears to
defraud any person.
   (B)   Liability Of Employers And Agents: When the provisions of any section
of this Village Code prohibits the commission of an act, not only the person
actually doing the prohibited act or omitting the directed act, but also the
employer and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the said
person shall be guilty of the offense described and liable to the penalty set
forth. (1971 Code)
1-1-5: CODE ALTERATION:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this Village Code in such a manner that
the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages
may be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by
the Village Board. The Clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly
inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the Clerk.
Any person having in his custody an official copy of this Village Code shall
make every effort to maintain said Code in an up to date and efficient manner.
He shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such
are delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the Village
Clerk. Said Code Books, while in actual possession of officials and other
interested persons, shall be and remain the property of the Village and shall
be returned to the office of the Clerk when directed so to do by order of the
Village Board. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVINGS CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of this
Village Code are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as
being still in force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from
repeal (subject to the saving clauses contained in the following Section), from
which are excluded the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax
levy ordinances; appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries
and annexations; franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special
rights to persons or corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances
authorizing the execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary
ordinances; ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or
other public places; improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances
relating to elections; ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of
real estate by or from the Village; and all special ordinances. (1971 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this Village Code or
by virtue of the preceding section, excepting as this Village Code may contain
provisions for such matters, in which case this Village Code shall be
considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect to such
provisions only. (1971 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   (A)   No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former
ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to
any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any
penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim
arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such
offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the part
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   (B)   This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   (C)   Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any
action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the Village
herein repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this
Code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the
same provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
Village under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this Village Code. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this Village Code importing the plural
number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties, or persons,
any single matter, party, or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this Village Code by
words importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several
matters, parties, or persons and females as well as males and bodies corporate
shall be deemed to be included; provided, that these rules of construction
shall not be applied to any section of this Village Code which contains any
express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or
content may be repugnant thereto. (1971 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code they shall have the
meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
BOARD: Unless otherwise indicated, the Board of Trustees of the Village.
CODE: The Municipal Code of Forest View and amendments thereto.
COUNTY: County of Cook.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the
Village of Forest View".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the Village for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
KNOWINGLY: The word "knowingly" imports only a knowledge that the facts exist
which brings the act or omission within the provisions of this Code. It does
not require any knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense deemed a violation of the provisions of this Code
which is a lesser offense than a felony as defined by State law.
NEGLIGENT: The word "negligent", as well as "neglect", "negligence" and
"negligently" imports a want of such attention to the nature of probable
consequences of the act or omission as a prudent man ordinarily bestows in
acting in his own concern.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the Village; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a
hazard to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or
to the community.
OCCUPANT: The word "occupant" applied to a building or land shall include any
person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether
alone or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this Code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the Village
of Forest View".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: The word "owner" applied to a building or land shall include any part
owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of
a part of such building or land.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, partnership, association, or
corporation in his or its own capacity or as administrator, conservator,
executor, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed by the court.
Whenever the word "person" is used in any section of this Code prescribing a
penalty or fine as applied to partnerships or associations, the word shall
include the partners or members thereof, and such word as applied to
corporations shall include the officers, agents, or employees thereof who are
responsible for any violation of said section.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Every description of money, goods, chattels, effects,
evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any pecuniary
obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred,
increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or interest
therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small quantities
direct to the consumer.
STATE: The State of Illinois.
STREET: Alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public squares, public places and
sidewalks.
TENANT: The word "tenant" when applied to a building or land shall include any
person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether
alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The Village of Forest View, County of Cook, State of Illinois.
WHOLESALER, WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be
understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in
quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WILFULLY: When applied to the intent with which an act is done or omitted,
implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or make the omission
referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to injure
another, or to acquire an advantage.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in
the proper handwriting of such person, or in case he is unable to write, by his
proper mark. (1940 Code Sec. 1-3; 1971 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: Penalty
1-4-2: Default; Labor
1-4-3: License
1-4-4: Application
1-4-5: Liability Of Officers
1-4-6: Nonsufficient Funds (NSF) Checks
1-4-1: PENALTY:
   (A)   Whenever in any ordinance or provision of this Code any act is
prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in
such ordinance or provision the doing of any act is required or the failure to
do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided
therefor, the violation of any such provision or ordinance shall be punishable
by a fine not exceeding of not less than two hundred and fifty dollars
($250.00) or more than unless provided elsewhere by separate offense.
   (B)   A subsequent violation of an ordinance occurring within a twelve (12)-
month period shall be punishable by a fine of not less than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or more than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
   (C)    A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day a violation
occurs or continues 1 . (Ord. 64-89, 2-25-1964; amd. Ord. 95-23, 10-10-1995;
Ord. 24-17, 12-10-2024)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.
1-4-2: DEFAULT; LABOR:
Any person in default of payment of any fine or costs imposed may be committed
to the County jail until the fine, penalty and costs are fully paid. Any person
imprisoned under the provisions of this Chapter may put to work for the benefit
of the Village for the term of his imprisonment. The committed person shall be
allowed, exclusive of board, a credit as provided by statute for each day's
work 1 . (1971 Code)
 
Notes
1 2. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-9.
1-4-3: LICENSE:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any section of this Code any
license previously issued to him by the Village may be revoked by the court or
by the Board of Trustees. (1971 Code)
1-4-4: APPLICATION:
The penalty provided in this Chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this Code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Code where any duty
is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is of a continuing
nature is forbidden or declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such
duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this Code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this Code the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this Code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this Chapter
shall apply and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a breach or violation occurs or continues. (1971 Code)
1-4-5: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the Board of Trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1971 Code)
1-4-6: NONSUFFICIENT FUNDS (NSF) CHECKS:
   (A)   Any check made payable to the Village, or any of its departments, and
deposited in the bank, or other financial institution, which results in
inability to pay the item, for any reason, shall be deemed nonsufficient funds
(NSF). The maker of the check shall be charged a fee of ten dollars ($10.00),
or rate as set by the Board from time to time, plus the face value of the
instrument returned, for any reason, to the Village by a bank or other
financial institution.
   (B)   The maker of the dishonored check shall make restitution to the
Village for the face value of the check plus a collection fee of ten dollars
($10.00), or fee set by the Board from time to time, per returned check. (Ord.
95-24, 10-10-1995)
CHAPTER 5
OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-5-1: Officers Of The Village
1-5-2: Oath And Bond

1-5-1: OFFICERS OF THE VILLAGE:
There shall be elected, as provided by law, a President and six (6) Trustees to
the Village Board. The President, with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees, may appoint a Treasurer, Attorney, Chief of Police, Chief of the Fire
Department and such other officers as may be necessary to carry on the good
government of the Village. (Ord. 78-5, 4-4-1978)
All newly elected officers shall take office at the conclusion of the business
portion of the Village's last regular meeting in the month of April, following
the election. If official election results are not received from the County
Clerk before the Village's last regular meeting in the month of April, the
terms of elected Municipal officers shall commence at the first regular or
special meeting of Corporate Authorities after receipt of official election
results from the County Clerk. Newly elected officers shall take office
immediately following the Village Board's adjournment sine die. (Ord. 09-02, 2-
10-2009)
1-5-2: OATH AND BOND:
Election of officers herein named shall be in accordance with the laws of the
State and the officers elected shall take oath and give bond in accordance with
the State law. Officers and committee men holding appointive positions shall,
when the State law so directs, take oath and give bond in like manner. (1940
Code Sec. 2-15)
1-5-3: TAKE OFFICE; VACANCY:
Appropriate officers shall be appointed and qualified at the first meeting of
the fiscal year. If their office becomes vacant, a successor shall be appointed
for the duration of the term of office. (1940 Code Sec. 2-15)
1-5-4: DELIVERY OF RECORDS TO SUCCESSOR:
   (A)   Every person retiring from office after having been an officer of the
Village shall, within five (5) days after notification and request, deliver to
his successor in office all property, books and effects of every description in
his possession belonging to the Village or appertaining to his office.
   (B)   All employees of the Village, including policemen and firemen, upon
termination of their employment, shall return to their department heads all
property, books and effects of every description in their possession belonging
to the Village.
Notice of the above and type of Village equipment or property concerned shall
be posted by all department heads. (Ord. 63-85, 9-10-1963)
1-5-5: SALARIES:
   (A)   Generally: The compensation paid the elected and appointed officials
of the Village and of the various employees thereof shall be set from time to
time by the President and Board of Trustees. (1971 Code)
   (B)   Elected Officials:
      1.   Village President: Any individual elected President of the Board of
Trustees of the Village at the April 1989 election, and any individual elected
or appointed President thereafter, shall receive a compensation of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per year. Any individual elected President of the
Board of Trustees at the April 2025 Election, and any individual elected or
appointed President thereafter shall receive a compensation of $10,000.
      2.   Board Of Trustees: Any individual elected trustee of the village at
the April 1989 election, and any individual elected or appointed trustee
thereafter, shall receive a compensation of two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00) per year. Any individual elected Trustee of the Village at the
April 2023 Election, and any individual elected or appointed Trustee thereafter
shall receive a compensation of $5,000.
   (C)   Reimbursement For Expenses Incurred: Elected officials shall be
advanced or reimbursed for the actual and reasonable expenses incurred by
individual elected officials in attending state, local, regional or national
conferences, seminars and similar events as approved by the board of trustees.
“Actual and reasonable expenses” for conferences in excess of seventy five (75)
miles radius of the village are those reasonably anticipated for travel,
lodging and per diem expenses as established by the board from time to time.
Expenditures for travel, lodging, meals and parking shall not be considered
reimbursable expenses for conferences within seventy five (75) miles radius of
the village. Conference registration shall be an advanced or reimbursable
expense regardless of the distance traveled.
      1.   After a meeting for which money was advanced to an elected official,
such official shall submit itemized expense vouchers showing the amount of his
actual expenses. Receipts shall be attached where possible. Officials seeking
reimbursement shall submit similar evidence of expenses actually incurred.
      2.   If the actual and reasonable expenses exceed the amount advanced,
the official shall be reimbursed for the amount not advanced. If the actual and
reasonable expenses are less than the amount advanced, the official shall
refund the excess amount.
      3.   No money for expenses shall be advanced nor shall any official be
reimbursed for any expenses incurred on behalf of any person other than the
official. (Ord. 87-12, 9-1-1987; amd. Ord. 97-19, 10-28-1997; Ord. 22-16, 7-26-
2022)
1-5-6: LONGEVITY SALARY INCREMENTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 78-6, 4-4-1978)
1-5-7: SICK LEAVE; BEREAVEMENT LEAVE:
   (A)   For purposes of this section, the term "sick leave" shall mean an
employee's personal illness requiring confinement at home or in the hospital.
The term "employee" means any person drawing a full time salary from the
village and does not include an elected official of the village. (Ord. 91-13,
8-27-1991)
   (B)   All employees other than firefighters shall be entitled to ninety six
(96) hours of sick leave for each calendar year (the equivalent of twelve 8-
hour days). After January 1, 2000, those employees will be allotted eighty (80)
hours of sick leave days for each calendar year (the equivalent of ten 8-hour
days). Firefighters shall be entitled to one hundred forty four (144) hours of
sick leave for each calendar year (the equivalent of eighteen 8-hour days).
After January 1, 2000, firefighters shall be allotted one hundred twenty (120)
hours of sick leave for each calendar year (the equivalent of fifteen 8-hour
days). Corporate authorities or department heads may require a physician's
certificate as a basis for pay during leave after an absence of three (3)
consecutive days in the case of employees except firefighters, or two (2)
consecutive shift days in the case of firefighters. The accumulation rate shall
be prorated at eight (8) hours per month (the equivalent of one 8-hour day) for
all employees other than firefighters. After January 1, 2000, for those
employees (other than firefighters), the accumulation rate shall be one 8-hour
sick day for each of the first ten (10) months of the calendar year and none
for the remaining two (2) months. Firefighters shall accumulate sick leave at
twelve (12) hours per month (the equivalent of 1.5 8-hour days). After January
1, 2000, firefighters shall accumulate sick leave at ten (10) hours per month
throughout the calendar year. (Ord. 98-14, 11-10-1998)
   (C)   Sick time may be used in increments of at least one-half (1/2) day for
all employees except firefighters, and eight (8) hours in the case of
firefighters. (Ord. 91-2, 2-12-1991, eff. retroactive to 1-1-1991; amd. Ord.
96-1, 1-9-1996)
   (D)   Employees (other than firefighters) may accumulate up to a maximum of
four hundred eighty (480) hours of unused sick leave (the equivalent of sixty
8-hour days). After January 1, 2000, employees (other than firefighters), may
accumulate up to a maximum of eight hundred (800) hours of sick leave (the
equivalent of one hundred 8-hour days). Firefighters may accumulate up to a
maximum of six hundred seventy two (672) hours of unused sick leave (the
equivalent of eighty four 8-hour days). After January 1, 2000, firefighters may
accumulate up to a maximum of one thousand one hundred twenty (1,120) hours of
unused sick leave (the equivalent of one hundred forty 8-hour days). (Ord. 98-
14, 11-10-1998)
   (E)   At retirement, any employee who qualifies for a Village retirement
plan shall be entitled to "cash in" one-third (1/3) of any accumulated sick
days for their current cash value, or may utilize two-thirds (2/3) of those
days as service credit toward retirement. (Ord. 97-3, 1-28-1997)
   In the event of termination, resignation or any other discontinuation of
employment, unused sick leave is lost without any form of compensation. (Ord.
91-2, 2-12-1991, eff. retroactive to 1-1-1991; amd. Ord. 96-1, 1-9-1996)
   (F)   In addition to the sick leave, vacation and compensatory time
authorized in this chapter, the Village Board may, in its discretion, authorize
an employee, other than a firefighter, with a verified, extended illness who
has expended all of his or her accumulated sick leave, vacation and
compensatory time to utilize up to ninety six (96) hours of the employee's sick
leave for the following year. The Village Board may, in its discretion,
authorize a firefighter with a verified, extended illness who has expended all
of his or her accumulated sick leave, vacation and compensatory time to utilize
up to one hundred forty four (144) hours of the firefighter's sick leave for
the following year. (Ord. 93-30, 11-9-1993)
   (G)   Full time employees shall be entitled to up to three (3) days of
bereavement leave (one 24-hour shift in the case of firefighters) when the
employee experiences a death in the immediate family. The Village may require
proof of death. For purposes of this section "immediate family" shall include
parents, spouse, brothers, sisters, children, stepchildren, grandparents,
grandchildren, parents-in-law, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law and legal
guardians. (Ord. 91-13, 8-27-1991)

         Ten (10) days after one full year of service.
         Fifteen (15) days after three (3) full years of service.
         Twenty (20) days after ten (10) full years of service.
         Twenty-one (21) days after twenty-one (21) full years of service.
         Twenty-two (22) days after twenty-two (22) full years of service.
         Twenty-three (23) days after twenty-three (23) full years of service.
      2.   Vacation Days Tier II (Hired on or after June 1, 2021): All full-
time employees shall be entitled to annual vacation periods without loss of
compensation, on the following basis. Vacation days are earned at the beginning
of the calendar year. Should employees be hired during the calendar year,
vacation days will be prorated based on when they were hired.
         Ten (10) days from date of hire, to five (5) years of service
         Fifteen (15) days from six (6) years of service, to nine (9) years of
service.
         Seventeen (17) days from ten (10) years of service, to fourteen (14)
years of service.
         Twenty (20) days from fifteen (15) years of service, to nineteen (19)
years of service.
         Twenty-two (22) days from twenty (20) years of service, to twenty-five
(25) years of service.
         Twenty-five (25) days for twenty-six (26) years of service and above.
         The Village Administrator, Chief of Police, Fire Chief, and
Superintendent of Public Works and Water shall be awarded 6 extra vacation days
above and beyond the amount earned for years of service.
         Vacation days may be carried over into the following calendar year,
not to exceed five (5) extra days total. Therefore, the maximum amount of
vacation days an employee can have will be based on the number of days they
earn for their years of service in their respective tier, plus five (5) days.
Should a situation arise where an employee has not used all of their vacation
time in the current year, or has run out of vacation time and would like to
take extra vacation days, permission to roll over the days or take more than
the allotted vacation time will be addressed on a case by case basis by the
Village Administrator and Village President. See the appendices at the end of
the ordinance.
      3.   Paid Sick Time:
         The number of paid sick days shall be twelve (12) per year. The
Village Administrator may require a physician’s certificate as a basis for pay
during a leave of absence for sick leave of three of more consecutive days.
Sick leave must be used in increments of at least one-half days. Employees may
accumulate up to one hundred (100) days of sick leave.
         Sick days are earned at the beginning of the calendar year. Should
employees be hired during the calendar year, sick days will be prorated based
on when they were hired.
      4.   Personal Days:
         Full-time employees will receive five (5) personal days off with pay
each year. Employees must make every effort to use the Personal Days during the
calendar year and may not carry over the Personal Days to the following
calendar year unless written permission is granted by the Village
Administrator.
         Personal days shall be initially selected on a seniority basis in
conjunction with the selection of vacation days. Thereafter, personal days
shall be selected on a first come-first served basis.
         No more than one (1) employee per department may be off on a personal
day leave at any one time. Employees must give the Employer at least forty-
eight (48) hours' notice of a personal day leave request. Such request will not
be unreasonably denied.
         Personal days are earned at the beginning of the calendar year. Should
employees be hired during the calendar year, personal days will be prorated
based on when they were hired.
   (H)   Hospitalization and Other Insurance:
      The Full-Time employees of the Village and their dependents shall be
eligible for participation in the medical and hospitalization insurance plan
provided by the Village, after eighty-nine (89) days’ service of their
employment. In addition, all Full-Time employees shall be eligible for
participation in the Village life insurance plan. All Full-Time employees of
the Village and their dependents shall be eligible for participation, after
eighty-nine (89) days’ service, in the group prescription drug and vision
service programs.
      1.    Health Insurance: Full-Time employees of the Village and their
dependents shall be eligible to participate in the current Village sponsored
health plan. Full-Time employee contribution toward that Plan shall be 15% of
the actual premium cost of their respective market category premium, or as
determined by the Village President and Board of Trustees from time to time,
irrespective if the Full-Time employee’s enrollment in any of the villages’s
health plan options.
      2.    Dental and Vision Insurance: Full-Time employees of the Village and
their dependents shall be eligible to participate in the dental and vision
insurance plan. Full-Time employees shall contribute 15% of the actual premium
cost of their respective market category premium, or as determined by the
Village President and Board of Trustees from time to time. The Village has
determined that these plans are “bundled” and as such all types of coverage
cannot be split.
   (I)   Part-Time Employees: Unless otherwise specified, all other persons
employed by the Village shall be deemed Part-Time employees and shall be
compensated at the rate of twenty dollars and sixty-two cents ($20.62) per
hour. Part-Time employees shall not be eligible to participate in the
hospitalization insurance plan provided by the Village unless required by
stipulations of the Affordable Care Act. Elected Officials and appointed
officers of the Village shall not be considered as Part-Time employees. The
Village shall observe the Paid Leave For All Workers Act requirements for part-
time employees by granting part-time employees one (1) hour of paid leave for
every forty (40) hours worked.
   (J)   Executive And Legislative:
 
                             Annual Salary
Village Administrator         $121,300
Village Clerk / Treasurer     $59,300
Village Building Commissioner $12,000
 
   (K)   Holiday Compensation:
      1.   Full-Time Employees: All Full-Time non-FOP employees shall be
granted paid time off on New Year’s Day (January 1), President’s Day (third
Monday in February), Memorial Day (last Monday in May), Independence Day (July
4), Labor Day (first Monday in September), Thanksgiving (fourth Thursday in
November), Day after Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve (December 24), Christmas Day
(December 25), and New Year’s Eve (December 31). Holidays that fall on a
Saturday will be observed on the preceding Friday, and holidays that fall on a
Sunday will be observed on the following Monday.
         All Full-Time non-FOP employees who are scheduled to work and do work
at least seven (7) hours on a “holiday”, (as defined above), shall receive an
additional sixteen (16) hours straight-time pay.
         Any Full-Time or Part-Time Public Works employee who is ordered to
work on a holiday shall be paid an additional two hours of straight time pay
for each hour worked, regardless of how many hours the employee works.
      2.   Part-Time Firefighters/paramedics and Part-Time Police Officers: Any
Part-Time Firefighters/paramedics or Part-Time Police Officers or Part-Time
Radio Operators who are scheduled to work on a “holiday” (as defined below)
shall receive an additional one (1) hour of straight time pay for each hour
worked up to twenty-four (24) hours.
         For purposes of Part-Time Firefighters/paramedics and Part-Time Police
Officers a “holiday” refers to:
         New Year’s Eve starting at the beginning of the first shift at 7:00
a.m. until 11:00 p.m. on New Year’s Day, and extending for twenty-four (24)
hours;
         President’s Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day,
Thanksgiving, starting at 7:00 a.m. and extending for 24 hours;
         Christmas Eve starting at the beginning of the first shift at 7:00
a.m. until 11:00 p.m. on Christmas Day and extending for twenty-four (24)
hours.
         Any Part-Time Firefighters/paramedics who are ordered to work on a
“holiday”, (as defined above), shall be paid an additional two hours of
straight time pay for each hour worked, regardless of how many hours the
employee works.
   (L)   The Village President shall have the authority to adjust starting
salaries by a plus or minus ten percent (+ or - 10%) depending on the
qualifications of new hires. The remainder of the salary grid shall be
proportionally adjusted based on the starting salary.
       Salary provisions of the above section shall be effective July 1, 2024.
(Ord. 17-13, 8-8-2017; amd. Ord. 20-07, 8-25-2020; Ord. 2021-14, 12-14-2021;
Ord. 2022-04, 1-11-2022; Ord. 22-06, 3-8-2022; Ord. 22-17, 7-26-2022; Ord. 23-
09, 8-1-2023; Ord. 23-17, 12-12-2023; Ord. 24-09, 6-25-2024)
1-5-9: ILLINOIS MUNICIPAL RETIREMENT FUND:
The Village does hereby elect to participate in the Illinois Municipal
Retirement Fund effective January 1, 1965, pursuant to the provisions set forth
in 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-101 et seq. (Ord. 64-92, 4-14-1964)
1-5-10: FULL TIME EMPLOYEE OF THE PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT:
   (A)   Position Created: The position of full time employee of the Public
Works Department of the Village be and the same is hereby created. The person
filling said position shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
      1.   To report to the Superintendent of Public Works and his assistants;
      2.   To perform any and all tasks assigned by the department head or his
assistants;
      3.   To carry out any and all assignments and responsibilities assigned
to said employee by the department head; and
      4.   To work a full forty (40) hour week, excluding lunch period.
   (B)   Public Service Employees: From time to time, pursuant to authorization
from the Board of Trustees, the Village Administrator may authorize the hiring
of part time public service employees. Such employees shall be assigned to the
Public Works Department and shall be considered public works employees for
purposes of any pension entitlements. Public service employees shall also be
available to assist as assigned in the Fire Department or to perform other
Village functions as assigned. Such employees shall be entitled to no vacation
or health insurance benefits. The Village Administrator is authorized to
prepare, subject to approval by the Board of Trustees, job descriptions and
workplace regulations governing the employment of public service employees.
(Ord. 94-20, 12-13-1994)
1-5-11: OVERTIME/COMPENSATORY TIME POLICY FOR ALL ELIGIBLE VILLAGE EMPLOYEES:
In accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Amendment of 1985, all eligible
employees entitled to receive overtime compensation shall receive in lieu
thereof compensatory time off at a rate of one and one-half (11/2) hours for
each hour of employment for which overtime compensation would be required by
law. No monetary overtime compensation shall be paid any employee unless the
employee receives the consent of the appropriate department head prior to the
performance of any work. (Ord. 86-1, 1-28-1986)
1-5-12: RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT FOR POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
All full time members of the Village's Police and Fire Departments employed
after January 27, 1987, shall reside within a five (5) mile radius of the
Village limits within six (6) months of the date of being hired. The President
and Board of Trustees may extend this time limit for up to an additional twelve
(12) months in individual cases upon a showing of exceptional need by the
employee. (Ord. 97-4, 2-11-1997)
1-5-13: OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT:
All full time employees of the Village who accept a second job or any outside
employment, who own or operate any business, or who perform any other work or
provide any other service for which they receive compensation, shall, upon the
commencement of such employment or work, notify the Village Administrator and
respective department head, in writing, on such forms as may be provided by the
Village Administrator. (Ord. 92-14, 10-13-1992)
CHAPTER 6
PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election; Qualifications; Term
1-6-2: Duties; Powers
1-6-1: ELECTION; QUALIFICATIONS; TERM:
The President shall be a qualified elector and reside within the Village limits
for at least one year prior to his election. He shall hold office for four (4)
years and until his successor is elected and duly qualified. Where a vacancy
exists in the office of President and the unexpired term is less than one year
it shall be filled by an election which shall be had for such purpose within
six (6) months after such vacancy occurs and pending said election and until a
successor is duly elected and qualified, the Board shall elect one of its
number to act as President Pro Tempore. Where said vacancy is for less than one
year the Board shall elect one of its number to act as President until the next
annual election and until the President's successor is duly elected and
qualified. (1940 Code Sec. 2-2)
1-6-2: DUTIES; POWERS:
   (A)   The President shall preside at all meetings of the Board of Trustees
but shall not vote except in case of a tie vote of the members of the Board of
Trustees, and except concerning matters which, by statute, require the vote of
the corporate authorities.
   (B)   He shall appoint all officers, full-time employees, and part-time
employees with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees with the
exception of those taking office by election. He shall have power to remove any
officer appointed by him as provided by law.
   (C)   He may exercise within the Village limits, the powers conferred upon
sheriffs to suppress disorder and keep the peace; he may release persons
imprisoned for violation of any Village ordinance, reporting such release and
the cause therefor at the next Board meeting.
   (D)   He may annually and from time to time, give the Board information
relative to the Village affairs and recommend measures he deems expedient for
their consideration.
   (E)   He shall have the power to suppress riot and other disorderly conduct
and to enforce Village ordinances by calling on all inhabitants of the Village
eighteen (18) years of age or more for assistance.
   (F)   He shall have power at all times to examine the books, records and
papers of any agent, officer or employee of the Village. (Ord. 78-7, 4-4-1978;
amd. Ord. 23-04, 4-25-2023)
CHAPTER 7
BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-7-1: Election; Qualifications; Term
1-7-2: Powers
1-7-3: Quorum; Attendance Required
1-7-4: President Pro Tem
1-7-5: Meetings
1-7-6: Order Of Business
1-7-7: Committees
1-7-8: Remote Participation At Village Board Meetings
1-7-1: ELECTION; QUALIFICATIONS; TERM:
The board of trustees shall consist of six (6) members, each of whom shall be
qualified electors and shall reside and have resided within the village limits
at least one year prior to his election. They shall each hold the office for a
period of four (4) years and until their respective successors are elected and
duly qualified. Where a vacancy exists in the office of trustee, the president
may appoint a trustee until the next election or special election. (1940 Code
Sec. 2-3)
1-7-2: POWERS:
The board and the president shall exercise such powers as are accorded to it by
state statutes. (1940 Code Sec. 2-3)
1-7-3: QUORUM; ATTENDANCE REQUIRED:
A majority of the corporate authorities elected shall constitute a quorum to do
business but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time.
The board shall be the judge of the election and qualification of its own
members and may punish its members for disorderly conduct in accordance with
statutes made and provided. It may elect a temporary chairman in the absence of
the president because of temporary illness or otherwise who shall act as
presiding officer. (Ord. 75-340, 5-13-1975)
1-7-4: PRESIDENT PRO TEM:
Where the president's absence is occasioned by absence from the village,
serious and continued illness or other disability, the board shall elect one of
its number as president pro tem who shall for the duration of said absence
exercise all of the powers of president. (1940 Code Sec. 2-3)
1-7-5: MEETINGS:
   (A)   Regular meetings of the board shall be held on the second and fourth
Tuesdays of each month at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. in the village hall, 7000
West 46th Street, and special meetings may be held at any time on call of the
president or three (3) trustees and in compliance with the requirements of the
Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. 89-6, 5-23-1989)
   (B)   A call for a special meeting shall be signed by the officers calling
it, shall specify the purposes for which it is called and be filed with the
village clerk before becoming effective, the village clerk shall cause a
written notice of the meeting to be served upon all of the trustees and the
president not later than the calendar day next preceding the day of the meeting
except in case of grave emergency when it may be served on the day of the
meeting. The vote of the board at a prior meeting shall not be reconsidered or
rescinded at a special meeting unless a large number of trustees be present as
were present when such vote was taken.
All meetings shall be open to the general public and shall be held at the
village hall. (1940 Code Sec. 2-4)
1-7-6: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The order of business at meetings shall be in accordance with such rules as the
board may from time to time prescribe. (1940 Code Sec. 2-4)
1-7-7: COMMITTEES:
From the membership of the board, the president shall annually appoint the
following committees who shall serve without remuneration therefor and have
such special duties on behalf of the board as may be delegated to them by this
code:
Building committee
Committee on public improvements
Health committee
Their commission shall be concurrent with their term of office. In the
discretion of the president he may appoint such standing and special committees
as he may deem appropriate. (1940 Code Sec. 2-14)
1-7-8: REMOTE PARTICIPATION AT VILLAGE BOARD MEETINGS:
Members of the board of trustees may participate in a regular meeting, special
meeting or administrative meeting of the board of trustees under the following
circumstances:
   (A)   Permissible Reasons: A board member may participate in a meeting by
video or audio conference if that board member's absence is necessitated by one
of the following:
      1.   Personal illness or disability of the board member.
      2.   Employment purposes of the board member.
      3.   The board member's participation in a matter relating to the
business of the village.
      4.   Family or other emergency involving the board member.
   (B)   Quorum Requirement: No meeting shall take place unless a quorum of the
board members is physically present at the meeting.
   (C)   Prior Notice: A board member desiring to participate at a meeting by
video or audio conferencing must advise the village administrator as soon as is
reasonably possible in order to facilitate the audio or video conferencing.
(Ord. 06-19, 11-28-2006)
CHAPTER 8
CLERK
SECTION:
1-8-1: Appointment; Qualifications; Term
1-8-2: Duties
1-8-3: Compensation
1-8-4: Village Board Meeting Clerk
1-8-5: Bond
1-8-1: APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS; TERM:
The clerk shall be appointed by the village president, subject to the
concurrence of the board of trustees. Such appointment shall be for a term of
one year. (Ord. 15-01, 3-24-2015)
1-8-2: DUTIES:
   (A)   The appointed village clerk shall:
      1.   Attend all meetings and executive sessions.
      2.   Verify and authenticate the final typed copy of such meeting minutes
by affixing his/her signature.
The appointed village clerk shall have the authority to delegate duties to
office staff whenever he/she deems necessary.
   (B)   The clerk shall keep the corporate seal to be provided by the
corporate authorities and all papers belonging to the village, the custody and
control of which are not given to other officers. He/she shall conduct
correspondence on behalf of the village and is hereby empowered to administer
oaths and affirmations upon lawful occasions. Copies of all papers duly filed
in the clerk's office and transcripts from the journals and other records and
files of the clerk's office, certified by the clerk under the corporate seal,
shall be evidence in all courts in like manner as if the originals were
produced. The clerk shall have other duties prescribed by the president and
board of trustees from time to time.
   (C)   Upon the request of any person and payment of a fee per page, as
established by the board of trustees from time to time, the clerk shall furnish
a reproduction or photocopy of any public record of the village. In the event a
certified copy of such record or document is requested, an additional charge of
five dollars ($5.00) shall be payable.
   (D)   The clerk shall serve as the local election official as provided in
the general election law. He/she shall serve as deputy registrar who may accept
the registration of all qualified residents of the village, certify the offices
to be filled, receive nominating petitions or certificates of candidacy,
conduct in person absentee voting and transmit all precinct tally sheets and
printouts to the canvassing board, and other statutory election provisions.
   (E)   By statute, the clerk shall serve as a member of the firemen's pension
fund board. (Ord. 97-6, 5-13-1997)
   (F)   The position of village clerk will serve as the official freedom of
information act officer for the village of Forest View. The village clerk will
hereafter be required to meet all required training stipulations as provided by
statute. (Ord. 16-03, 4-26-2016)
1-8-3: COMPENSATION:
The appointed village clerk shall receive compensation as the village board
shall fix from time to time. (Ord. 15-01, 3-24-2015)
1-8-4: VILLAGE BOARD MEETING CLERK:
   (A)   Appointment: The office assistant or village accountant shall serve as
the board meeting clerk.
   (B)   Duties: The village board meeting clerk shall:
      1.   Attend all twenty four (24) regular village board meetings.
      2.   Verify and authenticate the final typed copy of such meeting minutes
by affixing his/her signature.
   (C)   Compensation: The village board meeting clerk shall be compensated at
a rate of fifty dollars ($50.00) per meeting, regardless of the length of the
meeting. The fifty dollar ($50.00) compensation shall be in lieu of any
overtime compensation. (Ord. 97-6, 5-13-1997)
1-8-5: BOND:
The appointed village clerk shall furnish a bond in such amount as may be
required and with such surety as may be approved by the village board, said
bond shall be conditioned on the faithful performance of duties and shall be
conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of
duty or any act of the appointed village clerk. The premium on the bond shall
be paid by the village. (Ord. 97-6, 5-13-1997)
CHAPTER 9
VILLAGE ACCOUNTANT
SECTION:
1-9-1: Creation; Appointment
1-9-2: Powers And Duties
1-9-3: Compensation
1-9-4: Bond
1-9-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created in the Village the position of Village Accountant. The
Village Accountant shall be appointed by the President subject to confirmation
by the Board of Trustees and shall serve at the discretion of the President and
Board of Trustees as provided by law. (Ord. 97-8, 5-13-1997)
1-9-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Village Accountant shall be the principal accounting employee of the
Village. The Village Accountant shall be responsible for, but not limited to,
the following: maintaining a complete set of books and records relative to the
Village's business transactions, general and subsidiary ledgers, revenue and
expenditure reports, payroll, and bank reconciliation; preparing information
and assisting in Village audits; working closely with the Village Treasurer in
managing investments and financial liquidity; undertaking significant
responsibility in the overall operation of the Village computer system
including software utilization and data entry; preparing a summary statement of
current accounts payable, payroll and revenues received to be included in the
Village Board Meeting Clerk's Board meeting information; assisting in
maintaining Village Code books; the Village Accountant shall also serve as the
benefits coordinator for the Village; administer the employee assistance,
health, dental and life insurance plans; perform the duties of the Village
Board Meeting Clerk; assist the Village Clerk in his/her role as the local
election official by serving as a deputy registrar, conducting in-house
absentee voting and other duties delegated in accordance with the general
election law; serve as notary public; prepare quarterly newsletter; perform
secretarial and clerical office duties on word processing equipment and perform
other duties as may be assigned from time to time by the Village Administrator.
The position shall report directly to the Village Administrator in the chain of
command. (Ord. 97-11, 6-24-1997)
1-9-3: COMPENSATION:
The Village Accountant shall receive such compensation as the Village Board
shall fix from time to time. The Village Accountant shall be considered a full-
time employee of the Village for insurance purposes. (Ord. 97-8, 5-13-1997)
1-9-4: BOND:
The Village Accountant shall furnish a bond in such amount as may be required
and with such surety as may be approved by the Village Board. Said bond shall
be conditioned on the faithful performance of duties and shall be conditioned
to indemnify the Village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any
act of the Village Accountant. The premium on the bond shall be paid by the
Village. (Ord. 97-8, 5-13-1997)
CHAPTER 9A
OFFICE ASSISTANT
SECTION:
1-9A-1: Creation; Appointment
1-9A-2: Powers And Duties
1-9A-3: Compensation
1-9A-4: Bond
1-9A-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created in the Village the position of Office Assistant. The
Office Assistant shall be appointed by the President subject to confirmation by
the Board of Trustees and shall serve at the discretion of the President and
Board of Trustees as provided by law. (Ord. 93-17, 8-24-1993)
1-9A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Office Assistant shall be responsible for, but not limited to, the
following: function as the Water Clerk performing billing, collections, late
payment penalties and record keeping utilizing the Village computer system;
issue, monitor and collect various licenses, permits and applicable fees;
perform the duties of the Village Board Meeting Clerk, preparing the final copy
of Village Board meeting minutes from the written draft submitted by the
Village Board Meeting Clerk; record the original copy of minutes of the Board
in a well bound journal; forward the codifier copies of all applicable
ordinance and maintain up-to-date Code books and distribute as needed; develop
and maintain personnel records on all employees including, but not limited to,
W-4 and I-9 forms and sick leave records; assist the Chief of Police with
maintenance of "P" tickets; maintain vehicle sticker count annually to assist
Village Accountant with yearly audit; notify applicable officials of ethics
statements regulations; obtain and maintain officials bonds as required;
prepare petty cash funds to maintain sufficient ready cash; assist department
heads with property damage claims; maintain Illinois Risk Management property
control ledgers; assist the Village Clerk in his/her role as the local election
official by serving as a deputy registrar, conducting in-house absentee voting
and other duties as delegated in accordance with the General Election Law;
perform secretarial and clerical office duties as needed on word processing
equipment; maintain Village historical records; and perform other duties as may
be assigned from time to time by the Village Administrator. The position shall
report directly to the Village Administrator in the chain of command. (Ord. 97-
12, 6-24-1997; amd. Ord. 17-07, 4-11-2017)
1-9A-3: COMPENSATION:
The Office Assistant shall receive such compensation as the Village Board shall
fix from time to time. The Office Assistant shall be considered a part-time
position compensated at an hourly rate. (Ord. 93-17, 8-24-1993)
1-9A-4: BOND:
The Office Assistant shall furnish a bond in such amount as may be required and
with such surety as may be approved by the Village Board, said bond shall be
conditioned on the faithful performance of duties and shall be conditioned to
indemnify the Village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any act
of the Office Assistant. The premium on the bond shall be paid by the Village.
(Ord. 93-17, 8-24-1993)
CHAPTER 9B
OFFICE ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT
SECTION:
1-9B-1: Creation; Appointment
1-9B-2: Powers And Duties
1-9B-3: Compensation
1-9B-4: Bond
1-9B-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created in the village the position of village office
administrative assistant. The village office administrative assistant shall be
appointed by the president, subject to confirmation by the board of trustees
and shall serve at the discretion of the president and board of trustees as
provided by law. (Ord. 16-04, 4-26-2016)
1-9B-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village office administrative assistant shall be responsible for, but not
limited to, the following: function as the water clerk performing billing,
collections, late payment penalties and recordkeeping utilizing the village
computer system; issue, monitor, and collect business and other various
licenses, permits and fees; assist the village administrator and village
accountant in day to day work activities; perform the duties of the village
board meeting clerk; preparing the final copy of the village board meeting
minutes; record the original copy of minutes of the board in a well bound
journal; forward the codifier copies of all applicable ordinances for
codification, as well as maintain up to date code books and distribute as
needed; develop and maintain personnel records on all employees including, but
not limited to, W-4 and I-9 forms and sick leave records; assist the chief of
police with the collection of fines and maintenance of "P" tickets; notify
applicable officials of ethics statements regulations; prepare petty cash funds
to maintain sufficient ready cash; assist department heads with property damage
claims; assist the village clerk in his/her role as the local election official
by serving as a deputy registrar as delegated in accordance with the general
election law; assist freedom of information officer with duties; perform
secretarial and clerical office duties as needed, maintain village historical
records; creation of the quarterly newsletter, as well as other notices as
required; coordinate building permits and inspections with the building
commissioner; provide secretarial support to the public works superintendent;
and perform other duties as may be assigned from time to time by the president
or village administrator. The village office administrative assistant shall
also be cross trained to perform the duties of the village accountant,
including accounts payable and payroll; bank reconciliations; as well as making
weekly bank deposits, with receipts being provided to the village accountant.
The position shall report directly to the village administrator in the chain of
command. (Ord. 16-04, 4-26-2016)
1-9B-3: COMPENSATION:
The village office administrative assistant shall receive such compensation as
the village board shall fix from time to time. The village office
administrative assistant shall be considered a full time position for benefit
purposes. (Ord. 16-04, 4-26-2016)
1-9B-4: BOND:
The village office administrative assistant shall furnish a bond in such amount
as may be required and with such surety as may be approved by the village
board, said bond shall be conditioned on the faithful performance of duties and
shall be conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any
neglect of duty or any act of the village office administrative assistant. The
premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. (Ord. 16-04, 4-26-2016)
CHAPTER 10
TREASURER
SECTION:
1-10-1: Appointment; Qualifications; Term
1-10-2: Duties
1-10-3: Salary
1-10-1: APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS; TERM:
The Treasurer shall be a qualified elector and reside and have resided in the
Village limits for at least one year prior to his appointment. He shall hold
office for four (4) years and until his successor is appointed and duly
qualified. (1940 Code Sec. 2-6)
1-10-2: DUTIES:
   (A)   He shall receive all monies belonging to the Village other than
special assessment funds.
   (B)   He shall issue permits and licenses upon proper authority, and shall
at all regular meetings present a report of the balance in the general Village
funds at the time of the previous meeting and an itemized account of receipts
and disbursements together with one of all accounts paid in the period.
   (C)   He shall keep his books and accounts in form satisfactory to the Board
and said accounts shall always be subject to inspection by the President or a
member of the Board.
   (D)   Annually between the first and tenth of April he shall make out and
file with the Clerk a full and detailed account of all receipts and
expenditures and transactions during the preceding fiscal year. The Clerk shall
publish the same by posting and reporting thereon to the Board at its next
meeting. All warrants paid by the Treasurer shall be marked paid and filed with
his monthly account. A register of all warrants redeemed and paid shall be kept
by him showing the date, amount, number, the fund from which paid, the name of
the person to whom and when paid. (1940 Code Sec. 2-6)
1-10-3: SALARY:
The compensation of the Treasurer of the Village shall be one hundred twenty
five dollars ($125.00) per month. (Ord. 83-7, 6-28-1983, eff. 5-1-1983)
CHAPTER 11
VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-11-1: Creation Of Office; Appointment; Compensation
1-11-2: Suits And Actions
1-11-3: Judgments
1-11-4: Advice
1-11-5: Special Assessments
1-11-6: Ordinances And Documents
1-11-7: Bond Issues
1-11-8: Additional Legal Counsel
1-11-1: CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the office of Village Attorney, an executive office of
the Village. The Attorney shall be appointed by the President with the advice
and consent of the Board of Trustees and shall serve for a term of one year. A
law firm may be retained to act as Village Attorney, in which instance, the
President is authorized to appoint one or more members of said firm to act in
the capacity of Village Attorney. The Village Attorney shall receive such
compensation as may, from time to time, be provided by contract, motion or
ordinance. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
1-11-2: SUITS AND ACTIONS:
The Village Attorney, upon such financial arrangements as shall prevail, shall
prosecute or defend any and all lawsuits to which the Village may be a party,
or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against it, or which
may be brought by any officer on behalf of the Village, or which may be brought
in the capacity of such person as an officer of the Village. When so directed
by the Board of Trustees, the Attorney shall defend any and all lawsuits
brought against officials, employees and agents of the Village arising out of
the performance of duties on behalf of the Village. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
1-11-3: JUDGMENTS:
It shall be the duty of the Village Attorney to see to the full enforcement of
all judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the Village and of all
similar orders. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
1-11-4: ADVICE:
The Attorney shall be the legal adviser of the Village and upon such financial
arrangement as shall prevail, shall render advice on all legal questions
affecting the Village whenever requested to do so by any elected officer of the
Village or department head. The Attorney shall attend all regular and special
meetings of the Board and such other Municipal meetings at which his attendance
is required. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
1-11-5: SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS:
Upon such financial arrangements as shall prevail, it shall be the duty of the
Attorney to see to the completion of all special assessment proceedings and
condemnation proceedings. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
1-11-6: ORDINANCES AND DOCUMENTS:
When requested by the President or Board of Trustees, and upon such financial
arrangements as shall prevail, the Village Attorney shall prepare all
ordinances and resolutions, contracts, leases and other documents or
instruments to which the Village may be a party. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
1-11-7: BOND ISSUES:
Upon such financial arrangements as shall prevail, and at the request of the
Board of Trustees, the Attorney shall prepare all documents necessary to the
issuance of any bonds. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
1-11-8: ADDITIONAL LEGAL COUNSEL:
The corporate authorities may, from time to time, employ additional lawyers to
perform specialized, consultant or advisory services to the Village Attorney or
the Village. (Ord. 78-9, 4-4-1978)
CHAPTER 12
ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR
SECTION:
1-12-1: Office Created
1-12-2: Duties
1-12-3: Administration Of Electrical Regulations
1-12-4: Penalty
1-12-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of Electrical Inspector. Such office shall
be filled by appointment by the President and Board of Trustees. His term of
office shall be one year and until his successor shall have been appointed and
shall have qualified. He shall furnish a bond with good and sufficient
security, for the faithful performance of his duty, in form and effect and
amount as other officials of the Village. His salary shall be fixed from time
to time by the President and Board. He may be assisted in his work by such
assistant electrical inspectors as from time to time may be necessary for the
proper performance of his duties, which appointments shall be made in the same
manner and for the same term of office as the appointment of the Chief
Electrical Inspector.
In the absence of the Electrical Inspector, or in the case of a vacancy of his
office, the Building Commissioner shall perform all the duties of the office of
the Electrical Inspector. (Ord. 71-259, 7-13-1971)
1-12-2: DUTIES:
Such Electrical Inspector and his assistants shall have the following specific
powers, authority and duties:
   (A)   Power To Enter Building: The Electrical Inspector or assistant
electrical inspectors shall have the power to enter any building or premises at
any reasonable hour in the discharge of their duties, and it shall be competent
for them, when necessary to remove any existing obstructions such as laths,
plastering, boarding or partitions which may prevent a perfect inspection of
the electrical equipment; they shall also have the power to enter any building
used in whole or in part for the purpose of public assemblage at any time when
occupied by the public, in order to examine electrical equipment in such
building, and it shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with them in the
performance of their duties.
   (B)   Aid Of Police Department: Whenever, in the opinion of the Electrical
Inspector, it shall be necessary to call upon the Police Department for aid and
assistance in carrying out or enforcing any of the provisions in this Ordinance
governing the inspection of electrical equipment, he shall have the authority
to do so, and it shall be the duty of any member of the Police Department when
called upon by said Electrical Inspector to act according to the instructions
of and to perform such duties as may be required by such Electrical Inspector
in order to enforce or put into effect the regulations of the Village relating
to the inspection of electrical equipment.
   (C)   Police Power: The Electrical Inspector and assistant electrical
inspectors who may be designated, and who are under the direction of the
Electrical Inspector, shall have full police power and shall have the right to
arrest any person who violates any of the electrical regulations of the
Village.
   (D)   Attach Official Notices And Seals: The Electrical Inspector or the
assistant electrical inspectors are hereby empowered to attach to electrical
cabinets and equipment, an official notice or seal to prevent use of
electricity, and it shall be unlawful for any other person to put or attach
such seal or to break, change, destroy, tear, mutilate, cover or otherwise to
deface or injure any such official notice or seal posted by the Inspector.
   (E)   Permits: The Electrical Inspector shall issue permits for such
installation and alteration of electrical equipment in all cases where
application for such permit shall be made in accordance with the rules and
regulations applicable thereto.
   (F)   Inspection And Certificates Of Inspection:
      1.   The Electrical Inspector or the assistant electrical inspectors of
the Village shall inspect all electrical equipment installed or altered, except
such electrical equipment as may be lawfully exempt, and shall require that it
conform to the electrical regulations of this Village.
      2.   Upon completion of such installation or alteration in compliance
with the electrical regulations of the Village, the Electrical Inspector shall,
on request made by a registered electrical contractor, issue a certificate of
inspection covering such installation or alteration; provided, however, that no
such certificate shall be issued until all inspection fees for such
installation have been paid.
   (G)   Reinspection: The Electrical Inspector or the assistant electrical
inspectors are hereby empowered to reinspect any electrical equipment within
the scope of the electrical regulations of the Village, and when said equipment
is found to be unsafe to life or property, shall notify in writing the person
owning, using or operating the same to place such electrical equipment in a
safe and secure condition in compliance with the electrical regulations of this
Village within such time as the Electrical Inspector shall consider just and
reasonable. Refusal or failure to comply with the requirements of such
notification shall subject the person owning, using or operating such
electrical equipment to the penalties provided for in this Ordinance and in
addition thereto the Electrical Inspector or the assistant electrical
inspectors of the Village are hereby empowered to cut off and stop current to
any such electrical equipment found unsafe to life or property.
   (H)   To Keep Records: The Electrical Inspector shall keep complete records
of all permits issued and inspections made and other official work performed
under the electrical regulations of the Village.
   (I)   Temporary Current Permits: Whenever any electrical equipment has been
installed or altered, no electrical current shall be used on such equipment,
except as hereinafter provided, previous to the inspection of such equipment by
the Electrical Inspector or by an assistant electrical inspector under his
jurisdiction and the issuance of a temporary current permit covering designated
portions or the entirety of such installation or alteration; provided, however,
that in case of any installation or alteration, covered by permit authorizing
such installation or alteration, the portion of such equipment comprising the
service entrance equipment and wiring, the meter and meter connection cabinet
and the meter wiring up to but not beyond the customer's disconnecting switch
or other disconnecting device may be made electrically alive, prior to
inspection and the issuance of a temporary current permit; and provided
further, that in such case, the Electrical Inspector shall be notified of the
intention to make such portion of the equipment electrically alive and that the
customer's disconnecting switch or other disconnecting device shall be sealed
in the "off" position and tagged with a warning notice reading as follows:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place this switch in the "on" position
or to use electricity on any wiring beyond this switch previous to the
issuance, by the Electrical Inspector, of a temporary current permit or a
certificate of inspection authorizing the use of current on this installation.
   (K)   Suspend Work Of Electrical Contractor And To Revoke Permits: The
Electrical Inspector is hereby empowered to suspend the permit privileges of
any registered electrical contractor who shall fail to pay any just
indebtedness to the Village for inspection fees for electrical wires and
apparatus as fixed by the Village, until such registered electrical contractor
shall discharge and pay to the Village all just indebtedness then due and owing
from such registered electrician.
The Electrical Inspector is authorized to revoke any permit or certificate
obtained by fraud, misrepresentation, or in any way contrary to the provisions
of the electrical regulations of this Ordinance, for the installation,
alteration, repair and use of any electrical equipment.
   (K)   Personal Liability: In all cases where any action is taken by the
Electrical Inspector to enforce the electrical regulations of the Village, such
acts shall be done in the name of and on behalf of the Village and the said
Electrical Inspector in so acting for the Village shall not render himself
liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any
such act committed in good faith in the discharge of his duties, and any suit
brought against said Electrical Inspector by reason thereof shall be defended
by the Village, at its costs, until final termination of the proceedings
contained therein. (Ord. 71-259, 7-13-1971)
1-12-3: ADMINISTRATION OF ELECTRICAL REGULATIONS:
The Electrical Inspector shall administer the electrical regulations adopted by
the Village. (Ord. 71-259, 7-13-1971)
1-12-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this Ordinance shall be fined as
provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code for each such offense. (Ord. 71-259, 7-13-1971; amd. Ord.
95-23, 10-10-1995)

HEALTH OFFICER
