CHAPTER 14
SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
1-14-1: Appointment; Duties
1-14-2: Assistant Superintendent Of Public Works
1-14-1: APPOINTMENT; DUTIES:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall be appointed annually by the President
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, and shall hold office
until his successor is appointed and duly qualified. He shall have charge of
the maintenance of the sewer and water system of the Village, and shall receive
as compensation, such sums as the Board of Trustees may authorize to be paid as
provided by ordinance. When empowered by the Board of Trustees, he shall have
authority to engage the services of other individuals or corporations in the
maintenance of said system. (Ord. 78-10, 4-4-1978)
1-14-2: ASSISTANT SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
An Assistant Superintendent of Public Works shall be appointed annually by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, and shall hold
office until his successor is appointed and duly qualified. He shall assist the
Superintendent and shall exercise the powers of the Superintendent when said
Superintendent is ill, disabled or absent from the Village. (Ord. 78-10, 4-4-
1978)
CHAPTER 15
PUBLIC RELATIONS COMMISSIONER
SECTION:
1-15-1: Appointment; Duties
1-15-1: APPOINTMENT; DUTIES:
With the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees the President may annually
appoint a Commissioner of Public Relations who shall serve for a period of one
year and until his successor is appointed and duly qualified without
compensation, and whose duty it shall be to encourage the development of the
Village by attraction of new residents and industries and report to the Board
on the progress thereof together with any recommendations he might have for
their consideration, from time to time. (1940 Code Sec. 2-12)
CHAPTER 16
INSPECTOR OF WEIGHTS AND MEASURES
SECTION:
1-16-1: Appointment
1-16-2: Duties
1-16-3: Suitable Facilities
1-16-4: False Measures
1-16-1: APPOINTMENT:
The President may annually appoint with the advice and consent of the Board an
Inspector of Weights and Measures who shall receive as his compensation a
percent of all fees by him collected. He shall hold office for a period of one
year and until his successor is appointed and duly qualified. If no such
appointment is made, the Chief of Police or any duly appointed officer of the
Police Department, may exercise the powers and duties of this office. (1940
Code Sec. 2-11)
1-16-2: DUTIES:
His duties shall include the inspection once in each year of all weights,
measures, scales, balances, steelyards and other instruments used for weighing
and measuring devices in the Village except track scales and scales of a
capacity of three (3) tons or more and automatic or mechanical pumps or liquid
measuring devices which shall be inspected once in every six (6) months, and he
shall deliver to the owners thereof for money collected in accordance with
other sections of this Code. On the day of his receipt of fees he shall remit
the same, less his fees, together with a report thereon to the Clerk who shall
make report thereon at the next Board meeting and file the same for record,
remitting said funds to the Treasurer within one week of their receipts. The
Inspector shall have such police powers necessary to enforce applicable
provisions and regulations of this Code. (1940 Code Sec. 2-11)
1-16-3: SUITABLE FACILITIES:
Suitable facilities for proper measure in accordance with State standards shall
be made available to him. He is hereby given police powers to inspect packages
or accounts of commodities in order to determine whether they contain the
measure they are represented to have on sale and to make arrests with or
without warrant for violation of this Chapter. In the discretion of the
Inspector he may accept such evidence as may be available on the accuracy of
the weight or measure. (1940 Code Sec. 2-11)
1-16-4: FALSE MEASURES:
Any person found guilty of using false measures shall be fined as in this Code
provided. The Inspector is further empowered to condemn and confiscate false
weights and measures after lapse of ten (10) days from his notification to the
owner thereof of their inaccuracy. He shall also have power to seize and hold
false weights and measures as evidence in all procedures for violation of this
Chapter. (1940 Code Sec. 2-11)
CHAPTER 17
CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER
SECTION:
1-17-1: Position Established
1-17-2: Function
1-17-3: Duties
1-17-4: Compensation
1-17-1: POSITION ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established the position of Code Enforcement Officer for the
Village. (Ord. 66-143, 10-11-1966)
1-17-2: FUNCTION:
The function of the Code Enforcement Officer shall be to make inspections of
buildings and properties located within the Village to determine if they comply
with the Housing Code, National Building Code, National Fire Prevention Code,
Zoning Title and other codes and provisions of this Village Code. (Ord. 66-143,
10-11-1966)
1-17-3: DUTIES:
   (A)   The Code Enforcement Officer shall perform his duties and make
specific inspections only upon the direction of the corporate authorities.
   (B)   The Code Enforcement Officer shall make reports of all inspections to
the corporate authorities.
   (C)   Said Officer shall appear in court as directed by the corporate
authorities to testify in support of Code enforcement court actions. (Ord. 66-
143, 10-11-1966)
1-17-4: COMPENSATION:
The Code Enforcement Officer shall be paid a reasonable compensation based on
an hourly rate for services actually rendered, said rate to be determined by
the corporate authorities. (Ord. 66-143, 10-11-1966)
CHAPTER 18
BUILDING COMMISSIONER
SECTION:
1-18-1: Position Created
1-18-2: Appointment, Term
1-18-3: Duties
1-18-4: Powers
1-18-5: Salary
1-18-1: POSITION CREATED:
There is hereby created the position of Building Commissioner of the Village
who shall be under the supervision of the President and Board of Trustees, and
who shall see to the effective enforcement of all provisions of this Code
relating to buildings or zoning. (Ord. 76-7, 3-2-1976, eff. 4-30-1976)
1-18-2: APPOINTMENT, TERM:
A person competent to carry out the duties of the office of Building
Commissioner shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. Such appointment shall be for a term of one
year, and at such salary as may be provided by ordinance. The Building
Commissioner may be removed from office by the Village President at his
discretion. (Ord. 78-11, 4-4-1978)
1-18-3: DUTIES:
The Building Commissioner shall enforce all building and zoning provisions of
this Code. He shall have the power to order all work stopped on construction or
alteration or repair of buildings in the Village when such work is being done
in violation of any provisions relating thereto. Work shall not be resumed
after the issuance of such an order, except on the written permission of the
Building Commissioner; provided, that if the stop order is an oral one, it
shall be followed by a written stop order within one hour. (Ord. 69-186, 5-13-
1969)
1-18-4: POWERS:
The Building Commissioner shall have the power to make or cause to be made an
entry, at any reasonable hour, into any building or premises where the work of
altering, repairing or constructing any building or structure is going on, for
the purpose of making inspections. (Ord. 69-186, 5-13-1969)
1-18-5: SALARY:
The salary of the Building Commissioner of the Village is set at the sum of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per month. (Ord. 87-6, 5-12-1987)
CHAPTER 19
PLUMBING INSPECTOR
SECTION:
1-19-1: Position Established
1-19-2: Function
1-19-3: Duties
1-19-4: Compensation
1-19-1: POSITION ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established the position of Plumbing Inspector for the Village.
(Ord. 66-147, 11-22-1966)
1-19-2: FUNCTION:
The function of the Plumbing Inspector shall be to have immediate supervision
of all work done by plumbers, master sewer builders and certified drain layers
and gas fitters in connection with the plumbing, drainage and gas fitting of
buildings or structures in the Village and the connecting of such plumbing and
drainage with the sewer and water supply systems of the Village; he shall
investigate complaints pertaining to the drainage and plumbing of premises;
examine all plans as to drainage, plumbing and gas fitting, prior to the
issuance of permits for the work proposed to be done; he shall approve such
plans if the proposed work in all respects complies with the requirements of
provisions of this Code, he shall point out particulars, if any, in which the
proposed plans do not conform to the requirements of applicable Village Code
regulations. (Ord. 66-147, 11-22-1966)
1-19-3: DUTIES:
   (A)   The Plumbing Inspector shall be a master plumber and shall perform his
duties and make specific inspections only upon the direction of the corporate
authorities.
   (B)   The Plumbing Inspector shall make reports of all inspections to the
corporate authorities. (Ord. 66-147, 11-22-1966)
1-19-4: COMPENSATION:
The Plumbing Inspector shall be paid a reasonable compensation based on an
hourly rate for services actually rendered, said rate to be determined by the
corporate authorities. (Ord. 66-147, 11-22-1966)
CHAPTER 20
ORDINANCES
SECTION:
1-20-1: Style
1-20-2: Recording Of Votes Cast
1-20-3: Veto
1-20-4: Publications
1-20-5: Remittance Of Fines
1-20-6: Working Out Penalty
1-20-1: STYLE:
Ordinances passed by the Village may be in the following style: "Be it ordained
by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Forest View". (1940
Code Sec. 3-1)
1-20-2: RECORDING OF VOTES CAST:
The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all ordinances, on all
propositions to create any liability against the Village, for the appropriation
of expenditure of its money and in such other cases as any member of the Board
may direct. The concurrence of a majority of the Trustees elected to the Board
shall be necessary for the passage of any ordinance or other proposition, and
the yeas and nays on all propositions shall be recorded in the journal of the
Board's proceedings. (1940 Code Sec. 3-2)
1-20-3: VETO:
Before all ordinances shall take effect they shall be deposited in the office
of the Village Clerk after passage. If the President approves the ordinance, he
shall sign it. If he disapproves, he shall return it to the Board at its next
regular meeting occurring not less than five (5) days of the original roll call
and veto, together with his objections in writing. Such veto, in the case of an
appropriation ordinance, may extend to any one or more items of the ordinance
making an appropriation. Where the President fails to return said ordinance by
the time aforementioned with his objections, the ordinance shall take effect as
if, in fact, signed by him. Upon an ordinance's veto by the President it shall
require the affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the Trustees elected to
pass the same notwithstanding the veto. (1940 Code Sec. 3-3)
1-20-4: PUBLICATIONS:
Within one month after passage all ordinances imposing any fine, imprisonment,
forfeiture or making any appropriation shall be published by posting copies of
the same in three (3) public places within the Village limits, or in a
newspaper of general circulation in the Village, and shall not take effect
until ten (10) days after being so published. All other ordinances, unless
otherwise provided in the ordinance itself, shall take effect from and after
their passage. (1940 Code Sec. 3-4)
1-20-5: REMITTANCE OF FINES:
All fines and forfeitures for violation of ordinances shall be paid into the
Treasury by the officer receiving said fine within one week after their receipt
and be accompanied by a statement showing the name of the offender, the nature
of the offense and the amount of the fine. (1940 Code Sec. 3-5)
1-20-6: WORKING OUT PENALTY:
Where an offender is unable to pay the fine or penalty and costs assessed
against him in a proceeding, and said person is imprisoned in the Village Jail
it shall be the duty of the Superintendent of Public Works to provide suitable
labor, as provided by law, on a Village project until the fine is worked out.
Exclusive of board, the person shall be allowed a credit for each day's work on
account of such fine and costs 1 . (1940 Code Sec. 3-6)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-9.
CHAPTER 21
FINANCES
SECTION:
1-21-1: Deposit Of Funds
1-21-2: Depository Designated
1-21-3: Disbursal Of Funds
1-21-4: Audit
1-21-5: Clerk's Records
1-21-6: Appropriation And Levy
1-21-1: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
The Treasurer shall keep separate and distinct accounts of the gas tax, special
assessment and general funds of the Village and shall deposit all Village funds
received by him not later than the day following their receipt. These funds
shall be known and designated, respectively as "Village of Forest View, Motor
Fuel Tax Fund", "Village of Forest View Special Assessment Fund" and "Village
of Forest View, General Fund". Each shall be kept in a bank as designated by
Section
1-21-2 hereof, and said bank shall only remain qualified as a depository of
said funds upon furnishing the Village Board with a copy of all bank statements
it is required to furnish to the State Auditor of Public Accounts. Upon failure
to furnish said copies within a reasonable time of their issuance, the various
officers authorized to collaborate in the withdrawal of funds shall immediately
withdraw all of said funds and redeposit the funds which shall in the interim
remain in the custody of the Treasurer, within a reasonable time in an
appropriate bank. A special meeting of the Board to designate such new
depository shall be held before the redeposit of said funds. The Treasurer's
custody of funds shall at all times be in conformity with State laws. (1940
Code Sec. 4-1)
1-21-2: DEPOSITORY DESIGNATED:
The Bank of Lyons is hereby designated as one of the depositories of the funds
of the Village, and the officers or employees of the Village are hereby
authorized to endorse, in the name of the Village for the purpose of deposit
and collection in and with said Bank, checks, drafts, notes and other like
obligations, issued or drawn to and owned by the Village, and it is further
resolved that endorsements for deposit and collection may be by the written or
stamped endorsement of the Village without designation of the party making the
endorsement.
Said Bank is hereby authorized to pay out the funds of the Village on deposit
with it from time to time upon checks drawn upon said depository and signed in
the name of the Village by its Treasurer and countersigned by its President and
Clerk, whether said checks are payable to cash, bearer or the order of the
Village, or to any third party, or to the order of any signing or
countersigning officer of the Village or any other Village officer, in either
their individual or official capacity.
Said Bank shall not be in any manner whatsoever responsible for or required to
see to the application of any of the funds of the Village deposited with it,
checked out or borrowed from it, or secured by the discount of notes and other
obligations to it as hereinbefore provided, and all such transactions shall be
conclusively presumed to be legally binding upon the Village. (Ord. 66-142,
1966)
1-21-3: DISBURSAL OF FUNDS:
All warrants (which shall state the particular fund on which drawn) and all
withdrawals of the Village funds shall be signed by the President, Clerk and
Treasurer. When otherwise signed they shall be invalid, and, immediately upon
the change of personnel in any of said offices and at all times a resolution by
the Board shall be forwarded and kept on hand by depository incorporating
therein as exhibits the signatures of the authorized officers. It is a
mandatory duty of the President, Clerk and Treasurer to prepare, execute and
forward checks in payment of vouchers approved by the Board of Trustees within
ten (10) days of the date of approval. (Ord. 75-351, 10-7-1975)
1-21-4: AUDIT:
Annually at the close of the fiscal year it shall be the duty of the Board to
convene and cause to be audited the books, records and accounts of the
Treasurer, Collector, Clerk and all other officers who may have charge of the
collection, custody or disbursement of Village funds. If they deem it
necessary, a certified public accountant shall be retained to assist in said
audit. (1946 Code Sec. 4-3)
1-21-5: CLERK'S RECORDS:
The Clerk shall keep in form satisfactory to the Board a complete record of all
fees received by him and of the disposition of said fees. (1940 Code Sec. 4-4)
1-21-6: APPROPRIATION AND LEVY:
Appropriation and levy ordinances shall annually be passed by the Board in
accordance with State laws; and the fiscal year of the Village shall begin on
May 1 of each year. (1940 Code Sec. 4-5)
CHAPTER 22
VILLAGE SEAL
SECTION:
1-22-1: Village Seal
1-22-1: VILLAGE SEAL:
The seal of the Village shall be an obverse side bearing the legend "Village of
Forest View, Incorporated December 12, 1924" encircling and closest to its
outer rim, the word "Corporate"; within an inner circle, the word "Illinois" at
the reverse side of said circle and its lower rim, and the word "seal" in the
center. (1940 Code Sec. 2-1)
CHAPTER 23
CIVIL EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
1-23-1: Definitions
1-23-2: Emergency Declared
1-23-3: Regulations Imposed
1-23-4: Effective Period
1-23-5: Notice To News Media
1-23-6: Interpretation
1-23-1: DEFINITIONS:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS: For the purpose of this Chapter "alcoholic liquors" shall
mean an alcoholic liquor as that term is defined by section 5/1-3.05 of an Act
Relating to Alcoholic Liquors, approved January 31, 1934, as amended. (235
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-3.05)
CIVIL EMERGENCY: (A) A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of
actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate
power to execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority
of law; or
   (B)   Any natural disaster or man made calamity, including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate
limits of the Village resulting in the death or injury of persons or the
destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be
taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare.
CURFEW: A prohibition against any person or persons walking, running,
loitering, standing or motoring upon an alley, street, highway, public property
or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the Village, excepting
officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty
with reference to said civil emergency. (Ord. 68-176, 12-10-1968)
1-23-2: EMERGENCY DECLARED:
Whenever on emergency as defined in Section
1-23-1 hereof exists, the President of the Board of Trustees shall declare its
existence by means of a written declaration under oath, finding that the
foregoing standards have been met, setting forth facts to substantiate such
findings and describing the nature of the emergency; which statement or
declaration shall be filed with the Clerk of the Municipality as soon as
practicable. (Ord. 68-176, 12-10-1968)
1-23-3: REGULATIONS IMPOSED:
After proclamation of a civil emergency by the President of the Board of
Trustees, he may order:
   (A)   A general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the Village,
or to the Village as a whole, as he deems advisable; and applicable during such
hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of the public
safety and welfare.
   (B)   Prohibit the sale or other transfer of possession, with or without
consideration, offer to sell or transfer, and the purchase of any ammunition,
guns and other firearms of any size or description.
   (C)   Prohibit the display by or in any store or shop of any ammunition,
guns and other firearms of any size or description.
   (D)   Prohibit the possession in a public place of a rifle or shotgun by any
person, except a duly authorized law enforcement official or person in military
service acting in the official performance of his duty.
   (E)   Prohibit the possession of any rifle or shotgun in any place, public
or private, by a nonresident who has not been issued a permit for the purchase
and possession of rifles and shotguns.
   (F)   Prohibit the sale of any alcoholic liquor.
   (G)   Prohibit the possession on the person in a public place of any
portable container containing any alcoholic liquor.
   (H)   Close places of public assemblage with designated exceptions.
   (I)   Prohibit the sale or other transfer of possession, with or without
consideration, of gasoline or any other flammable or combustible liquid
altogether or except by delivery into a tank properly affixed to an operable
motor-driven vehicle, bike, scooter, boat or airplane and necessary for the
propulsion thereof. (Ord. 68-176, 12-10-1968)
1-23-4: EFFECTIVE PERIOD:
The proclamation herein authorized shall be effective for a period of forty
eight (48) hours unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the President of
the Board of Trustees indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists. The
President shall have the power to reproclaim the existence of a civil emergency
at the end of each forty eight (48) hour period during the time the said civil
emergency exists. (Ord. 68-176, 12-10-1968)
1-23-5: NOTICE TO NEWS MEDIA:
Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the Chief of Police shall
notify the news media situated within the Village and cause three (3) copies of
the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the
following places within the Village: the Village Hall, the police station and
the post office. (Ord. 68-176, 12-10-1968)
1-23-6: INTERPRETATION:
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed to impair the powers
contained in the Municipal Code of the Village giving powers to the Police and
Fire Departments, but shall be construed together with existing provisions now
in effect for the safety and welfare of the citizens of the Village. (Ord. 68-
176, 12-10-1968)
CHAPTER 24
VILLAGE HALL
SECTION:
1-24-1: Use For Village Public Purpose; Residents Only
1-24-2: Private And Other Governmental Use; Application
1-24-3: Restrictions On Use
1-24-4: Sanctions; Revocation
1-24-5: Charges For Use Of Multi-Purpose Room Of Village Hall
1-24-1: USE FOR VILLAGE PUBLIC PURPOSE; RESIDENTS ONLY:
The Village Hall, or any part or facility thereof, including the Village multi-
purpose room, shall be used and occupied exclusively for the public purposes of
the Village, except as provided hereinbelow. The Village Hall and multi-purpose
room shall be available for use only for residents of the Village as described
further in this Chapter. (Ord. 92-12, 9-8-1992)
1-24-2: PRIVATE AND OTHER GOVERNMENTAL USE; APPLICATION:
Every person, group or organization desiring to use the Village Hall, or any
part or facility thereof, for a private purpose, or any governmental or school
authority desiring to use the Village Hall, or any part thereof, for an
official purpose, shall file an application therefor with the Village Clerk
upon a form furnished by the Village. Said application shall contain the
following information:
   (A)   Name, address and telephone number of applicant;
   (B)   If application is made on behalf of a group, club or organization, its
name and the names, addresses and telephone numbers of its officers;
   (C)   Date(s) and time period(s) of contemplated use and/or frequency
(weekly or monthly basis);
   (D)   Purpose of use;
   (E)   Food service or name and address of caterer, if any;
   (F)   Such additional information as the Board of Trustees shall deem
necessary.
All applications must be approved by a majority vote of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 74-314, 6-25-1974)
1-24-3: RESTRICTIONS ON USE:
The use of the Village Hall or any part thereof, shall be subject to the
following conditions and restrictions and such additional conditions as may be
imposed, from time to time, by the corporate authorities:
   (A)   Except in the case of a request by a governmental or school authority,
all applicants must be a resident of the Village. If application is made on
behalf of a civic, social, charitable or religious organization, club or group,
the application must establish that the majority of the active members of such
organization, club or group are residents of the Village. Use of the Village
Hall for a private party shall be limited to residents of the Village and their
immediate families who reside within the Village.
   (B)   All use of the Village Hall, or any part or facility thereof, must
terminate at or before one o'clock (1:00) A.M., and all persons will be
required to leave the premises at such time.
   (C)   Each applicant, group or organization must agree to indemnify and hold
harmless the Village against any claim, loss, action or judgment against the
Village, its officers, agents or employees, arising out of the use and
enjoyment of the Village Hall, or any part thereof, by such applicant, group or
organization. Further, each applicant shall agree to pay and reimburse the
Village for any damage to or destruction of Village property occurring as a
result of the use of the Village Hall.
   (D)   The Board room shall not be available for private parties. Under
exceptional circumstances, the Board room will be available for a Village party
or celebration. (Ord. 77-20, 12-20-1977)
1-24-4: SANCTIONS; REVOCATION:
If any person, group or organization shall submit an application that is found
to contain inaccurate or misleading statements or information, or if any
person, group or organization shall fail, refuse or neglect to fulfill its
obligations and commitments under its application, the Board of Trustees may
refuse to approve such application or any subsequent applications from such
person, group or organization. The Board of Trustees, after having granted an
application, may withdraw such permission if there is found any
misrepresentation or misstatement in connection therewith or if the Board
determines that such use would not be in the best interests of the Village.
(Ord. 74-314, 6-25-1974)
1-24-5: CHARGES FOR USE OF MULTI-PURPOSE ROOM OF VILLAGE HALL:
The Board shall, from time to time, establish charges, fees and other rules and
regulations relating to the use of the multi- purpose room. Such regulation
shall be approved by the Board by motion at a regular meeting or a special
meeting called for that purpose. Any such policies, procedures, or schedules
shall be made available to all parties interested in using the multi- purpose
room. (Ord. 93-23, 9-28-1993)
CHAPTER 25
POLICE PENSION FUND
SECTION:
1-25-1: Fund Established
1-25-2: Deposits
1-25-1: FUND ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established in and for the Village a Police Pension Fund in
accordance with and subject to the terms and provisions of "An Act to provide
for the setting apart, formation and disbursement of a police pension fund in
cities, villages and incorporated towns having a population of not more than
two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants", approved June 14, 1909, as
amended. (Ord. 59-17, 5-19-1959)
1-25-2: DEPOSITS:
There shall be deposited in the Pension Fund the sums required by law, which
shall include five percent (5%) per month deducted from the salary of each
member of the police force, and the proceeds of an annual tax of not to exceed
five one-hundredths percent (0.05%) which shall be levied as from time to time
required; and also three-fourths (3/4) of the dog licenses, all the monies
received for special detail of police officers, ten percent (10%) of fines
collected for violation of provisions of this Code, money received as fines
imposed upon policemen, rewards turned over to the Pension Fund, and ten
percent (10%) of the license revenue exclusive of vehicle licenses, which shall
be contributed to the Pension Fund, as required by statute. (Ord. 59-17, 5-19-
1959)
CHAPTER 26
PARK SUPERINTENDENT
SECTION:
1-26-1: Creation
1-26-2: Duties; Term Of Office
1-26-3: Salary
1-26-4: Enforcement Of Regulations
1-26-1: CREATION:
There is hereby created the office of Park Superintendent of the Village of
Forest View, who shall be under the supervision of the Village President and
who shall see to the effective enforcement of all laws pertaining to park
property within the Village of Forest View. (Ord. 72-271, 2-22-1972)
1-26-2: DUTIES; TERM OF OFFICE:
The office of Park Superintendent shall be filled by an appointment made by the
Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees,
of a person competent to carry out the duties of said office. Such appointment
shall be for a term of one year. The Park Superintendent may be removed from
office by the Village President at his discretion. (Ord. 72-271, 2-22-1972)
1-26-3: SALARY:
The salary for the Park Superintendent shall be at the rate of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per month. (Ord. 72-271, 2-22-1972)
1-26-4: ENFORCEMENT OF REGULATIONS:
The Park Superintendent shall enforce all ordinances and regulations pertaining
to the operation of any park property within the Village of Forest View. The
Park Superintendent shall have such further powers as may be granted by the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Forest View. (Ord. 72-271, 2-
22-1972)

SECTION:

SECTION:

1-30-2: Duties

1-30-3: SALARY:
