   Article FIREWORKS
5-7-27: Definition
5-7-28: Prohibitions
5-7-28.1: Advertising
5-7-29: Display In Public Places
5-7-30: Displays On Private Property
5-7-31: Permit Fee
5-7-32: Exemption
   Article VIOLATION OF CHAPTER PROVISIONS
5-7-33: Penalty
   EXPLOSIVES
5-7-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in blasting operations or in any other activity using
explosives, or shall have, keep, sell, use, or give away any black powder in
excess of five (5) pounds, guncotton, blasting powder, giant powder, dynamite,
nitroglycerine, fulminate of mercury, or any other explosives, or any
substances, compound, mixture, or article having properties of such a character
that alone, or in combination or contiguity with other substances or compounds,
may decompose suddenly and generate sufficient heat, gas, or pressure, or all
of them, to produce rapid flaming combustion or administer a destructive blow
to persons or property; nor shall any person keep, sell, give away, offer for
sale, or transport, any loaded paper shells, metallic shot, loaded cartridges,
blank cartridges, percussion caps, primers, or detonators, nor keep or store
flashlight powder in excess of five (5) pounds within the corporate limits of
the Village except in the manner and upon the conditions hereinafter provided
and without first obtaining a license therefor. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-2: APPLICATION:
A written application for a license under this Chapter shall be made to the
Fire Chief and otherwise in conformity with the general requirements of this
Code relating to applications for licenses. In addition, the applicant shall
set forth the location at which it is desired or intended to keep such
explosives, or any other substance mentioned in the preceding Section, the
maximum amount of such explosives, or any of them intended to be kept on hand
at any one time at such place, and shall state whether such explosives are to
be kept in bulk or in barrels, canisters, or other containers, and the number
of loaded shells, loaded cartridges, blank cartridges, percussion caps,
primers, or detonators, or the number of pounds of flashlight powder, intended
to be kept on hand at any one time in such place. Any applicant engaging in
blasting operations or in any other activity using explosives shall further
state in his application the nature of the work to be performed, the site of
the proposed work, the location of the magazine in which it is intended to keep
such explosives, and the quantity and kind of explosives to be kept therein.
Upon receipt of such application, the Fire Chief shall make, or cause to be
made, an investigation for the purpose of ascertaining whether the place at
which it is desired or intended to keep, sell, offer for sale, use, or give
away such explosives or other aforementioned substances is so situated that a
license to keep such loaded paper shells, metallic shot, loaded cartridges,
blank cartridges, percussion caps, primers, detonators, or flashlight powder in
the quantity desired would not be so dangerous as to constitute a nuisance or
be a menace to the safety of the public or of adjoining property, and also
whether the conditions under which such explosives, cartridges, percussion
caps, flashlight powder, or any of them, are to be kept or handled shall be
such as to provide the maximum of safety. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-3: LICENSE FEE:
The annual license fee for each license issued pursuant to the provisions of
this Chapter shall be the sum of two hundred twenty five dollars ($225.00);
provided, that if the applicant shall desire a license for the sole purpose of
keeping, selling, or giving away within the Village loaded paper shells,
metallic shot, loaded cartridges, or blank cartridges designed or intended to
be used in shotguns, pistols, rifles, or other firearms, and shall not desire
to have on hand at any time a greater quantity of such shells or cartridges in
the aggregate than twenty five thousand (25,000), the annual license fee shall
be the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-4: BONDS:
Each applicant for a license under this Chapter shall furnish and file with the
Fire Chief a bond with good and sufficient surety, conditioned for the payment
of any loss, damage, or injury resulting to persons or property by reason of
the use, sale, or keeping of such explosives, and for the strict observance of
the provisions of this Code relating to explosives and substances referred to
in Section
5-7-1 of this Chapter. Said bond shall be subject to the approval of the
Village Clerk and shall be filed in the office of the Village Clerk. Said bonds
shall be in amounts as follows:
For manufacturers, agents, and all others who desire to bring to, or sell
within, the corporate limits of the Village such explosives as are designated
in Section
5-7-1 of this Chapter, a bond in the penal sum of five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00), and in case of delivery being made by vehicles, an additional
sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each and every vehicle in excess
of one vehicle engaged within the Village in the delivery of such explosives.
Provided, however, no bond shall be required from any person receiving a
license for the sole purpose of keeping, selling, or giving away, within the
Village, loaded paper shells, metallic shot, loaded cartridges, or blank
cartridges designed or intended to be used in shotguns, pistols, rifles, or
firearms, as specified in Section
5-7-1 of this Chapter, where the total amount of such loaded paper shells,
metallic shot, loaded cartridges, or blank cartridges does not exceed twenty
five thousand (25,000).
For all contractors or others now engaged in, or purporting hereafter to engage
in, any activity involving explosives or blasting operations, a bond in one of
the following classes shall be required:
   (A)   For the right to use or have on hand in any one day explosives not
exceeding fifty (50) pounds, a bond in the sum of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00).
   (B)   For the right to use or have on hand in any one day explosives in
excess of fifty (50) pounds but not exceeding one hundred (100) pounds, a bond
of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00).
   (C)   For the right to use or have on hand in any one day explosives in
excess of one hundred (100) pounds but not exceeding two hundred (200) pounds,
a bond of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00).
   (D)   For the right to use or have on hand in any one day explosives in
excess of two hundred (200) pounds and not exceeding four hundred (400) pounds,
a bond of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00).
   (E)   For the right to use or have on hand in any one day explosives in
excess of four hundred (400) pounds, a bond of five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00); provided, however, that where the material used or kept on hand
in any one day shall consist only of nitrocellulose wet down with alcohol and
scrap film used in the manufacture of imitation leather, the amount of the bond
shall be two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00).
Provided, however, that in lieu of any such bond or bonds the licensee may
furnish the Village, subject to the approval of the Village Engineer and
Village Attorney, public liability and property damage insurance coverage in
like amount, by a policy of insurance issued therefor running to the Village or
by rider attached to any existing policy running to the Village, conditioned
upon the payment of any loss, damage or injury resulting to persons or property
by reason of the use, keeping, sale or transporting of such explosives, a
certified copy of such policy of insurance or such rider to be furnished the
Village Clerk.
All contractors or others engaging in blasting operations shall reimburse the
Village for the services of professional consultants employed by the Village to
regulate blasting operations. Such contractors and others engaging in blasting
operations shall deposit two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) with the
Village Clerk as security for the payment of the cost of such services. All
funds so deposited with the Village Clerk which are not required by the Village
to pay the cost of such services shall be returned after all such professional
consultants' fees have been paid by the Village. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-5: CERTIFICATE OF FITNESS:
Before any operation shall begin under a license for the transportation of any
explosives, or for the use of explosives in any manner, or for blasting, the
licensee shall file with the Fire Chief, in writing, the name or names of the
person or persons designated by him to handle said explosives or to load holes
or discharge explosives, to prepare charges and load the holes, to transport
any vehicle or otherwise, or to have the care of magazines.
Any such person, before being permitted to exercise any of such functions,
shall file a written application, with the Fire Chief for a "certificate of
fitness", and before the issuance of any such certificate the Fire Chief shall
examine such applicant as to his qualifications to fill such position or
positions, under the conditions herein prescribed. No person shall be permitted
to have the actual care and handling of such explosives without first having
obtained a certificate of fitness as herein provided. Such certificate of
fitness shall be subject to inspection by any member of the Fire or Police
Department at all times. The annual fee for such certificate of fitness shall
be fifteen dollars ($15.00) to be paid to the Village Clerk.
To receive a certificate of fitness the person must:
   (A)   Be at least twenty one (21) years of age;
   (B)   Be able to understand and speak the English language;
   (C)   Be of temperate habits;
   (D)   Have letters of recommendation from his last two (2) employers (if
any), and, if he has not been in the service of his last employer for at least
three (3) years, a letter testifying to his good character and capacity from
his last employer;
   (E)   Be familiar with the laws and the provisions of this Code governing
the transportation, storage, and use of explosives, particularly that part
relating to the service to be performed by the applicant; and
   (F)   Be familiar with the risks incident to the service to be performed by
him, and capable of taking all necessary precautions.
Nothing herein contained shall prevent a licensee from applying for and
obtaining a certificate of fitness if entitled to the same under the provisions
of this Section. The actual work done must at all times be conducted by a
person holding a certificate of fitness. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-6: INSPECTION:
No person shall engage in blasting operations without giving the Fire Chief not
less than twenty four (24) hours' notice in advance of each incidence of
blasting. The Fire Chief shall appoint an inspector whose duty it shall be to
make frequent inspection of all premises and work of all licensees. Said
inspection shall include detailed and exact examination of the manner in which
licensees are complying with the provisions of this Chapter, and whether all
due and reasonable precautions to avoid accidents are being taken, and shall
include a verification that all employees who are performing work for which a
certificate of fitness is required are in possession of such certificate. The
inspector shall make a report in writing to the Fire Chief at the close of each
day's inspection, stating conditions observed, and such reports shall be kept
on file by the Fire Chief. The Fire Chief may employ professional consultants
to aid in the regulation of blasting operations. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-7: SALES TO OTHER THAN LICENSEES:
It shall be unlawful for any person, or his agent or employee, to sell, offer
for sale, or give to any person for purposes of sale any of the substances or
explosives mentioned in Section
5-7-1 of this Chapter, unless such person receiving such substances shall have
procured and be in possession of a license as required by this Chapter;
provided, however, that the provisions of this Section shall not apply to
flashlight powder or black powder where the amount involved is less than five
(5) pounds. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-8: WEEKLY REPORT OF SALES:
Any person selling, offering for sale, or giving away any of the aforementioned
substances or explosives to any person within the Village shall file a weekly
statement of such sales or deliveries to the Fire Chief. Such statement shall
be verified as to its correctness by an affidavit and shall specify the
deliveries for the preceding week for use within the Village and in detail as
follows:
   (A)   Date of delivery,
   (B)   Name of buyer,
   (C)   Point of delivery,
   (D)   Number of pounds, and name, character, kind and strength of
explosives.
Such statements shall be on forms provided by the Fire Chief and must be
delivered by mail or messenger not later than the second business day in each
week. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-9: ANALYSIS OF EXPLOSIVES:
The Fire Chief shall designate a chemist whose duty it shall be to analyze and
test such explosives as are brought or submitted to him by applicants for
licenses or certificates.
All dynamite containing nitroglycerin shall be tested by the chemist according
to the potassium iodide starch heat test, otherwise known as the British heat
test. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-10: SUBMISSION OF SAMPLES FOR ANALYSIS:
No license shall be granted to any person engaged in the use or sale of
dynamite or other explosive until such dealer, contractor, or other person
heretofore referred to, shall first submit to the chemist for analysis a sample
of such dynamite or any other explosive sought to be used or sold, and whenever
such chemist shall certify that such sample is of standard purity and quality,
a license shall be issued, if all other requirements heretofore prescribed are
complied with.
It shall be the duty of the inspector from time to time to bring a sample of
dynamite or other explosives sold or used by licensees, and to submit such
sample to the chemist, who shall analyze and test same, and if it shall be
found that such sample is not of standard purity and quality, the license of
such licensee shall be revoked by the Village President. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-11: TRANSPORTATION OF EXPLOSIVES ON PUBLIC WAYS:
   (A)   No explosives shall be transported in any vehicles through the public
ways of the Village unless such vehicle is in charge of two (2) competent
persons each holding a certificate of fitness for such purpose. Said
certificate of fitness shall be issued only to employees of a person duly
licensed to transport or sell explosives in the Village.
   (B)   Any mechanically propelled vehicle used for the transportation of
explosives shall be in good condition for service, and shall have an enclosed
body completely fire protected on the outside. The motor, fuel tank,
carburetor, electric wiring and exhaust, shall be separate from the body of the
vehicle. Internal combustion engines shall be separated not less than two feet
(2') from the outer wall of the body in which explosives are to be carried. All
such vehicles must be constructed and maintained in accordance with
specifications of, and subject to the approval, of the Fire Chief, who shall
inspect or cause to be inspected all such vehicles at least once every six (6)
months.
   (C)   No metal tools or other pieces of metal shall be carried within a
vehicle carrying explosives, except in a separate tool box.
   (D)   No blasting caps or electric blasting caps or other combustible
material shall be transported in the same vehicles with other explosives.
   (E)   A vehicle carrying explosives shall have power amply able to draw the
load, and it shall avoid stoppages other than to load and unload, and no
unnecessary stops or stands shall be made.
   (F)   Vehicles carrying explosives must not be left standing unless
absolutely necessary, and then only when brakes are set and motors stopped.
   (G)   No explosives shall be left in a vehicle unless such vehicle is in
charge of an employee with a certificate of fitness, and no vehicle loaded with
explosives shall be left unattended.
   (H)   Every vehicle carrying more than five (5) pounds of explosive
substances referred to in Section
5-7-1 of this Chapter, shall display the words "EXPLOSIVES" painted on the rear
end and each side of such vehicle in letters at least ten inches (10") in
height.
   (I)   A vehicle carrying explosives shall avoid, whenever possible, those
public ways on which there are large numbers of persons.
   (J)   No intoxicated person shall be permitted on a vehicle carrying
explosives.
   (K)   No smoking within ten feet (10') of a vehicle loaded with explosives
shall be permitted.
   (L)   No person shall carry or transport in or upon such vehicle any
explosives in excess of two thousand (2,000) pounds.
   (M)   No person in charge of a vehicle carrying explosives shall deliver
them except in original and unbroken packages, nor at any place other than a
duly authorized magazine and to the person in charge thereof.
   (N)   Each vehicle shall carry an approved liquid chemical fire extinguisher
thereon of not less than two and one-half (21/2) gallons' capacity. (Ord. 77-
12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-12: EXPLOSIVES IN PUBLIC CONVEYANCES:
No person shall carry or transport on any public conveyance or on any railroad
car running from point to point in the Village, any black powder, guncotton,
giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerine, fulminate of mercury, or any other
explosive. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-13: TRANSPORTATION TO OR FROM VESSELS OR RAILROAD CARS:
Explosives received at any railway or freight stations within the Village
limits, for reshipment to points beyond the Village limits, shall be promptly
transferred; provided, however, that no explosives received for shipment shall
remain at any railway or freight station for a period exceeding forty eight
(48) hours. Every railroad car containing explosives within the Village limits
must be placarded on sides and ends with standard explosive placards as
prescribed by the Interstate Commerce Commission regulations for explosives and
other dangerous articles. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-14: LABELING OF PACKAGES:
Each package containing an explosive must have the name and brand of the
manufacturer marked thereon, and must be marked conspicuously as prescribed by
the Interstate Commerce Commission for explosives and other dangerous articles.
(Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-15: EXPLOSIVE CARTRIDGES:
All boxes in which explosive cartridges containing nitroglycerine are packed
must be lined with a suitable material that is impervious to liquid
nitroglycerine. Cardboard cartons closed at the bottom and made of strong and
flexible material that is impervious to nitroglycerine may be used as a lining.
At least one-fourth inch (1/4") of dry sawdust or wood pulp or similar material
must be spread over the bottom of the box before inserting the cartridges, and
all the vacant space in the top must be filled with this material. The
cartridges must be so arranged in the boxes that when they are transported with
the boxes top side up all cartridges will be on their sides and never on their
ends.
No explosive cartridge sold shall be larger than four inches (4") in diameter
and eight inches (8") long. Packages of explosives shall not contain more than
fifty (50) pounds. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-16: MAGAZINES:
No explosives shall be stored in any building other than a magazine.
Magazines for the storage of explosives shall be constructed as required under
the provisions of the National Fire Codes, 1973-74 Edition, Code for the
Manufacture, Transportation, Storage and Use of Explosives Material. (Ord. 77-
12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-17: THAWING OF EXPLOSIVES:
All thawing of frozen dynamite or other explosives by means of artificial heat
from any source, is prohibited within the Village. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-18: SUPERVISION OF MAGAZINES:
All magazines shall at all times be in the care of a competent employee whose
duty it shall be to see that no unauthorized person has access to them. Said
employee shall have no other duty that will interfere with his careful
supervision of such magazine or thaw house, and shall have a certificate of
fitness as a magazine keeper.
All magazines shall be painted bright red with the words "MAGAZINE - DANGER"
painted thereon in white letters on a black background. Such letters shall be
at least six inches (6") high.
Only persons who hold certificates of fitness, or other authorized persons,
shall be permitted to have access to magazines, which shall be kept securely
locked when not open for the introduction or removal of explosives or for
inspection by duly authorized officers of the Village. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-19: PERMIT FOR BLASTING:
Every person engaged in, as a principal, or connected with, any activity
involving explosives or blasting operations, shall make an application to the
Fire Chief for a permit to keep and use explosives, giving at the time, in
writing, the name of the licensee, location of the office or place of business,
the nature of the work, the description of any Village property located in the
blasting area, the proposed location of the magazine, together with plans and
descriptions of the construction of such magazine, the quantity and kind of
explosives proposed to be kept therein, and the names of the employees required
to have certificates of fitness, and designating structures located within the
sphere of blasting influence which will be photographed by the licensee.
The Fire Chief shall review said application to determine whether the proposed
location of the magazine, the description of the Village property and the
designation of structures to be photographed by the licensee are satisfactory.
If the Fire Chief approves such application, he shall transmit the same with
his approval thereon to the Village Clerk, who shall, upon payment by such
applicant to the Village Clerk of a permit fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00)
issue to such application a permit to locate the magazine at the location given
in such application.
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to move or cause to be moved any
magazine, after having received a permit for the use of same, until such
licensee shall make a new application to the Fire Chief for permission so to do
and shall have secured a permit for such purpose, and every application for
such permit shall specify the place at which it is desired to locate the
magazine proposed to be moved.
The Fire Chief shall recommend the revocation of any permit issued to blast
rock or any other substance for noncompliance with any of the provisions of
this Section. (Ord. 78-19, 5-16-1978)
5-7-20: BLASTING OPERATIONS:
   (A)   No blasting operations shall commence until all structures designated
by the Fire Chief within the sphere of blasting influence have been
photographed by the permittee to document their current condition.
   (B)   The permittee shall agree to make immediate repairs at the sole
expense of the permittee to any Village property designated by the Fire Chief
which is located within one thousand five hundred (1,500) yards of any blasting
site and which suffers damage within fourteen (14) days after any incidence of
blasting at such a site.
   (C)   In blasting, it shall be unlawful to use a quantity of explosive
exceeding in disruptive force the equivalent of one pound in weight of forty
percent (40%) dynamite for each two feet (2') depth of hole that is above or
less than ten feet (10') below the curb; and the equivalent of one pound in
weight of sixty percent (60%) dynamite, for each two feet (2') depth of hole
that is more than ten feet (10') below the curb.
   (D)   Frozen or partly frozen explosives shall not be placed in drill holes.
Frozen cartridges, if not capped, must be returned to the thawing apparatus to
be thawed. The removal of a primer from a frozen cartridge is hereby
prohibited.
   (E)   In tamping drill holes, wooden rammers only shall be employed. Tamping
by strokes is forbidden, and only direct application of pressure permitted.
   (F)   Blasts, except as hereinafter provided, shall be fired by the
application of some form of electrical current only. In blasting in stone
quarries, it shall be permissible to fire blasts by the application of time
fuses.
   (G)   In case of an explosion not carrying away the entire drill hole, but
leaving the lower part intact, it is prohibited to begin drilling from the
bottom of the old drill hole.
   (H)   In order to ensure the safety of surrounding property and persons, no
larger charge shall be used than is necessary to properly start the object it
is intended to wreck or blast, and excavating contiguous to any structure shall
be so carried on as not to cause damage to such structure. Weak walls or other
supports of such structure must be shored up. The blasting of decomposed or
soft rock is hereby prohibited.
   (I)   Before any blast shall be fired, except in tunnels, the rock to be
blasted shall be covered on the top and sides with timber and covered with
stout metal matting or some other equally serviceable material to prevent the
debris from flying.
   (J)   When necessary, competent man carrying red flags shall be placed at a
reasonable distance from the blasts on all sides to give warning at least three
(3) minutes in advance.
   (K)   No blasting shall proceed on any day, unless the Fire Chief has been
given not less than twenty four (24) hours' notice that one or more blasts are
to be fired on such day. (Ord. 78-19, 5-16-1978)
5-7-21: STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES:
Fixed ammunition stored above the ground floor in a building used for any other
purpose shall be enclosed by wire netting, having no larger than one-fourth
inch (1/4") mesh, supported by iron or heavy wooden uprights. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-
1977)
5-7-22: PROHIBITED EXPLOSIVES:
The sale, transportation, or use of the following explosives are hereby
prohibited:
   (A)   Liquid nitroglycerine, except for medicinal purposes.
   (B)   Explosives containing chlorate of potash, perchlorate of potash, and
picric acid, except as used in blasting caps; provided, however, that any
explosive containing chlorate of potash may be sold if it first conforms to the
following test: such mixture must be able to withstand a glancing blow
inflicted with a rawhide mallet on soft wood without in any manner exploding,
and also such mixture must be made so as not to reduce the chlorate;
   (C)   Nitroglycerine cynamite containing over sixty percent (60%) of
nitroglycerine, or gelatine dynamite equal in strength to over seventy five
percent (75%) of nitroglycerine dynamite;
   (D)   Blasting caps containing less than nine and one-half (91/2) grains of
explosive mixture, at least eighty percent (80%) fulminate of mercury and
twenty percent (20%) chlorate of potash, or its equivalent detonating strength;
   (E)   Any fulminate of mercury in a dry condition;
   (F)   Any fulminate or other metals in any condition except as a component
of articles not otherwise prohibited;
   (G)   Any fireworks which combine an explosive and a detonator. (Ord. 77-12,
9-6-1977)
5-7-23: RESTRICTIONS ON EXPLOSIVES:
   (A)   No person shall have more than one thousand (1,000) electrical
detonators in stock at any time.
   (B)   Chlorides calculated as potassium chloride must not exceed one-fourth
of one percent (0.25%).
   (C)   Any explosive mixture containing chlorate of potash offered for sale
must contain no free acid or substance liable to produce free acid.
   (D)   All explosives containing chlorate of potash or nitro compounds shall
be subject to the British heat test.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful to sell, transport, or use leaky dynamite
(leaking nitroglycerine).
   (F)   The keeping or storing of nitro-cellulose in a dry condition in
quantities greater than ten (10) pounds in one place is hereby prohibited.
   (G)   The use of frozen or partly frozen cartridges and the breaking or
cutting of them or drilling them for caps is hereby prohibited.
   (H)   Blasting powder, black powder, sporting powder, rifle powder, all
military smokeless powder, and low blasting explosives shall be packed in metal
cases containing not more than twenty five (25) pounds. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-24: MANUFACTURE OF EXPLOSIVES IN VILLAGE:
No person shall manufacture, assemble, or mix anywhere within the Village any
black powder, guncotton, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerine, fulminate of
mercury, or other explosives of similar nature. Any person violating this
Section shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate and
distinct offense shall be considered as having been committed every day upon
which any such explosives are manufactured in the Village in violation of the
provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-25: SALES TO MINORS:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to sell, deliver or give to
any person under eighteen (18) years of age any black powder, dynamite,
nitroglycerine, guncotton or other explosive. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-26: SEIZURE OF EXPLOSIVES KEPT UNLAWFULLY:
If it shall be found that any of the explosives mentioned in Section
5-7-1 of this Chapter, are being kept in any building, structure or premises,
or in any vehicle within the Village in violation of any of the provisions of
this Chapter, any such explosives so kept shall be immediately seized and
removed to such place as the Fire Chief may direct.
It is hereby made the duty of the members of the Police Department to assist in
making such seizure when requested so to do by said Fire Chief, and to assist
in the removal of such explosives to such place as may be designated by him.
(Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
ARTICLE FIREWORKS
5-7-27: DEFINITION:
The term "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive composition, or any
substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of
producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by
explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank
cartridges, toy cannons, in which explosives are used, the type of balloons
which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes,
skyrockets, roman candles, sparklers, bombs or other fireworks of like
construction and any fireworks containing any explosive compound, or any
tablets or other device containing any explosive substances producing visual
effects; provided, however, that the term "fireworks" shall not include toy
pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper caps containing
twenty five one-hundredths (0.25) grains or less of explosive compound are
used, providing they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact
with the cap when in place for the explosion, and toy pistol paper caps which
contain less than twenty one-hundredths (0.20) grains of explosive mixtures.
(Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-28: PROHIBITIONS:
No person shall have, keep, store, use, manufacture, assemble, mix, sell,
handle or transport any fireworks; provided, however, that nothing in this
Chapter shall be held to apply to the possession or use of signaling devices
for current daily consumption by railroads, vessels and others requiring them
or to the possession, sale or use of normal stocks of flashlight compositions
by photographers or dealers in photographic supplies; and provided further that
the Fire Chief may issue permits for the display of fireworks as hereinafter
provided. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-28.1: ADVERTISING:
No person shall advertise, print, publish, or cause to be advertised, printed,
or published in any newspaper or other publication having a general circulation
in the Village, or which is sold or offered for sale within the Village, or by
means of any handbills, circular, or poster, any advertisement or notice of
sale or delivery within the Village of any fireworks, except to a person to
whom a permit has been issued as provided herein. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-29: DISPLAY IN PUBLIC PLACES:
The Fire Chief may, upon due application, issue a permit to a properly
qualified person for giving a display of fireworks in the public parks or other
public open places. Such permits shall impose such restrictions as in the
opinion of the Fire Chief may be necessary to safeguard life and property in
each case.
Every person conducting or in charge of any public display of fireworks as
herein provided for shall be in possession of a certificate of fitness, as
provided for in Section
5-7-5 of this Chapter.
Every applicant shall also file an indemnity bond running to the Village in the
sum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) to indemnify the Village
against any and all claims arising through or because of such display. Such
bond shall be subject to the approval of the Village Attorney and shall be
filed in the office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-30: DISPLAYS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
The Fire Chief may, upon due application, issue a permit to a properly
qualified person for giving a display of fireworks on privately owned property;
provided, however, that the written consent of the owner of such property shall
be filed with the Fire Chief with said application; and provided further that
no display of fireworks shall be permitted between the hours of eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-31: PERMIT FEE:
The permit fee for each display on private property shall be two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00). (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
5-7-32: EXEMPTION:
Nothing contained in this part of this Chapter dealing with fireworks shall be
construed as applying to the transportation of any article or thing shipped in
conformity with the regulations prescribed by the Interstate Commerce
Commission, nor as applying to the military or naval forces of the United
States. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977)
ARTICLE VIOLATION OF CHAPTER PROVISIONS
5-7-33: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not
less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than the maximum penalty
provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code for each offense, except where otherwise provided; and a
separate and distinct offense shall be considered as having been committed for
each and every day any person shall violate any of the said provisions of this
Chapter. (Ord. 77-12, 9-6-1977; amd. Ord. 95-23, 10-10-1995)
CHAPTER 8
AUTOMATIC SUPERVISED FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM
SECTION:
5-8-1: Definitions
5-8-2: Regulations
5-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
AUTOMATIC SUPERVISED FIRE ALARM SYSTEM(S): Any automatic or manual fire alarm
system with detection and manual pull stations, installed in a structure to
detect the presence of fire or its byproducts, to alert the building's
occupants by visual and audible means of the presence of a fire, and transmit
the presence of an alarm condition directly to the authorized fire department
alarm board as designated by the deputy fire chief or his/her designee.
AUTOMATIC SUPERVISED FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM(S): Any approved automatic or
manual fire suppression system(s), installed within a structure to extinguish
fire(s) within said structure in the earliest possible stage(s) of a fire.
LICENSED FIRE PROTECTION COMPANY: A private company certified or licensed by
the office of the Illinois state fire marshal, the state of Illinois, and/or
another authority having jurisdiction, to design, install, service, test, and
certify fire protection systems including, but not limited to, sprinkler,
standpipe, or other fire protection systems as required by this chapter. (Ord.
08-01, 1-8-2008)
5-8-2: REGULATIONS:
   (A)   All new construction that is equal or greater than the "total building
area" criteria established in table 8.1 of this section shall be fully
protected with an approved automatic supervised fire suppression system
complying with NFPA-13, 1999 edition, with no exceptions. Where any part of the
structure has a use group or occupancy type meeting the criteria listed in
table 8.1 of this section, and the use group classification or occupancy type
is in only a portion of the building, the entire building shall be fully
protected by the approved automatic supervised fire suppression system
complying with NFPA-13, 1999 edition.
   (B)   Any modifications to any existing structure, whereby the use group
classification or occupancy within a structure or portion thereof changes and
subsequently meets or exceeds the criteria established in table 8.1 of this
section, shall result in the requirement that the entire structure be fully
protected by an approved automatic supervised fire suppression system complying
with NFPA-13, 1999 edition.
   (C)   Any modifications to any existing structure constructed prior to the
effective date of this chapter, whereby the total building area is increased by
fifty percent (50%) or more over a period of five (5) consecutive years, shall
result in the requirement that the entire structure be fully protected by an
approved automatic supervised fire suppression system complying with NFPA-13,
1999 edition.
   (D)   Any modifications to any existing structure constructed after the
effective date of this chapter, whereby the total building area is increased by
fifty percent (50%) or more, and/or subsequently meets or exceeds the criteria
established in table 8.1 of this section, shall result in the requirement that
the entire structure be fully protected by an approved automatic supervised
fire suppression system complying with NFPA-13, 1999 edition.
   (E)   Buildings required in whole or part, to be protected by an approved
automatic supervised fire suppression system and any building having an
automatic sprinkler system shall be equipped with an approved automatic
supervised fire alarm system panel. All required automatic supervised fire
alarm systems shall automatically transmit the presence of water flow alarm or
valve tamper alarm conditions directly to the fire department alarm board as
designated by the deputy fire chief or his/her designee.
   (F)   All required approved automatic supervised fire suppression systems
shall comply with all codes and standards set forth in this chapter, as well as
meet minimum standards of professional installation specifications as set forth
by the manufacturer of the equipment being installed. In locations where a fire
pump is installed, installation shall comply with NFPA-20.
   (G)   Where approved automatic supervised fire suppression systems are
required in table 8.1 of this section, the sprinkler riser valve and fire pump
rooms shall be equipped with exterior and interior access doors. If it seems
impracticable or impossible, this room may have only one door if approved by
the deputy fire chief or his/her designee. In locations where a fire pump is
installed, installation shall comply with NFPA-20.
   (H)   All required approved automatic supervised fire suppression systems
shall be equipped with water flow alarm detection devices or water flow switch
alarms, which shall be located in easily accessible areas. Any multiple-story
building having a required automatic supervised fire suppression system shall
be equipped with floor control valves with water flow switches for each floor.
Water flow detection devices and water flow switch alarms shall be properly
installed so that an activation of one or more sprinkler heads causes the flow
switch alarm to actuate. Upon activation of a water flow switch alarm, the fire
alarm control panel shall activate and cause audible and visual warning devices
to activate. Visual and audible warning devices shall be provided, seen and
heard in all areas of every building. Devices shall be installed so as to
provide proper and required audible and visual warning of fire from any
location within the structure. Upon activation of a water flow switch alarm,
the fire alarm control panel shall automatically transmit the presence of the
water flow alarm condition directly to the fire department alarm board as
designated by the deputy fire chief or his/her designee. Notwithstanding the
foregoing one- and two-family construction may utilize an approved listed
central station or other approved monitoring agency.
   (I)   All sprinkler system control valves installed on required approved
automatic supervised fire suppression systems shall be supervised by water
valve tamper switch alarms. Water valve tamper switch alarms shall be located
in easily accessible areas and properly installed so that the closing of any
sprinkler system control valve causes a water valve tamper switch alarm to
actuate. Upon actuation of a water valve tamper switch alarm, the fire alarm
control panel shall activate and automatically transmit a trouble alarm
condition directly to the fire department alarm board as designated by the
deputy fire chief or his/her designee. All sprinkler system control valves
including, but not limited to, shutoff valves and inspectors' test valves shall
be properly labeled for quick identification. Labels shall consist of an
approved permanent sign having lettering red in color with a white background.
Signs shall have letters which state the name and/or description of the valve,
i.e., "SPRINKLER SHUT OFF VALVE", or "INSPECTORS TEST VALVE". All signs shall
be installed prior to final acceptance of any installed fire suppression
equipment. All signage shall comply with NFPA standards 13, 14, and 20.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, one- and two-family construction may utilize an
approved listed central station or other approved monitoring agency.
   (J)   All required approved automatic supervised fire suppression systems
shall be equipped with an outside audio/visual indicating device over the fire
department connection. Audible indicating devices shall consist of an approved
outdoor rated "water gong" type bell. If required and used, visual devices
shall consist of a strobe light indicator rated for outdoor use. All audio/
visual indicators used outdoors, shall operate on fire alarm system control
panel voltage. Fire alarm control panel battery calculations shall take all
indicating devices into consideration when calculations are made.
   (K)   Minimum water supply pipes for fire suppression systems shall be no
less than six inches (6") in diameter. All underground piping installed in
conjunction with required automatic fire suppression systems shall comply with
all locally adopted codes, standards and ordinances.
   (L)   Backflow prevention devices shall be installed on all automatic fire
suppression systems and standpipe systems. A certified double detector check
valve or other device approved by the water superintendent or his/her designee
shall be installed on all systems which are directly connected to the municipal
water source. Locations of backflow prevention devices shall be reviewed and
approved by the water superintendent or his/her designee. In systems which are
served by a fire pump, every effort shall be made to ensure the device is
installed on the discharge/output side of the fire pump. All backflow
prevention devices used in conjunction with required automatic fire suppression
systems and standpipe systems, shall be certified as often as required by
state, county and local plumbing codes, however the minimum period of time
shall not exceed at a minimum of at least once annually. Copies of the
certification documents shall be provided to the deputy fire chief or his/her
designee annually.
   (M)   Any persons wishing installation of an approved automatic supervised
fire suppression system or a required approved automatic supervised fire
suppression system within a multiple-family residential or commercial building
shall obtain a permit issued by the building commissioner or his/her designee.
Permit applications can be obtained from the village office during normal
business hours.
   (N)   By application for permit to install an approved automatic supervised
fire suppression system, the applicant shall agree to follow all requirements
set forth in this chapter. The minimum requirements as directed by the deputy
fire chief or his/her designee shall be followed for all installations.
Applications shall be accompanied by all required submittal material as
directed by the building commissioner or his/her designee.
   (O)   Installations of all required automatic supervised fire suppression
systems shall be performed by licensed fire protection companies.
   (P)   All automatic supervised fire suppression systems, and modifications
to existing systems, shall be submitted to the village's building department
for review and approval by the deputy fire chief or his/her designee prior to
any installation or modification.
   (Q)   Prior to any new or required approved automatic supervised fire
suppression system being placed into service, it shall be inspected by and
tested in the presence of the deputy fire chief or his/her designee. All said
required alarm systems shall be connected directly to the fire department alarm
board as designated by the deputy fire chief or his/her designee, prior to any
and all required inspections and testing. A minimum of forty eight (48) hours'
notice shall be provided prior to any required inspections and testing.
   (R)   The key(s) required for access to any sprinkler system valve rooms, or
locks securing valves shall be provided to the deputy fire chief or his/her
designee upon installation of any sprinkler system or at the time of updating
of said keys. Any submitted key(s) shall remain in the Knox box key vault
mounted at the property. Keys for this purpose shall not be provided to
residents or other persons except personnel responsible for operation and
maintenance of the alarm system. Doors leading directly into sprinkler system
valve rooms shall be properly labeled. Labels shall consist of lettering red in
color with a white background. Letters shall be at least two inches (2") in
height in capital lettering and shall state: "SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVE ROOM".
Notwithstanding the foregoing, individual letters may be used to properly label
doors without a label background color when letter size and color complies with
this subsection.
   (S)   Each person or entity having an approved automatic supervised fire
suppression system shall be responsible for any false alarms transmitted by the
system which he/she operates or maintains. Any failures of fire suppression
systems shall be corrected and the system placed back into full operable
service within eight (8) hours of the time it was disabled or shut down.
   (T)   Inspection, testing, and maintenance frequency shall be performed by a
licensed fire protection contractor according to NFPA-25. Documentation of all
inspection(s) shall be filed with the village's fire department within thirty
(30) days of the inspection(s). If a system malfunctions or otherwise requires
repair, the building owner and/or occupant shall be responsible for contacting
the proper contractor to complete the job within eight (8) hours of discovery.

CHAPTER 9
RAPID ENTRY SYSTEM
SECTION:
5-9-1: Definitions
5-9-2: Regulations
5-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
"Rapid entry system" shall be defined as approved supra key box(r) key vaults/
boxes manufactured by Supra Corporation, that meet the specifications of the
village's fire department. These key vaults/boxes are for the exclusive use of
the village's fire and police departments for official and emergency purposes
only. (Ord. 08-01, 1-8-2008)
5-9-2: REGULATIONS:
All buildings having required approved automatic fire alarm systems, approved
automatic supervised fire suppression systems, approved automatic or manual
supervised commercial kitchen fire suppression systems shall have a rapid entry
system by which to allow emergency personnel immediate access to the building.
This system shall consist of an approved model Knox box key vault, securely
mounted to the exterior of the building in a location approved by the deputy
fire chief or his/her designee, containing the following keys:
   (A)   All exterior entry doors leading into the building;
   (B)   Fire alarm control panel (FACP);
   (C)   Fire protection/sprinkler rooms;
   (D)   All utility/electrical rooms; and
   (E)   All boiler/furnace rooms.
The building owner(s)/occupant(s) shall be responsible for the purchase and
installation of the Knox box as well as contacting the deputy fire chief or
his/her designee to secure the building keys. It shall be the building owner's
and building occupant's responsibility to provide the fire department with
properly labeled and updated keys as needed. Application forms for obtaining
the Knox box can be obtained from the fire department during normal business
hours. (Ord. 08-01, 1-8-2008)
CHAPTER 10
STANDPIPE SYSTEMS
SECTION:
5-10-1: Definitions
5-10-2: Regulations
5-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
"Standpipe system" shall be defined as a fire suppression system consisting of
an arrangement of piping, valves, hose outlets and allied equipment installed
in a building or structure which, when required, shall be properly supervised.
(Ord. 08-01, 1-8-2008)
5-10-2: REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Supervised automatic standpipe systems shall be installed in
accordance with NFPA-14, "Standard For The Installation Of Standpipe And Hose
Systems", 1996 edition, as well as all provisions within this chapter,
throughout all buildings in which the floor level of the highest story is
located more than twenty feet (20') above the lowest level of the fire
department vehicle access or in which the floor level of the lowest story is
located more than twenty feet (20') below the highest level of fire department
vehicle access.
   (B)   Supervised automatic standpipe systems shall be installed in
accordance with NFPA-14, "Standard For The Installation Of Standpipe And Hose
Systems", 1996 edition, as well as all provisions within this chapter,
throughout all buildings where any portion of the building floor area is
greater than two hundred feet (200') of travel from the nearest point of fire
department access. All required standpipe systems shall be installed in a
location determined by the deputy fire chief or his/her designee prior to any
installation.
   (C)   Any persons wishing installation of a required standpipe system or a
required approved automatic supervised fire suppression system within any
building, shall obtain a permit issued by the building commissioner or his/her
designee. Permit applications can be obtained from the village office during
normal business hours.
   (D)   Doors leading directly into standpipe system valve rooms shall be
properly labeled. Labels shall consist of lettering red in color with a white
background. Letters shall be at least two inches (2") in height in capital
lettering and shall state: "STANDPIPE CONTROL VALVE ROOM". Notwithstanding the
foregoing, individual letters may be used to properly label doors without a
label background color when letter size and color complies with this
subsection.
   (E)   Standpipe cabinets shall be properly labeled. Standpipe cabinets shall
have labels which identify the cabinet as: "FIRE DEPARTMENT STANDPIPE
CONNECTION". Labels and lettering shall comply with subsection (D) of this
section.
   (F)   All standpipe system control valves including, but not limited to,
shutoff valves shall be properly labeled for quick identification. Labels shall
consist of an approved permanent sign having lettering red in color with a
white background. Signs shall have letters which state the name and/or
description of the valve, i.e., "STANDPIPE SHUT OFF VALVE". All signs shall be
installed prior to final acceptance of any installed fire suppression
equipment. All signage shall comply with NFPA standards 13, 14 and 20. (Ord.
08-01, 1-8-2008)
TITLE 6
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
6-1-1: Creation
6-1-2: Chief Of Police; Deputy Police Chief
6-1-3: Rank
6-1-4: Duties Of Chief
6-1-5: Duties Of Members
6-1-6: Service Of Process
6-1-7: Court Appearances; Witness Fees
6-1-8: Rules And Regulations
6-1-9: Juvenile Officer
6-1-10: Community Service Officers
6-1-1: CREATION:
There is hereby created a police department for the village which shall consist
of one chief of police, one deputy chief, and such number of sergeant(s),
patrolmen, and such full and part time community service officers as the
president and board of trustees may from time to time designate. (Ord. 24-11,
7-23-2024)
6-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE; DEPUTY POLICE CHIEF:
   (A)   There is hereby created the position of chief of police in the
village. The chief of police shall serve under the direction of the village
administrator, supervise all work and employees connected with or assigned to
the police department. He shall be responsible for management, administration
and direction of personnel, equipment, facilities and operation of the police
department. He shall exercise sole control and command and possess complete
authority regarding internal organization, structure and discipline. The chief
of police shall be a member of the police department. The chief of police shall
devote his full time to said position and shall be compensated at a sum to be
set from time to time by the president of the board of trustees, and shall
enter into a bond in favor of the village in such amount as may be required by
the president and board of trustees.
   (B)   There is hereby created the position of deputy chief in the village.
The deputy chief shall be appointed by the president, based on the
recommendation of the village administrator and chief of police, subject to the
approval of the board of trustees. The deputy chief shall perform such duties
as shall be assigned by the chief of police and shall serve as the acting chief
of police in the absence of the chief of police. (Ord. 16-11, 9-13-2016)
6-1-3: RANK:
The chief of police shall be the head of the police department and shall
supervise all officers and members thereof. Following him in rank shall be the
deputy chief, sergeant(s), and patrolmen in the order of seniority within each
group. (Ord. 16-11, 9-13-2016)
6-1-4: DUTIES OF CHIEF:
The chief of police shall keep such records and make such reports concerning
the activities of the police department as shall be necessary and proper for
the effective operation and management thereof, and as may be required by
statute or ordinance, or by direction of the corporate authorities. Further,
the chief of police shall be custodian of all lost, abandoned or stolen
property. (Ord. 73-296, 5-22-1973; amd. Ord. 76-12, 3-16-1976, eff. 5-1-1976)
6-1-5: DUTIES OF MEMBERS:
It shall be the duty of members of the police department to see to the
enforcement of all ordinances of the village and all statutes applicable
therein, and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and arrest
violators thereof. Further, it shall be the duty of each member of the police
department to conduct himself in a proper and law abiding manner, and to avoid
the use of unnecessary force. Each member of the department shall obey the
orders and directions of his superior. (Ord. 73-296, 5-22-1973)
6-1-6: SERVICE OF PROCESS:
The chief of police shall be authorized to serve writs, summonses, and other
legal process, but no member of the police department shall serve any such
process except by order of the chief of police. (Ord. 79-27, 11-20-1979)
6-1-7: COURT APPEARANCES; WITNESS FEES:
Every member of the police department shall appear as a witness whenever this
is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of an ordinance or any state or
federal law, but no such member shall receive or retain any witness fee for
service as a witness in any action or suit to which the village is a party. All
fees due for such services, if paid, shall be turned over to the chief of
police, who shall deposit the same with the village treasurer. The foregoing
provisions do not relate to the payment of compensation by the village for
court appearances made on behalf of the village. (Ord. 80-3, 5-13-1980)
6-1-8: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The chief of police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations as he
shall deem advisable for the better efficiency of the police department. Such
rules, when approved by the board of trustees, shall be binding on all members.
(Ord. 73-296, 5-22-1973; amd. Ord. 76-12, 3-16-1976, eff. 5-1-1976)
6-1-9: JUVENILE OFFICER:
   (A)   There is hereby established the position of village juvenile officer,
to be appointed by the village president, subject to the advice and consent of
the board of trustees.
   (B)   The juvenile officer shall process all offenders under the age of
seventeen (17) who shall be arrested within the village limits; further, he
shall supervise such offenders and accompany them to the juvenile court
facilities when necessary, and he shall attend all court hearings in connection
with such offenders. The juvenile officer shall perform such other duties,
including recordkeeping, as the chief of police or board of trustees shall
prescribe.
   (C)   The juvenile officer shall be paid straight time wages for performance
of his duties as juvenile officer. Said straight time wages shall be calculated
and paid based on the individual officer's hourly salary structure. The
juvenile officer shall accurately log and record all time spent actually
performing duties as the juvenile officer and shall submit such records to the
chief of police. The chief of police shall approve all such compensation for
the juvenile officer. (Ord. 80-3, 5-13-1980)
6-1-10: COMMUNITY SERVICE OFFICERS:
   (A)   The Village President, by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees, may appoint civilian Community Service Officers (CSOs) to assist
sworn police officers in efficiently performing their duties. Such CSOs shall,
at all times during the performance of their duties, be subject to the
direction and control of the Chief of Police or the Chief's designee. Any
employment relationship between the village and the CSOs shall be at will
employment, and are subject to suspension and termination by the Chief of
Police.
   (B)   Prior to appointment, all prospective CSOs shall complete an
application form as prescribed by the Village President. Prior to appointment,
all prospective CSOs shall be fingerprinted and have a criminal background
check completed. No person shall be appointed as a CSO if he has been convicted
of a felony.
   (C)   CSOs shall not be issued or permitted to carry a firearm.
   (D)   CSO duties may include, but are not limited to, traffic control, desk
duty, assisting motorists locked out of vehicles, animal complaints and
control, village ordinance and parking enforcement, taking of noncriminal
reports, conducting station tours, fingerprinting for non-criminal purposes,
coordination of village administration hearings and assistance with ticket
management programs.
   (E)   CSOs shall be under the command of the Chief of Police. The Chief of
Police shall assign a regular police commander, sergeant or officer to act as
liaison to CSOs.
   (F)   The Chief of Police shall establish rules and regulations to implement
this section. (Ord. 24-11, 7-23-2024)
CHAPTER 2
PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS
SECTION:
6-2-1: Appointments
6-2-2: Hiring Standards
6-2-3: Powers And Duties
6-2-4: Firearms
6-2-5: Training Requirements
6-2-6: Compensation
6-2-7: Covered By Workmen's Compensation
6-2-1: APPOINTMENTS:
   (A)   The Village President is hereby authorized to appoint part- time
police officers as employees, subject to the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. Prior to appointment, all part- time police officers shall be subject
to a background check which shall include being fingerprinted and their
fingerprints shall be checked with the Federal Bureau of Identification,
Washington, D.C., and the Illinois State Police, Bureau of Identification for
any possible criminal record. No person shall be appointed as a part-time
police officer if he has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving
moral turpitude.
   (B)   A person hired as a part-time police officer must obtain from the
Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board, hereinafter known as the
Board, a certification:
      1.   Attesting to his or her successful completion of the part-time
police officer training course.
      2.   Attesting to his or her satisfactory completion of a training
program of similar content and number of hours that has been found acceptable
by the Board under provisions of P.A. 89-170 or attesting to the Board's
determination that the part-time police training course is unnecessary because
of the person's extensive law enforcement experience.
   (C)   A person hired on or after January 1, 1996, must obtain this
certificate within eighteen (18) months after the date of hire. A person hired
before January 1, 1996, must obtain this certificate within twenty four (24)
months after the effective date of this mandatory Act of P.A. 89-170 effective
January 1, 1996. (Ord. 96-4, 2-13-1996)
6-2-2: HIRING STANDARDS:
   (A)   Education And Experience: Any person appointed as a part-time police
officer in the Village must possess a diploma from an accredited high school or
a GED;
   (B)   Minimum Age: Any person appointed as a part-time police officer in the
Village must be twenty one (21) years of age or older at time of application;
and
   (C)   Other Requirements: Any person appointed as a part-time police officer
in the Village must:
Possess a valid Class D Illinois driver's license;
Be a United States citizen;
Have no felony convictions or disqualifying criminal histories;
Have 20/100 vision correctable to 20/20;
Be able to pass a background investigation and any other examinations the
Village may require;
Possess State certification as a police officer or successfully obtain from the
Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board a waiver of such
certification due to his or her successful completion of the part-time police
officer training course or his or her satisfactorily completion of a training
program of similar content and number of hours that has been found acceptable
by the Board under provision of P.A. 89-170. (Ord. 97-14, 7-8-1997)
6-2-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (A)   Part time police officers when assigned by the chief of police shall
be primarily responsible for prevention or detection of crime and enforcement
of the criminal code, traffic, or highway laws of this state and applicable
village codes. It shall be the duty of each member of the police department to
conduct himself or herself in a proper and law abiding manner, and to avoid the
use of unnecessary force. Each member of the department shall obey the orders
and directions of his or her superior. The number of hours a part time officer
may work within a calendar year is restricted. (Ord. 12-4, 5-8-2012)
   (B)   Part time police officers shall at all times during the performance of
their duties be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police.
Such part time police officers are also subject to discipline and discharge
from the department. (Ord. 96-4, 2-13-1996)
6-2-4: FIREARMS:
Part time police officers shall not carry firearms except with the permission
of the chief of police of the village and then only when in uniform and in the
performance of their duties. (Ord. 96-4, 2-13-1996)
6-2-5: TRAINING REQUIREMENTS:
Part time police officers shall be trained under the intergovernmental law
enforcement officer's in-service training act in accordance with the procedures
for part time police officers established by the Illinois law enforcement
training and standards board. Such part time police officers shall, prior to
entering upon any of their duties, receive a course of training within the
police department to include, but not be limited to, police procedures, laws of
arrest, search and seizure, deadly force, traffic law, criminal code and any
other pertinent training issues covering rules and regulations, directives and
policies and procedures. Such course of training shall not be less than forty
(40) hours in duration. (Ord. 96-4, 2-13-1996)
6-2-6: COMPENSATION:
Part time police officers shall be paid an hourly wage for each hour of service
performed, provided such service is performed at the direction of the chief of
police. (Ord. 96-4, 2-13-1996)
6-2-7: COVERED BY WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION:
Such part time police officers shall be considered employees of the village and
as such shall be covered by workmen's compensation. (Ord. 96-4, 2-13-1996)
CHAPTER 3
DOGS
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definitions
6-3-2: Prohibitions
6-3-3: Authorizations
6-3-4: Registration
6-3-5: Penalties
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
COMPETENT PERSON: A competent person who is physically and mentally capable of
managing and controlling a dog which is in his responsibility while off the
premises of the owner or keeper thereof.
HOUSED FOR OBSERVATION: When the animal control officer receives information
that any person has been bitten by a dog or other animal, the animal control
officer or his authorized representative shall have such dog or other animal
confined under the observation of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten
(10) days. The animal control officer may by regulation permit such confinement
to be reduced to a period of less than ten (10) days. Such veterinarian shall
report the clinical condition of the dog or other animal immediately, with
confirmation in writing to the animal control officer within twenty four (24)
hours after the dog or animal is presented for examination, giving the owner's
name, address, the date of confinement, the breed, description, age and sex of
such dog or other animal on appropriate forms. The animal control officer shall
notify the attending physician or responsible health agency. At the end of
confinement period, the veterinarian shall submit a written report to the
animal control officer advising him of the final disposition of such dog or
other animal on appropriate forms. When sufficient evidence is presented that
such dog or other animal was inoculated against rabies within the time
prescribed by law, it may be confined in the house of its owner, or in a manner
which will prohibit it from biting any person for a period of ten (10) days, if
the animal control officer, or other licensed veterinarian adjudges such
confinement satisfactory. The animal control officer may by regulation permit
such confinement to be reduced to a period of less than ten (10) days. At the
end of the confinement period such dog or other animal shall be examined by the
animal control officer or another licensed veterinarian. Such confinement shall
be at the expense of the owner.
RESTRICTED AREA: Any sidewalk, street, parkway, right-of-way, park, playground
or private lawn other than that of the owner.
RUNNING AT LARGE: Any dog shall be deemed to be running at large when it is off
the premises of its owner or keeper and not under adequate restraint of a
competent person. A dog is under adequate restraint within the meaning of this
chapter if it is on its owner's or keeper's premises and the dog has not
strayed off of such premises; or on a stout leash, not more than six feet (6')
in length; or at heel within seven feet (7') of a competent person and obedient
to that person's commands. (Ord. 77-55, 6-21-1977; amd. Ord. 17-12, 8-8-2017)
6-3-2: PROHIBITIONS:
   (A)   1. Not more than three (3) dogs shall be housed, kept or maintained in
or around any premises within a residential district of the Village.
      2.   Any individual housing more than three (3) dogs as of August 8, 2017
shall not be subject to the restrictions set forth in this section. However:
         (a)   Such individuals may not add to the number of dogs currently
residing in their homes; and
         (b)   All such individuals must register with the Village on or before
September 15, 2017 identifying the number of dogs currently in the residence.
(Ord. 17-12, 8-8-2017)
   (B)   No person shall allow any dog which he owns, houses, keeps or
maintains to run at large within the Village.
   (C)   Any person who owns, houses, keeps or maintains a dog which defecates
within or upon a restricted area shall be responsible for removing such
defecation.
   (D)   Any person who owns, houses, keeps or maintains a dog which has bitten
a person, shall house such dog for observation for a period of ten (10) days at
the order of a police officer or the animal control officer.
   (E)   No person shall house, keep or maintain any dog six (6) months of age
or older that does not have a current, valid Cook County rabies control
identification tag and license.
   (F)   No person or persons shall harbor or keep any animal which disturbs
the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. (Ord. 77-5, 6-21-
1977)
6-3-3: AUTHORIZATIONS:
   (A)   The Chief of Police, any officer of the Police Department or employee,
officer or independent contractor of the Village hired for that purpose is
authorized to use a chemical-type capture gun or other necessary devices to
effect the apprehension of a dog running at large.
   (B)   The Chief of Police, any officer of the Police Department or employee,
officer or independent contractor of the Village hired for that purpose is
authorized to humanely destroy any dog found running at large that presents a
real and immediate hazard to persons.
   (C)   The Chief of Police, any officer of the Police Department or employee,
officer or independent contractor of the Village hired for that purpose is
authorized to incarcerate or cause to be incarcerated at any veterinary
hospital any dog found running at large if the owner is unknown. Owner of such
dog, when found, shall pay all expenses incurred.
   (D)   The Chief of Police and/or the animal control officer is authorized to
direct any veterinarian at a veterinary hospital housing a dog secured by the
Police Department under this chapter, to humanely destroy such animal housed if
the owner cannot be located within a period of ten (10) days from the date of
incarceration. (Ord. 77-5, 6-21-1977)
6-3-4: REGISTRATION:
   (A)   On or before January 1 of each succeeding year, it shall be the duty
of any person owning, keeping, maintaining or harboring a dog in the Village to
register said dog with the Clerk of the Village.
   (B)   The Clerk shall receive a fee of one dollar ($1.00) for each dog
registered, and upon the payment of said fee the Clerk shall issue, in triplet,
a certificate of registration, one copy thereof to be delivered to the person
registering said dog, one copy to be retained by the Police Department and one
copy to be retained by the Clerk. Said certificate shall show a general
description of the dog, the owner's name and address, and rabies vaccination
tag number and expiration date.
   (C)   Prior to registering any dog as herein required, the person
registering said dog must present to the Clerk a certificate of current
vaccination against rabies as herein required. (Ord. 77-5, 6-21-1977; amd. Ord.
19-08, 3-12-2019)
6-3-5: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this Ordinance shall be fined
seventy five dollars ($75.00) for a first offense, one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) for a second offense, three hundred dollars ($300.00) for a third
offense, five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a fourth offense and seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for a fifth and subsequent offenses. (Ord. 77-5, 6-21-
1977; amd. Ord. 95-23, 10-10-1995; Ord. 18-08, 7-24-2018; Ord. 22-31, 11-8-
2022)
CHAPTER 4
ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-4-1: Disposal Center Authorized
6-4-2: Impounding Strays
6-4-3: Request Disposal
6-4-4: Village Not Responsible
6-4-1: DISPOSAL CENTER AUTHORIZED:
The Village officials are hereby authorized to maintain a disposal center for
the destruction of stray animals that may be impounded, which shall conform
with the laws of the State and shall meet the recommendations of the various
humane societies located in the State. (3-9-1953)
6-4-2: IMPOUNDING STRAYS:
All stray dogs and animals found running at large shall be impounded. (3-9-
1953; amd. Ord. 77-5, 6-21-1977)
6-4-3: REQUEST DISPOSAL:
All litters of puppies will be destroyed by request of the owner, but no bounty
will be paid for said litter and no such litter shall be accepted from minors.
No dog shall be accepted for disposal from minors, and each person bringing a
dog or dogs for disposal shall sign a proper statement to the effect that to
the best of his knowledge and belief the dog or dogs are strays and that he
captured said dog or dogs within the boundaries of the Village. (3-9-1953)
6-4-4: VILLAGE NOT RESPONSIBLE:
The Village assumes no responsibility regarding the said stray dogs other than
to see that they are humanely disposed of after a ten (10) day confinement
period. (3-9-1953; amd. Ord. 77-5, 6-21-1977)
CHAPTER 5
MISDEMEANORS
SECTION:
6-5-1: Assault
6-5-2: Battery
6-5-3: Billposting; Advertising
6-5-4: Breach Of The Peace
6-5-5: Burglar's Tools, Possession
6-5-6: Burning Prohibited
6-5-7: Concealing Identity
6-5-8: Disorderly Conduct
6-5-9: Possession, Drinking In Public
6-5-10: False Fire Alarm
6-5-11: Fighting
6-5-12: Firearms; Discharging
6-5-13: Gambling
6-5-14: Fire Hydrants; Unauthorized Use
6-5-15: House Of Ill Fame
6-5-16: Impersonating, Interfering With Village Officers
6-5-17: Indecent Exhibitions
6-5-18: Injuring Village Property
6-5-19: Liquor In Vehicles
6-5-20: Prostitution
6-5-21: Public Indecency
6-5-22: Slugs; Coin Operated Machines
6-5-23: Soliciting For A Prostitute
6-5-24: Trespass
6-5-25: Unlawful Appurtenances
6-5-26: Weapons, Carrying Concealed
6-5-27: Driving On Sidewalks
6-5-28: Driving Under Influence Of Intoxicating Liquor Or Narcotic Drugs
6-5-29: Reckless Driving
6-5-30: Drag Racing
6-5-31: Negligent Driving
6-5-32: Vandalism Of Property
6-5-33: Unauthorized Scavengers Prohibited
6-5-34: Certain Activities And/Or Items Prohibited In Village Park
6-5-35: Cannabis Regulations
6-5-36: Drug Paraphernalia
6-5-1: ASSAULT:
A person commits an assault when, without lawful authority, he engages in
conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery.
A person convicted of assault shall be fined as in this code provided. (Ord.
64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-2: BATTERY:
A person commits battery if he intentionally or knowingly without legal
justification and by any means: a) causes bodily harm to an individual or b)
makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an individual.
A person convicted of battery shall be fined as in this code provided. (Ord.
64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-3: BILLPOSTING; ADVERTISING:
No person shall post, stick, stamp, tack, paint or otherwise fix, or cause the
same to be done by any person, any notice, placard, bill card, poster,
advertisement or other device calculated to attract the attention of the
public, to or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or curbstone, or any other
portion or part of any parkway, park, public way, lamppost, electric light,
telegraph or telephone pole, hydrant or shade tree or property of the village
except such as may be required by the laws of the state and the provisions of
this code. (Ord. 61-33, 4-25-1961)
6-5-4: BREACH OF THE PEACE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to provoke a breach of the peace or to use
any violent, threatening, profane or indecent language to the disturbance of
any person, or to use any threatening, reproaching or abusive language to or
concerning any person tending to provoke a breach of the peace. (Ord. 64-97, 6-
9-1964)
6-5-5: BURGLAR'S TOOLS, POSSESSION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any nippers of
the description known as burglar's nippers, picklock, skeleton key, key to be
used with a bit, jimmy or other burglar's instrument or tool of whatsoever kind
or description, unless it be shown that such possession is innocent or for
lawful purpose. (1940 Code Sec. 5-11)
6-5-6: BURNING PROHIBITED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause a fire to be made
for burning any combustible waste material in any public way or public space or
upon any private property within the village, except in a suitable metal or
wire burner so constructed as to prevent the escape of burning material or
sparks which might endanger surrounding property.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause a fire to be made
for burning any waste materials, with or without the protection required by
subsection (A) of this section in any location within a radius of two hundred
feet (200') of any tank containing flammable liquids or any flammable liquids,
nor closer than fifty feet (50') to any wood frame building or stock, store or
accumulation of lumber, or other combustible material. (1940 Code Sec. 5-10)
6-5-7: CONCEALING IDENTITY:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the village to appear in public in
any mask, cap, cowl, hood or other thing concealing the identity of the wearer;
provided, that the provisions of this action shall not apply to persons
attending or taking part in carnivals, mask balls, public shows,
entertainments, or celebrations in the village, or under permission of the
proper authorities of the village, nor to any person holding a written permit
issued by proper authorities of the village. (1940 Code Sec. 5-11)
6-5-8: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of disorderly conduct
or to make, aid, countenance or assist in making any improper riot, disturbance
or breach of the peace in the village.
   (B)   A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly does any act in
such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach
of the peace. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-9: POSSESSION, DRINKING IN PUBLIC:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following
definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning:
    PUBLIC PLACE: Any street, sidewalk, highway, public thoroughfare, or
parking area available to the public, or any street, sidewalk, alley or parking
area located on private property for which the owner(s) of said property has
entered into a contract with the village for enforcement of traffic
regulations, and village owned property, public grounds, recreation areas,
parks, and schools.
   (B)   Consumption And Possession Of Alcohol: It shall be unlawful for any
person to consume any alcoholic beverage or carry on his/her person any open
containers of alcoholic beverages upon any public place within the corporate
limits of the village.
   (C)   Intoxication Creating A Disturbance: It shall be unlawful for any
person to be drunk or to be in a state of intoxication in any public place or
in any private house or place within the corporate limits of the village to the
disturbance of any person. (Ord. 09-07, 8-25-2009)
6-5-10: FALSE FIRE ALARM:
It shall be unlawful for any person, without reasonable cause, by outcry or
otherwise, to make or circulate, or cause to be made or circulated any false
alarm of fire. (1940 Code Sec. 5-10)
6-5-11: FIGHTING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to instigate, cause or procure any public
or private fighting. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-12: FIREARMS; DISCHARGING:
It shall be unlawful for any person, except a member of the police department,
when on duty, or any officer of any court whose duty it may be to serve
warrants or make arrests, to fire or discharge any gun, pistol or other
firearm, within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-13: GAMBLING:
Except as allowed pursuant to section
