3-3-22, "Video Gaming", of this code:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in gambling for money or
other valuable thing whether by means of a device, scheme, game of chance,
hazard or skill, either as bookmaker, dealer, keeper, player or otherwise, nor
shall any person aid, assist, abet in any manner or be a party to any of the
foregoing offenses or the betting on the outcome of any particular event,
including horse races.
   (B)   Every structure, room, or premises kept or used for the purpose of
permitting persons to gamble by the means of devices, games, chance or
otherwise, or aid and abet in the same is hereby declared to be a common
nuisance, and no person who is the owner, lessor, agent or caretaker of said
room or structure shall permit therein gambling of any sort.
   (C)   No person shall frequent or be found in any room or structure where
devices of gambling are kept or sheer gambling of any kind is engaged in, nor
shall any person have in his possession articles of any kind commonly used in
carrying on or promoting any game of chance or any type of gambling. (Ord. 13-
09, 11-26-2013)
6-5-14: FIRE HYDRANTS; UNAUTHORIZED USE:
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than members of the fire department
or employees of any department of the village to use water from any fire
hydrant being a part of the village water system except for extinguishing fires
or unless specifically authorized by the Superintendent of Public Works. (Ord.
62-63, 2-13-1962)
6-5-15: HOUSE OF ILL-FAME:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain a house of ill-fame or
assignation or place for the practice of prostitution or lewdness. No person
shall patronize or be an inmate of the same nor let, own or be interested in
any house, room or other premises for any such purpose or shall keep a common,
ill-governed, disorderly house to the encouragement of idleness, gaming,
drinking, fornication or other misbehavior. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-16: IMPERSONATING, INTERFERING WITH VILLAGE OFFICERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be an
officer of the Village or to, without being duly authorized, exercise or
attempt to exercise any of the duties, functions or powers of a Village officer
or shall hinder, obstruct, resist or otherwise interfere with any Village
officer in the discharge of his official duties. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-17: INDECENT EXHIBITIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any indecent, lewd, or filthy act
in any public place in the Village; to utter any lewd or filthy words, sing any
song the words of which are suggestive of indecency or immorality, or use any
threatening or abusive language in the hearing of other persons; to make any
overture of lewdness, tending to pervert the morals of any person, upon or in
the public ways or other public places or in any public conveyance in the
Village.
It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit, sell, offer to sell, circulate,
or distribute any indecent or lewd book, picture, or other thing of any immoral
or scandalous nature, or exhibit in any place where the same can be seen from
the public way, or in a public place frequented by children, any picture
representing a person in a nude state which is not connected with any art or
education exhibition, or perform any indecent, immoral, or lewd play or other
representation, or exhibit himself in a public place in a state of nudity,
indecency or lewdness. And it shall be unlawful for any person to offer or
exhibit for sale, or offer to give away any book or other printed matter
purporting on its cover or otherwise to be lewd, salacious or obscene. (1940
Code Sec. 5-4)
6-5-18: INJURING VILLAGE PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to negligently or wilfully injure, destroy
or deface any bridge, crossings, sidewalks, lamp, lamppost or other property of
the Village. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-19: LIQUOR IN VEHICLES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any alcoholic liquor as
defined by law on any public way or in or about any motor vehicle upon a public
way in the Village.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to transport, carry, possess or
have any alcoholic liquor in or upon or about any motor vehicle upon any public
way in the Village except in the original package and with the seal unbroken.
(Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-20: PROSTITUTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to perform, offer or agree to perform any
of the following acts for money:
   (A)   Any act of sexual intercourse; or
   (B)   Any act of deviate sexual conduct. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-21: PUBLIC INDECENCY:
   (A)   Any person of the age of seventeen (17) years or older who performs
any of the following acts in a public place commits a public indecency:
      1.   An act of sexual intercourse; or
      2.   An act of deviate sexual conduct; or
      3.   A lewd exposure of the body done with intent to arouse or to satisfy
the sexual desire of the person; or
      4.   A lewd fondling or caress of the body of another person of either
sex.
   (B)   "Public place" for purposes of this Section means any place where the
conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-
1964)
6-5-22: SLUGS; COIN-OPERATED MACHINES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to insert, or to attempt to insert, into
the coin box or money receptacle of any telephone, any slug, button, or other
substance, or to manipulate or operate, or to attempt to manipulate or operate,
in any manner whatever, any telephone instrument or any mechanism or device
connected or commonly used therewith, with the intent to obtain telephone
service without paying therefor.
It shall be unlawful for any reason to insert, or to attempt to insert, into
the coin box or money receptacle of any telephone, slug, button, wire, hook, or
other implements or substances with the intent to obtain from such coin box or
money receptacle a legal tender coin of the United States. (1940 Code Sec. 5-6)
6-5-23: SOLICITING FOR A PROSTITUTE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any of the following acts
described as soliciting for a prostitute:
   (A)   Solicit another for the purpose of prostitution; or
   (B)   Arrange or offer to arrange a meeting of persons for the purpose of
prostitution; or
   (C)   Direct another to a place knowing such direction is for the purpose of
prostitution. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-24: TRESPASS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into or upon any lot, block or
tract of ground in the Village which is under cultivation, unless such person
is an owner, lessee, or person entitled to so enter, or the duly authorized
agent thereof, and any person found by the police in and upon any such premises
shall be treated as a trespasser unless he can produce satisfactory evidence of
ownership or right to be in and upon any such premises. (1940 Code Sec. 5-14)
6-5-25: UNLAWFUL APPURTENANCES:
It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee, or person in possession of any
building in the Village to erect, maintain, or permit to be erected or
maintained on or about the stairway in, or the entrance to, such building, or
in or about its exterior building, any railing, fence, guard, or protection of
any kind, upon which there shall be affixed or in any manner attached so as to
protrude therefrom any spike, nail, or other pointed instrument of any kind or
description. (1940 Code Sec. 5-12)
6-5-26: WEAPONS, CARRYING CONCEALED:
It shall be unlawful for an person within the corporate limits of the Village
to carry or wear, under his clothes or concealed about his person, any pistol,
revolver or sling shot, cross knuckles or buckles of lead, brass or other metal
or bowie knife, dirk knife or dirk or dagger or any other dangerous or deadly
weapon.
This prohibition shall not apply to members of the Police Department of the
Village when on duty nor to any officer of any court whose duty it may be to
serve warrants or to make arrests.
Any such weapon duly adjudged by any proper officer or to have been worn or
carried by any person in violation of this Section, shall be forfeited or
confiscated to the Village. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-27: DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS:
The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within or upon any sidewalk area except
at a permanent or temporary driveway. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-28: DRIVING UNDER INFLUENCE OF INTOXICATING LIQUOR OR NARCOTIC DRUGS:
It shall be unlawful for any person who is a habitual user of narcotic drugs or
any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drugs
to drive any vehicle within the Village. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-29: RECKLESS DRIVING:
Any person who drives any vehicle with a wilful or a wanton disregard for the
safety of persons or property is guilty of reckless driving. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-
1964)
6-5-30: DRAG RACING:
Any person, who, as an operator of a motor vehicle, is a participant in drag
racing shall be fined as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code.
For the purpose of this Section "drag racing" means the act of two (2) or more
individuals competing or racing on any street or highway in this Village in a
situation in which one of the motor vehicles is beside or to the rear of a
motor vehicle operated by a competing driver and the one driver attempts to
prevent the competing driver from passing or overtaking him. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-
1964; amd. Ord. 95-23, 10-10-1995)
6-5-31: NEGLIGENT DRIVING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon any public way
negligently, heedlessly and without due caution in a manner so as to endanger
or be likely to endanger any person or property. (Ord. 64-97, 6-9-1964)
6-5-32: VANDALISM OF PROPERTY:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purposes of this Ordinance, the following
definitions shall apply:
      1.   "Person" shall include any individual, firm, partnership,
association, corporation, company or organization of any kind, the State of
Illinois, or any political subdivision.
      2.   "Property" shall include any real estate including improvements
thereon, and tangible personalty.
      3.   "Legal guardian" shall include a person appointed guardian, or given
custody, of a minor by a Circuit Court of this State, but does not include a
person appointed guardian, or given custody of a minor under the Illinois
Juvenile Court Act.
      4.   "Minor" shall be a person who has attained eleven (11) years of age
but who has not yet reached eighteen (18) years of age.
   (B)   Offenses:
      1.   Within the Village of Forest View no person shall:
         (a)   Knowingly or recklessly damage or cause to be damaged any
property of another person without his consent; or
         (b)   Knowingly and without authority enter into or obtain control
over any motor vehicle, bicycle, aircraft or watercraft or any part thereof of
another person without his consent.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian of any minor living
with his parents or guardian to neglect to restrain such minor from committing
any act prohibited by subsection (B)1 of this Section.
Option 1:
The commission of any act prohibited by subsection (B)1 of this Section by a
minor who is living with his parents or guardian shall be conclusive proof that
the parent or guardian has neglected to restrain such minor from committing
such act.
Option 2:
The commission of any act prohibited by subsection (B)1 of this Section by a
minor who is living with his parents or guardian shall raise the presumption
that the parent or guardian has neglected to restrain such minor from
committing such act. It shall be an affirmative defense for the parent or
guardian to prove that such parent or guardian exercised his duty to restrain
the minor from committing the act prohibited by subsection (B)1 of this Section
complained of in the pending action, but that such action on the part of the
parent or guardian to attempt to restrain said minor, although exercised with
due care, was unsuccessful.
   (C)   Penalty:
      1.   Every person found guilty of an offense under subsection (B)1 of
this Section shall be subject to either or both of the following penalties:
         (a)   A fine not in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);
         (b)   A period of conditional discharge not to exceed one year.
(1) The conditions of a conditional discharge shall include that the defendant:
   A. Did not violate any criminal statute or ordinance of any jurisdiction;
and
   B. Did report to and appear in person before such person or agency as
directed by the court.
(2) The conditions of conditional discharge may, in addition require that the
defendant:
   A. Work or pursue a course of study or vocational training;
   B. Undergo medical or psychiatric treatment, or treatment for drug addiction
or alcoholism;
   C. Make restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed actual loss or
damage to property and pecuniary loss or one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
whichever is less; and
   D. If a minor, reside with his parent or in a foster home; attend school;
attend a nonresidential program for youth, or contribute to his own support at
home or in a foster home.
(3) When a court orders restitution or reparation as a condition for a
conditional discharge, the court shall determine the amount and conditions of
payment. When the conditions of payment have not been satisfied, the court, at
any time prior to the expiration of termination of the period of conditional
discharge may impose an additional period of not more than two (2) years. Only
the conditions of payment shall continue to apply during such additional
period. The court shall retain all of the incidents of the original sentence,
including the authority to modify or enlarge the original conditions and to
revoke the penalty of conditional discharge if the conditions of payment are
violated during such additional period.
(4) When the petition is filed charging a violation of a condition imposed for
conditional discharge, the court:
   A. May order a summons to the offender to appear; or order a warrant for the
offender's arrest where there is danger of his fleeing the jurisdiction or
causing serious harm to others or when the offender fails to answer a summons.
The issuance of such warrant or summons shall stay the sentence of conditional
discharge until the final determination of the charge, and the term of
conditional discharge shall not run so long as the offender has not answered
the summons or warrant.
   B. Shall conduct a hearing of the alleged violation. The court may admit the
offender to bail pending the hearing.
   C. Shall receive evidence in open court with the right of confrontation,
cross-examination and representation by counsel. The Village has the burden of
going forward with the evidence and proving the violation by the preponderance
of the evidence.
   D. Shall not revoke a conditional discharge for failure to comply with
conditions of a sentence which imposes financial obligations upon the offender
unless such failure is due to his wilful refusal to pay.
   E. May modify the conditions of a conditional discharge on motion of the
Village or on its own motion or at the request of the offender after notice to
all parties and a hearing.
(5) If the court finds that the offender has violated a condition at any time
prior to the expiration or termination of the period, it may continue the
offender on the existing period, with or without modifying or enlarging the
conditions, or may impose any other penalty that was available at the time of
the initial penalty.
(6) A judgment revoking a sentence of conditional discharge is a final
appealable order.
      2.   Every person found guilty of an offense under subsection (B)2 of
this Section shall pay a fine not in excess of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00).
   (D)   Liability Of Parent Or Legal Guardian Of Minor Offender: The parent or
legal guardian of a minor defendant who resides with such parent or legal
guardian shall be liable for any fine or condition or restitution or reparation
imposed by a court upon a minor for violation of this Ordinance, provided that
said minor has not paid said fine or made restitution or reparation within the
time ordered by the court, and further provided that said parent or legal
guardian has been served with summons or notice to appear in the original cause
against such minor and all proceedings thereafter. (Ord. 76-26, 11-16-1976)
6-5-33: UNAUTHORIZED SCAVENGERS PROHIBITED:
No person other than an authorized representative of a scavenger licensed by
the village may remove or disturb any waste containers or recycling containers
or the contents thereof after the containers are placed in the public right of
way by the property owner. (Ord. 08-17, 9-9-2008)
6-5-34: CERTAIN ACTIVITIES AND/OR ITEMS PROHIBITED IN VILLAGE PARK:
   (A)   The following activities and/or items are prohibited in the village
park except when such activities are conducted in conjunction with an event
sponsored by the village of Forest View or the Forest View park district:
      1.   Bicycles.
      2.   Skateboards.
      3.   Rollerblades.
      4.   Food.
      5.   Pets.
      6.   Smoking.
   (B)   A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine not
exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 08-15, 9-9-2008)
6-5-35: CANNABIS REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Cannabis Defined: Cannabis includes marijuana, hashish and other
substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis
sativa, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any
part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture,
or preparation of such plant, its seeds, or resin, including
tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its
naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced
directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical
syntheses or by a combination of extraction and chemical syntheses; but shall
not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks,
oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant, any other compound, manufacture,
salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such mature stalks (except the
resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil, cake, or the sterilized seed of such
plant which is incapable of germination.
   (B)   Violation: It shall be a violation of this section for any person
knowingly to possess any quantity of any substance containing cannabis, except
that the effect of this section shall be limited to persons knowingly
possessing thirty grams (30 g) or less of any substance containing cannabis.
   (C)   Citation: A law enforcement officer may, in lieu of filing a complaint
or arresting a violator, issue to the violator a citation ("notice to appear"
or "P" ticket) allowing the violator to settle and compromise the violation
claim by paying to the village the amount set forth below, not more than ten
(10) days after the time such citation was issued:
 
2 grams or less                               $150.00
More than 2 grams and not more than 10 grams  250.00
More than 10 grams and not more than 20 grams 400.00
More than 20 grams and not more than 30 grams 500.00
 
If the person to whom a citation was issued fails to settle within ten (10)
days, the amount of settlement prior to a court appearance shall be double the
amount enumerated in this subsection.
   (D)   Penalty: If the person to whom the citation was issued fails to settle
and pay such violation claim, proceedings shall be instituted in the Cook
County circuit court against the violator. If a fine is imposed by the court,
such fine shall not be less than the amount set forth in subsection (C) of this
section, as the settlement amount, but not more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 10-10, 9-28-2010)
6-5-36: DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning:
    CANNABIS: Shall have the meaning ascribed to it in section 3 of the
"cannabis control act" 1 , as if that definition were incorporated herein.
   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Shall have the meaning ascribed to it in section 102
of the "Illinois controlled substances act" 2 , as if that definition were
incorporated herein.
   DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products and materials of any kind which
are peculiar to or adapted for use in planting, growing, harvesting,
manufacturing, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging,
storing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing
into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance in violation of the
cannabis control act, the Illinois controlled substances act, section
6-5-35 of this chapter, or similar law or local ordinance.
Drug paraphernalia shall include, but not be limited to: water, ice, air driven
or electric pipes; miniature cocaine spoons or vials; smoking or carburetion
pipes, tubes, masks or other devices; bongs; roach clips; or any item whose
purpose, as announced or described by the possessor, or whose actual use as
determined by the presence of a controlled substance on, in or near the item,
is for use in violating the cannabis control act, the Illinois controlled
substances act, section
6-5-35 of this chapter, or similar law or local ordinance.
   (B)   Possession Of Drug Paraphernalia: No person shall knowingly possess an
item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or
otherwise introducing cannabis or a controlled substance into the human body,
or in preparing cannabis or a controlled substance for that use.
In determining use or intent under this section, the trier of fact can take
into consideration the general, usual, customary and historical use to which
the item involved has been put, and/or the proximity of the cannabis or
controlled substance to the drug paraphernalia or the presence of cannabis or
controlled substance on the drug paraphernalia.
   (C)   Citation: A law enforcement officer, may, in lieu of filing a
complaint or arresting a violator, issue to the violator a citation ("notice to
appear" or "P" ticket) allowing the violator to settle and compromise the
violation claim by paying to the village the amount of thirty five dollars
($35.00), not more than ten (10) days after the time such citation was issued.
If the person to whom a citation was issued fails to settle within ten (10)
days, the amount of settlement prior to a court appearance shall be doubled the
amount enumerated in this subsection.
   (D)   Penalty: Any person found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction
of having violated subsection (B) of this section, shall be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). (Ord. 10-10, 9-28-2010)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 550/3.
2 1. 720 ILCS 570/102.
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE CURFEW
SECTION:
6-6-1: Curfew Hours
6-6-2: Affirmative Defenses
6-6-3: Enforcement
6-6-4: Parents' Responsibility
6-6-1: CURFEW HOURS:
   (A)   No person under the age of seventeen (17) years shall be upon any
public street, alley, or public way within the village at the following times:
      1.   Between ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
Sundays through Thursdays.
      2.   Between eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. Fridays and Saturdays.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be present in or upon any
portion of the village park between the hours of nine thirty o'clock (9:30)
P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 04-02, 3-9-2004)
6-6-2: AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES:
It is a defense to a violation under section
6-6-1 of this chapter that the child engaged in the prohibited conduct while:
   (A)   Accompanied by the child's parent, legal guardian, or legal custodian;
   (B)   Accompanied by an adult at least eighteen (18) years of age and
specified by the child's parent, legal guardian, or legal custodian;
   (C)   Participating in, going to, or returning from:
      1.   Lawful employment;
      2.   A school sanctioned activity;
      3.   A religious event;
      4.   An emergency involving the protection of a person or property from
an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage;
      5.   An activity involving the exercise of the child's rights protected
under the first amendment to the United States constitution such as freedom of
speech and the right of assembly; or
      6.   An activity conducted by a nonprofit or governmental entity that
provides recreation, education, training, or other care under the supervision
of one or more adults. (Ord. 04-02, 3-9-2004)
6-6-3: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the police department to escort any minor child under
the age of seventeen (17) years, found upon the streets, alleys or public ways
of the village during the prohibited hours, to the village police department
and thereupon contact the parents or legal guardians of said child and request
said parents or legal guardians to come to the village police department and
escort said minor to his or her home. The police department will cause written
notice to be serviced upon the parent or legal guardian setting forth the
manner in which this chapter has been violated. Prior to detaining or escorting
any minor, the officer shall make an affirmative inquiry of the minor as to
whether any of the affirmative defenses set forth in section
6-6-2 of this chapter applies. (Ord. 04-02, 3-9-2004)
6-6-4: PARENTS' RESPONSIBILITY:
No person having the legal care and custody of a child under seventeen (17)
years of age shall allow or permit such child to go or be upon any public
street, alley or other place in the village during the hours set forth in this
chapter, exceptions herein outlined. Any parent, legal guardian or person in
charge of such child who shall knowingly allow or permit such child to violate
the provisions of this chapter after receiving notice of the first violation
shall be fined as in this code provided. (Ord. 04-02, 3-9-2004)
CHAPTER 7
WEEDS
SECTION:
6-7-1: Growth Restriction
6-7-2: Failure To Destroy
6-7-3: Lien For Costs
6-7-4: Duty Of Director Of Public Works
6-7-5: Fee For Cutting Of Weeds
6-7-6: Definition
6-7-1: GROWTH RESTRICTION:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or lessee of any real estate in the village
to refuse or neglect to cut weeds, when such weeds shall have reached a height
in excess of five inches (5"). (Ord. 96-15, 7-9-1996)
6-7-2: FAILURE TO DESTROY:
Every owner or lessee of real estate within the village shall cut the weeds on
his property at all such times as may be necessary so that such weeds shall not
exceed five inches (5") in height, and if such owner neglects or refuses to cut
such weeds which exceed five inches (5") in height, the village may cut the
weeds or authorize some person to cut the same on behalf of the village. Prior
to cutting such weeds, the village shall provide three (3) days' written notice
and demand that the owner cut the weeds. (Ord. 01-08, 10-9-2001)
6-7-3: LIEN FOR COSTS:
If the village cuts or authorizes the cutting of weeds on its behalf, the
village shall be entitled to a lien against the real estate in an amount of
money covering the cost and expense incurred or payable for the performance of
the service rendered in cutting such weeds. The property owner shall be liable
for all costs incurred by the village or its agent in placing or removing said
lien. (Ord. 99-1, 3-9-1999)
6-7-4: DUTY OF DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
It shall be the duty of the director of public works to remove from and keep
the streets, alleys, parks and public places in the village free and clean of
any growth of noxious weeds. (Ord. 70-222, 6-9-1970)
6-7-5: FEE FOR CUTTING OF WEEDS:
The director of public works shall keep a record of all lands upon which the
village has been required to cut or authorize the cutting of weeds and shall
submit a list of such land to the village clerk. The village clerk shall bill
the owner and lessee of all such real estate for the cutting of weeds at a rate
of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each five thousand four hundred
(5,400) square feet of lot area or fraction thereof for the initial cutting of
weeds during any one calendar year. Each additional cutting shall be billed at
a rate of three hundred twenty five dollars ($325.00) for each five thousand
four hundred (5,400) square feet of lot area or fraction thereof during the
same calendar year. The owner and occupant of such lands shall be jointly and
severally liable for the cost of the service rendered in cutting such weeds.
(Ord. 01-08, 10-9-2001)
6-7-6: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this chapter the term "weeds" means weeds, grass, or any
similar natural growth foliage on or about any private property within the
village. (Ord. 96-15, 7-9-1996)
CHAPTER 8
NOISES
SECTION:
6-8-1: Declaration Of Policy
6-8-2: Definitions
6-8-3: Unlawful Noise
6-8-4: Specific Limitations
6-8-5: Amplified Sound; Motor Vehicles
6-8-6: Emergency Signaling Devices
6-8-7: Mufflers
6-8-8: Exemptions
6-8-9: Authorized Complainants
6-8-10: Violation; Penalty
6-8-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
   It is hereby declared that the making, creation or maintenance of excessive,
loud, raucous or unnecessary noise within the village affects and endangers the
public health, comfort, convenience, safety, and welfare of the people of the
village. The provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained are enacted for
the purpose of securing and promoting the public health, safety, and welfare of
the village and its residents.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
   Certain words and terms used in this chapter are hereby defined as follows:
   EMERGENCY: An occurrence of a set of circumstances involving actual or
imminent physical trauma or property damage demanding immediate attention.
   EMERGENCY WORK: Any work performed for the purpose of preventing or
alleviating physical trauma or property damage, whether actual or threatened by
an emergency, or work by public or private utilities when restoring utility
service.
   EXCESSIVE, LOUD, RAUCOUS OR UNNECESSARY NOISE Any noise which unreasonably
disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of
reasonable persons of ordinary sensitivity; or any noise which is so harsh,
prolonged, unnatural, or unusual in time or place as to occasion unreasonable
discomfort to any person.
   PLAINLY AUDIBLE: Any sound that can be detected by a person using his or her
hearing faculties, unaided by any mechanical device such as a hearing aid. For
a sound to be plainly audible, it is not required that particular words or
phrases are determinable or that the name, artist or type of instrument
producing the sound can be determined. The detection of any rhythmic bass or
reverberating type of sound is sufficient to constitute a plainly audible
sound.
   PROPERTY LINE: The boundary line of a parcel of real estate.
   RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY: Any real property which contains a building
constructed for a residential purpose or in which one or more persons reside,
provided that the building is properly zoned or is legally nonconforming for
residential use within the village.
   SOUND AMPLIFICATION DEVICE: Any loudspeaker, amplifier, stereo, radio,
television, tape recorder, compact disk player, DVD player, portable media
player, or any other device or system by which sounds may be enhanced or
magnified.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-3: UNLAWFUL NOISE:
   It is unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person within the
village to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued, any excessive,
loud or raucous noise within the limits of the village.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-4: SPECIFIC LIMITATIONS:
   For the purposes of this chapter, acts declared to be excessive, loud,
raucous or unnecessary noises include, but are not limited to, the following:
   (A)   Instruments And Sound Amplification Devices: The playing, using,
operating or permitting to be played, used or operated of any musical
instrument or sound amplification device, or combination thereof, played or
operated in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, comfort and repose of
the neighboring inhabitants or at more volume than is necessary for the
convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room, chamber,
vehicle or outdoor area, within the village limits, in which or where such
instrument or sound amplification device is played, used or operated and who
are voluntary listeners thereto. The playing, use or operation of any such
instrument or sound amplification device between the hours of nine-thirty (9:
30) P.M. and eight o’clock (8:00) A.M. Sunday through Thursday and ten-thirty
(10:30) P.M. and eight o’clock (8:00) A.M. on Friday and Saturday in such
manner as to be plainly audible for a continuous period of one minute or more
at a distance of fifty feet (50') from the location of such instrument or sound
amplification device shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this
section.
   (B)   Yelling, Shouting, And Similar Activities: Yelling, shouting, hooting,
whistling or singing in the public parks, parkways and streets of the village,
particularly between the hours of nine-thirty (9:30) P.M. and eight o’clock (8:
00) A.M. Sunday through Thursday and ten-thirty (10:30) P.M. and eight o’clock
(8:00) A.M. on Friday and Saturday, or at any other time or place so as to
annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office,
business establishment, dwelling or residence or of any person in the vicinity
within the limits of the village.
   (C)   Advertising Noise Or Attention: The playing, using, operating or
permitting to be played, used or operated of any instrument or sound
amplification device which is cast upon the public streets, parks and parkways
of the village for the purpose of commercial advertising or of attracting the
attention of the public to any building or structure, except when a license has
first been procured from the proper village authorities.
   (D)   Animals: The keeping of any animal within any yard, house, enclosure,
garage or other place within the village, which by frequent or long continued
barking, howling, crying, singing or other noise shall disturb the peace,
quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any neighboring dwelling or residence or
of persons in the vicinity within the limits of the village.
   (E)   Construction Or Landscaping: The conduct of any outside construction
or landscaping activities such as construction tools or power equipment, or
engage in any building or construction activities requiring the use of any
equipment that creates a loud and disturbing noise, or use gasoline-powered
landscape maintenance equipment, including, without limitation, leaf blowers,
lawn mowers, chain saws, trimmers, edgers, mechanical tree or brush grinding
equipment, or other mechanical landscape maintenance devices except between the
hours of eight o’clock (8:00) A.M. and eight o’clock (8:00) P.M.
   (F)   Exhausts: The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam
engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorboat or motor vehicle
except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or
explosive noises therefrom.
   (G)   Blowers And Generators: The use or operation of any noise creating
blower, power fan, or internal combustion generator within twenty five feet
(25') of any residential property between the hours of eight o’clock (8:00)
P.M. and eight o’clock (8:00) A.M.
   (H)   Defect In Vehicle Or Load: The use of any automobile, truck, cart,
trailer, motorcycle or other vehicle, so out of repair or loaded in such a
manner or with material of such nature so as to create loud, excessive or
unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises.
   (I)   Loading/Unloading: Causing, allowing or permitting the loading,
unloading, opening or handling of boxes, crates, containers, garbage cans or
recyclable containers between the hours of eight o’clock (8:00) P.M. and eight
o’clock (8:00) A.M. daily when such operations are conducted on a property
within the village located within one hundred feet (100') of any residential
property within the village, measured from the property line of the residential
property.
   (J)   Drums: The use of any drum or similar instrument or device for the
purpose of attracting attention, by the creation of noise, to any place of
business, entertainment or public assembly.
   (K)   Horns And Signaling Devices: The use or operation of any horn or
signaling device on any motor vehicle within the village, except as a danger
warning or in an emergency. No person shall use or operate any horn or
signaling device operated by an engine exhaust or for the purpose of attempting
to increase traffic flow or move traffic in any manner.
   (L)   Utility Equipment In Rights Of Way: Utility equipment located in the
public right-of-way and in residentially zoned districts shall be operated in
such a manner so as to minimize any possible disruption to residents and
occupants of nearby buildings caused by noise. Backup generators, if needed,
shall only be operated during periods of power outages, and for no more than
one weekly testing period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes, and shall not be
tested on weekends or holidays, or between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.
Except during periods of construction, power outages, or during authorized
backup testing conforming to the time limitations in this subsection, at no
time shall any utility facility, or group of ground or pole-mounted utility
facilities, in a residentially zoned area be permitted to exceed 45 dBA at a
ground level distance of twenty feet (20') as measured from the pole base or
ground-mounted equipment, as applicable, or exceed any other applicable noise
levels imposed by codes adopted by the Village.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-5: AMPLIFIED SOUND; MOTOR VEHICLES:
   No person shall cause, allow or permit the operation of any sound
amplification device from any motor vehicle which is plainly audible outside
the vehicle at a distance of seventy-five feet (75') or more. This provision
shall not apply to any sound amplification device being operated by an
authorized emergency vehicle.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-6: EMERGENCY SIGNALING DEVICES:
   No person shall sound, allow or permit the sounding outdoors of any
emergency signaling device, including fire, burglar, civil defense alarm,
siren, whistle, or similar emergency signaling device except in an emergency or
as a permitted test as specified herein. Permitted testing of an emergency
signaling device may only occur between the hours of nine o’clock (9:00) A.M.
and seven o’clock (7:00) P.M. Any testing shall use only the minimum cycle test
time for the emergency signaling device, but in no event shall the test time
exceed five (5) minutes.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-7: MUFFLERS:
   No person shall operate a motor vehicle within the village that is not
equipped with an adequate muffler or exhaust system in constant operation and
properly maintained to prevent any excessive or unusual noise. No person shall
operate a motor vehicle with a muffler or exhaust system modified with a
cutout, bypass or similar device.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-8: EXEMPTIONS:
   Sounds caused by the following are exempt from the prohibitions contained in
this chapter:
   (A)   Utility Repairs: Repairs of utility structures that pose a clear and
immediate danger to life or safety.
   (B)   Emergency Vehicles: Sirens, whistles or bells lawfully used by
emergency vehicles.
   (C)   Emergency Signals: The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting
persons to the existence of an emergency or in the performance of emergency
work.
   (D)   Repairs: Repairs or excavations of bridges, streets or highways by or
on behalf of the village, Cook County, the State of Illinois or the United
States government between the hours of eight o’clock (8:00) P.M. and seven
o’clock (7:00) A.M., when the public welfare and convenience renders it
impractical to perform the work during hours otherwise allowed by ordinance.
   (E)   Outdoor Gatherings And Public Events: Outdoor gatherings and public
events, provided that such events are village sponsored or a permit has been
obtained from the appropriate permitting authority.
   (F)   Power Outages: Internal combustion engines when used during power
outages to generate electricity, prevent freezing or to prevent flooding.
   (G)   The restrictions of this section shall not be applicable to situations
requiring emergency repairs related to health or safety of persons or property.
Once the emergency has been remedied, the property owner shall comply with this
section.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-9: AUTHORIZED COMPLAINANTS:
   Any person witnessing a violation of the provisions of this chapter,
including a police officer, is authorized to be a complainant on any complaint,
citation or other notice of violation issued under this chapter.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
6-8-10: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   Any person, firm or corporation violating or being liable under any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a first
violation within the past twelve (12) months, not less than one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a
second violation within the past twelve (12) months, and not less than three
hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for a third or subsequent offense within the past twelve (12) months. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed with each recurrence of a violation
of the noise disturbance provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 24-06, 5-28-2024)
CHAPTER 9
PARADES AND PUBLIC ASSEMBLIES
SECTION:
6-9-1: In General
6-9-2: Parade Or Public Assembly Permit, Procedure
6-9-3: Permit Fees
6-9-4: Penalty
6-9-1: IN GENERAL:
No person, firm, corporation, partnership, voluntary association, public body
or other organization shall engage in, participate in, form or organize any
parade, public assembly, musical program or festival, or similar activity or
event on any street or in any park within the corporate limits of the Village
unless a permit allowing such activity has been obtained from the Chief of
Police as provided in Section
6-9-2 below. (Ord. 78-26, 12-5-1978)
6-9-2: PARADE OR PUBLIC ASSEMBLY PERMIT, PROCEDURE:
   (A)   Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, voluntary association,
public body or other organization seeking to obtain a parade or public assembly
permit shall file an application with the Chief of Police not more than one
year and not less than thirty (30) days before the date for which the parade,
public assembly or similar activity or event is proposed.
   (B)   The application for a parade or public assembly permit shall be sworn
under oath and shall contain the following information:
      1.   The name, address and phone number of the person signing the
application;
      2.   The name, address and phone number of the person or organization
wishing to conduct such activity;
      3.   The name, address and phone number of the authorized and responsible
leaders of the organization conducting the parade or public assembly;
      4.   The date of the proposed parade or public assembly and the hours
that it will commence and terminate, the specific location of the assembly
area, and if a parade or similar event, the time when the parade will begin to
assemble;
      5.   The estimated or anticipated attendance at the activity, and, if a
parade, the number of persons participating; if a parade, the route along which
the parade will proceed and the lanes of traffic it intends to occupy;
      6.   A detailed description of the activity proposed.
   (C)   The Chief of Police, where good and compelling cause is shown
therefor, may consider any application hereunder which is filed less than
thirty (30) days before the date such event is proposed to be conducted.
   (D)   The Chief of Police shall investigate the facts set out in the
application and shall issue a permit if:
      1.   The activity does not conflict with a previously-approved activity
at the date and time set forth in the application;
      2.   The conduct of such activity will not substantially interrupt the
safe and orderly movement of traffic;
      3.   The conduct of such activity will not require the diversion of so
great a number of Village police officers or other employees to properly police
and control such activity and the areas contiguous thereto, as to prevent
normal police protection for the Village;
      4.   The conduct of such activity is not reasonably likely to cause
injury to persons or property, incite violence, crime or disorderly conduct;
and
      5.   The event is not being conducted for an unlawful purpose.
   (E)   The Chief of Police shall act upon the application for a parade or
public assembly permit within five (5) days after the filing thereof. If the
Chief of Police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant
within five (5) days after the date upon which the application was filed a
notice of his action, stating the facts and conclusions which are the basis for
his denial of the permit. Any applicant who believes that his application is
wrongfully disapproved may appeal to the Village Board. Upon the filing of such
appeal, the Village Board may cause a hearing to be held, and, based upon the
evidence contained in the record of such hearing, either affirm or reverse the
decision of the Chief of Police. In the event the Chief of Police fails to act
within five (5) days after the date upon which the application was filed, said
application for permit shall be deemed approved and the permit deemed granted
in conformance with the application.
   (F)   The Chief of Police, in denying an application for a parade or public
assembly permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of a parade or
public assembly on a date, at a time, at a location or over a route different
from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate
parade or public assembly permit shall, within three (3) days after notice of
the action by the Chief of Police, file a written notice of acceptance with the
Chief of Police. An alternate parade or public assembly permit shall conform to
the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade or public assembly
permit. (Ord. 78-26, 12-5-1978)
6-9-3: PERMIT FEES:
Permit fees shall be based upon the actual costs incurred by the Village in
connection with any given event. At the time that a parade or public assembly
permit application is filed, the Chief of Police shall estimate the likely
manpower and other expenses which will be necessarily incurred by the Village
for the control of traffic, for the enforcement of laws in connection
therewith, and for other purposes, and shall advise each applicant of the
estimated permit fee, which fee shall equal the Village's estimated costs. No
permit shall be issued under this Section until such time as the applicant has
paid the estimated permit fee as ascertained by the Chief of Police hereunder.
Within fourteen (14) days following any event for which a permit was issued
under this Chapter, the Village shall determine the actual costs incurred by
the Village in conjunction therewith, and either refund or additionally charge
the applicant the difference between the estimated permit fee which was paid
and the actual costs incurred by the Village in conjunction with the permitted
activity. (Ord. 78-26, 12-5-1978)
6-9-4: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, voluntary association, public body
or other organization found in violation of any of the terms of this Chapter
shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than the maximum
penalty provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. The Village may avail itself of any other administrative or
judicial remedy to prevent a violation of this Chapter. (Ord. 78-26, 12-5-1978;
amd. Ord. 95-23, 10-10-1995)
CHAPTER 10
SMOKING IN VILLAGE-OWNED BUILDINGS PROHIBITED
SECTION:
6-10-1: Possession Of Lighted Smoking Materials Prohibited
6-10-2: Signs Posted
6-10-3: Enforcement
6-10-4: Violation; Penalty
6-10-1: POSSESSION OF LIGHTED SMOKING MATERIALS PROHIBITED:
Effective May 1, 1995, the Village prohibits any person to possess lighted
smoking materials in any form including, but not limited to, the possession of
lighted cigarettes, cigars, pipes, or other tobacco products within all
Village-owned buildings. (Ord. 95-7, 4-25-1995)
6-10-2: SIGNS POSTED:
Prominently post "NO SMOKING" signs, with letters of not less than one inch
(1") in height, or the international "NO SMOKING" symbol consisting of a
pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a
bar across it shall be conspicuously displayed throughout Village-owned
buildings. (Ord. 95-7, 4-25-1995)
6-10-3: ENFORCEMENT:
All employees of the Village share in the responsibility for adhering to and
enforcing this policy. (Ord. 95-7, 4-25-1995)
6-10-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this Chapter.
Any employee or nonemployee after receiving an oral request to cease smoking of
the cigarette or tobacco material from personnel of any department, authority,
or commission shall be subject to action by the Municipality. (Ord. 95-7, 4-25-
1995)
TITLE 7
HEALTH AND SANITATION
CHAPTER 1
NUISANCES
SECTION:
7-1-1: Notice And Summary Abatement
7-1-2: Unhealthful Business Or Structure
7-1-3: Nuisances Brought Into Village
7-1-4: Offensive Premises
7-1-5: Carboniferous Odors; Refuse
7-1-6: Spreading Of Vermin Poison
7-1-7: Littering
7-1-8: Graffiti Prohibited
7-1-9: Removal Of Graffiti; Notice
7-1-10: Keeping Or Feeding Certain Animals Prohibited
7-1-1: NOTICE AND SUMMARY ABATEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the building commissioner to serve notice, in writing,
upon the owner, occupant, agent or person in possession or control of any lot,
building or premises in or upon which any nuisance may be found, or who may be
the owner or cause of any such nuisance, requiring him to abate the same in
such manner as it shall prescribe, within a reasonable time. It shall not be
necessary in any case for the building commissioner to specify in his notice
the manner in which any nuisance shall be abated unless he shall deem it
advisable so to do. Such notice may be given or served by any officer who is so
directed or deputed. If the person so notified shall neglect or refuse to
comply with the requirements of such order by abating such nuisance within the
time specified, such person shall be fined as in this code provided.
It shall be the duty of the building commissioner to proceed at once upon the
expiration of the time specified in said notice to cause such nuisance to be
abated; provided, however, that whenever the owner, occupant, agent or person
in possession or control of any premises, in or upon which any nuisance may be
found, is unknown or cannot be found, the building commissioner shall proceed
to abate such nuisance without notice. In either case the expense of such
abatement shall be collected from the person who may have created, continued,
or suffered such nuisance to exist, in addition to any penalty or fine.
Whenever any nuisance shall be found on any premises within the village, the
building commissioner is hereby authorized in his discretion to cause the same
to be summarily abated in such manner as he may direct.
In all cases where no provision is herein made defining what are nuisances and
how the same may be removed, abated or prevented, in addition to what may be
declared such herein, those offenses which are known to the common law of the
land and the statutes of Illinois as nuisances may, in case the same exist
within the village limits or within one mile thereof, be treated as such, and
proceeded against as is provided in this code, or in accordance with any other
provision of law. (1940 Code Sec. 10-1)
7-1-2: UNHEALTHFUL BUSINESS OR STRUCTURE:
   (A)   No building, vehicle, structure, receptacle, yard, lot, premises or
part thereof shall be made, used, kept, maintained or operated in the village
if such use, keeping, maintaining or operating shall be dangerous or
detrimental to health.
   (B)   No substance, matter or thing of any kind whatever, which shall be
dangerous or detrimental to health, shall be allowed to exist in connection
with any business, or be used therein, or be used in any work or labor
performed in the village and no nuisance shall be permitted to exist in
connection with any business or in connection with any such work or labor.
(1940 Code Sec. 10-2)
   (C)   Except for properties located in residentially zoned areas, whenever
the village determines that presence of garbage, waste materials, construction
debris, trash or other items disposed on vacant property may interfere with the
public health, safety and welfare, the village shall require the owner thereof
to erect a six foot (6') high fence constructed of chainlink or similarly
suitable material around the entire perimeter of the vacant lot or so much
thereof as is necessary to prevent the continued dumping or depositing of such
waste materials thereon. It shall be unlawful for an owner of such vacant lot
to fail to enclose his property as required herein for more than thirty (30)
days after notice thereof from the village. The penalty provisions of section
1-4-1 of this code shall apply to violations hereof. In addition, the village
may seek appropriate injunctive relief to enforce the requirements of this
section. (Ord. 93-4, 3-23-1993)
7-1-3: NUISANCES BROUGHT INTO VILLAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into the village, or keep therein
for sale or otherwise, either for food or for any other purpose, any dead or
live animal, nor any matter, substance or thing which shall be a nuisance or
which shall occasion a nuisance in the village, or which may or shall be
dangerous or detrimental to health. (1940 Code Sec. 10-3)
7-1-4: OFFENSIVE PREMISES:
Any factory, yard, building or structure of any kind or any tallow chandler's
shop, soap factory, tannery, distillery, livery stable, cattle yard or shed,
barn, packing house, slaughterhouse or rendering establishment which shall
become nauseous, foul or offensive is hereby declared a nuisance; and the
person owning, maintaining or in possession or control of any such factory,
shop, yard, house, building or structure aforesaid shall be fined as in this
code provided. (1940 Code Sec. 10-4)
7-1-5: CARBONIFEROUS ODORS; REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person manufacturing gas or distilling, rectifying
or storing volatile combustibles to throw or deposit or permit to be thrown or
deposited into any public way any gas, tar or any other refuse matter from said
gas house, manufactory, distillery or place of storage, nor shall any such
person allow any substance or odor to escape therefrom or be formed in the
process distillation or other process which shall be offensive or dangerous or
prejudicial to life or health. All reasonable means for preventing the escape
of offensive odors shall be utilized by said person. (1940 Code Sec. 10-5)
7-1-6: SPREADING OF VERMIN POISON:
It shall be unlawful for any person to spread, or to cause or permit any agent
or employee to spread, any poison for the purpose of killing rats, mice,
insects or other vermin in any public way or public place in the village. It
shall further be unlawful for any person to spread, or to cause or permit any
agent or employee to spread any poison for such purpose in any yard, court,
passageway or other open place on private premises, or on the outside of any
building or structure, or in any place within a building which is open to the
general public, or where pet dogs, cats or other domestic animals or fowls have
access without placing the same in a receptacle of such kind or character that
it can be reached only by the kind of vermin which the poison is intended to
kill, or without placing a wire or other guard about same in such way that no
child or domestic animal, domestic fowl or other harmless creature can reach
the same. (1940 Code Sec. 10-7)
7-1-7: LITTERING:
   A.   Littering: No person shall place or cause to be placed upon any street,
alley, park, or other public or private property, any litter unless the litter
is placed into a receptacle intended for the deposit of litter.
   B.   Penalty: The penalties provided in Section
1-4-1 of the Village Code shall apply to violations of this Section. (1940 Code
Sec. 10-8; amd. Ord. 22-13, 5-10-2022)
7-1-8: GRAFFITI PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared a nuisance to inscribe, draw or otherwise place upon the
surface of any structure or wall that is privately or publicly owned, any word,
phrase, diagram, symbol, sketch or letters where the contents thereof are
visible to the general public and contain references to sexual activity, to any
portion of the human anatomy, to gang or criminal activities, to personal
relationships or to defamatory or offensive material about public or private
persons, said inscriptions commonly referred to as "graffiti". (Ord. 93-3, 1-
26-1993)
7-1-9: REMOVAL OF GRAFFITI; NOTICE:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any premises upon which
graffiti (as defined in section
7-1-8 of this chapter) has been placed, to allow such graffiti to remain in
place for more than ten (10) days after receiving notice to remove such
graffiti from the village. For good cause shown, the village may extend the
time period by which such graffiti shall be removed. (Ord. 93-3, 1-26-1993)
7-1-10: KEEPING OR FEEDING CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
   (A)   No person shall feed or otherwise deposit upon his property any
household food, garbage or other edible products, in the open, in such manner
as to attract any stray dog or cat not owned by said person or any other
domestic animal, rodent, bird or other wild animal at or upon the property of
said person within the village. Simple, casual feeding of birds with birdseed,
corn, bread, nuts or similar types of natural products is permitted if not
excessive and does not cause a public nuisance.
   (B)   It is permissible for a birdfeeder, birdhouse and/or birdbath to be
placed on the property of the resident, however, said item must be at least
three feet (3') from the ground. (Ord. 10-12, 11-23-2010)
CHAPTER 2
REFUSE
SECTION:
7-2-1: Definitions
7-2-2: Refuse Containers, Yard Waste Containers/Paper Bags, And Recycling Bins
7-2-3: Removal Of Containers And Contents
7-2-4: Disposal Of Ashes
7-2-5: Commercial Garbage
7-2-6: Unlawful Disposal Of Garbage
7-2-7: Vending Decayed Food
7-2-8: Manure
7-2-9: Animal Bedding And Straw
7-2-10: Refuse In Vacated Buildings
7-2-11: Transportation Of Refuse
7-2-12: Industrial Refuse
7-2-13: Decaying Animal Matter
7-2-14: Dumping Refuse; Permit
7-2-15: Opening Offensive Ground
7-2-16: Substances Scattered By Wind
7-2-17: Refuse On Roof; Areaways
7-2-18: Roofers
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed to them:
ASHES: All ashes of wood, coal and coke, the residue resulting from the
combustion of any material or substance, soot, cinders, slag or charcoal.
GARBAGE: Any rejected or waste household food, offal, swill or carrier.
MANURE: The excrement of all domestic animals and fowls, stable bedding or all
hay, straw, shavings, grass, weeds or leaves which have been used for stable
bedding.
MISCELLANEOUS WASTE: Dust and all refuse except excrement, dead animals and
parts thereof, and articles and substances herein included under "garbage",
"ashes" and "manure". (1940 Code Sec. 10-9)
7-2-2: REFUSE CONTAINERS, YARD WASTE CONTAINERS/PAPER BAGS, AND RECYCLING BINS:
   (A)   The owner or occupant of every building where persons live shall
provide for such building, and at all times maintain in good order and repair,
one or more receptacles for garbage, waste, yard waste, and refuse of an
aggregate capacity to contain the accumulation from said premises for at least
seven (7) days. The village shall provide suitable recycling bins for on-site
collection of recyclable items.
   (B)   1. Receptacles for garbage, waste, and refuse shall be watertight and
made of metal or plastic with close fitting metal or plastic covers. Each
garbage, waste, and refuse receptacle shall have a capacity of not less than
ten (10) gallons nor more than thirty five (35) gallons, with handles suitable
for lifting by one person.
      2.   Receptacles for yard waste shall include:
         (a)   Watertight, rigid containers with close fitting lids, made of
metal or plastic, with not less than ten (10) nor more than thirty five (35)
gallons capacity, with handles suitable for lifting by one person, with
"Compost Only" stickers affixed to the lid; or
         (b)   Biodegradable kraft paper refuse bags, minimum 2-ply, fifty (50)
pound wet strength, approximately thirty (30) gallons capacity or other
biodegradable paper bags of comparable size and quality.
   (C)   The refuse containers, yard waste containers/paper bags and recycling
bins shall be placed in the following manner:
      1.   Curb Collections: At the curb lines not earlier than five o'clock
(5:00) P.M. preceding the designated day of collection, and removed not later
than eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. the day of collection.
      2.   Alley Collections: At the alley line to be readily accessible for
refuse, yard waste and recyclable item collection vehicles.
At all other times, except as above provided, such refuse receptacles, yard
waste receptacles/paper bags and recycling bins, if placed out of doors, shall
be placed to the rear of the principal building on said premises; provided
however, that the same shall in no event be so placed or maintained as to
constitute a nuisance or annoyance to adjacent property or the occupants
thereof.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cast, place, sweep or deposit
anywhere within the village any garbage, waste, yard waste, recyclables, or
refuse of any kind in such a manner that it or any part thereof may be carried
or deposited by the action of sun, wind, rain or snow into or upon any street,
sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway or other public place or upon any private
premises. (Ord. 00-1, 1-11-2000)
7-2-3: REMOVAL OF CONTAINERS AND CONTENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person other than a scavenger employed by or
licensed by the Village or the owner, occupant, tenant or person in possession
of the premises for which a container for garbage and a container for ashes and
miscellaneous waste, or any of them, has been provided, or his agent and
employees to deposit any article or thing in such container, or to remove,
displace, injure, deface, destroy, uncover or in any manner disturb such
container or any portion of its contents. (1940 Code Sec. 10-11)
7-2-4: DISPOSAL OF ASHES:
Every person occupying, operating or controlling any building or portion
thereof in the Village which is heated by steam, hot air or hot water, or in or
about which combustibles are used or ashes are produced, shall keep in or about
such building all ashes, cinders and other waste arising from combustion and
produced therein, and shall remove the same or cause the same to be removed
from the said premises at his own expense at such times and in such manner as
the Commissioner of Public Works may direct. It shall be unlawful to use in
connection with said building or portion thereof any container for ashes and
miscellaneous waste which is provided for domestic use.
This Section shall not apply where a container for ashes is required by the
provisions of this Chapter, nor to any building where less than two (2)
containers of ashes or miscellaneous waste are collected each week.
Ashes stored inside of any non-fireproof building shall be stored only in
masonry bins, approved metal ash cans, or steel truck tanks. All ash containers
shall be kept at least five feet (5') from combustible material. Ashes shall
not be stored inside or outside of any building in wooden receptacles, or
dumped in contact with or in close proximity to any combustible material.
Cans used for dumping ashes into conveyances shall be constructed equivalent to
the following: body of No. 18 U.S. gauge corrugated galvanized iron with bonds
of No. 14 U.S. gauge iron at least six inches (6") wide, located at the top,
center, and bottom; the lower edge of lower bond being three inches (3") below
the bottom of the can. If the middle band is omitted, then reinforcement shall
be substituted consisting of vertical guards of No. 14 U.S. gauge iron spaced
six inches (6") on center around the can. These guards shall extend from the
top to the bottom bands, shall be formed in channel-shape or M-shape and shall
be not less than one and one-half inches (11/2") in depth. All parts shall be
securely riveted. Heavy iron handles shall be riveted or bolted to the middle
or top bands. (1940 Code Sec. 10-12)
7-2-5: COMMERCIAL GARBAGE:
Every person occupying, operating or controlling any building or portion
thereof where persons do not reside, board or lodge shall provide therefor and
maintain upon the premises, a separate container for garbage, which shall be
plainly marked in a conspicuous place "Not for Domestic Use", sufficient to
carry out the purpose of this Chapter and not to use for or in connection with
the said building, or portion thereof, any container for garbage provided for
domestic use. Such person shall remove, or cause to be removed, the contents of
the container so provided from said premises at his own expense at such time
and in such manner as the Commissioner of Public Works may direct.
Every person owning or controlling any hotel, restaurant, cafe or other
premises where more than twenty (20) guests or boarders are fed daily, shall
cause all garbage to be placed in proper metallic containers which shall be
practically air and watertight, and shall cause all substances deposited in
such containers to be removed daily from his premises and to be disposed of
either by burning in a properly constructed incinerator which shall have been
approved by the Board of Health, or by dumping the same at any dumping ground
or place where garbage is dumped or disposed of by the Village. The removal and
disposition of such substances shall be done by such person at his own expense
and in accordance with the provisions of this Code and the rules or regulations
of the Board of Health relating to the disposition and removal of such
substances. Any person occupying a building located in a district where there
is regular collection of garbage by the Village shall be entitled to have one
container of garbage removed per week without expense to the said person. (1940
Code Sec. 10-13)
7-2-6: UNLAWFUL DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw into or deposit in any vault,
sink, privy, catch basin or cesspool any garbage or other substance, except
that of which any such place is the appropriate receptacle; nor shall any slops
or kitchen waste be permitted to run into any privy.
Incinerators and ash chutes shall be constructed in conformity with the
building provisions of this Code. (1940 Code Sec. 10-14)
7-2-7: VENDING DECAYED FOOD:
It shall be unlawful for any person to vend or attempt to vend in the Village
any fruit, vegetable or other article of food that may be decayed or partially
rotten, or that may have been taken from any barrel, box or other receptacle
for the same, in any public way of the Village. (1940 Code Sec. 10-15)
7-2-8: MANURE:
It shall be unlawful to construct, maintain or use in any public way or public
place any box, receptacle or vault for the accumulation or storage of manure.
Every person occupying or controlling any lot, barn, stable, shed, buildings or
place where any horses, mules, cattle or swine are kept or fed, shall provide
and maintain within said lot, barn, stable, shed, building or place, above the
level of the ground upon said premises, either a box, receptacle or vault
constructed as hereinafter prescribed; or in lieu of said box, receptacle or
vault there may be provided and maintained within any barn, stable, shed or
building where any horses, mules, cattle or swine are kept or fed, but not
elsewhere, a bin with a floor of impervious cement and walls of the same
material not less than four feet (4') high above the level of the floor. Said
person shall place or cause to be placed in said bin, box, receptacle or vault
all the manure produced upon the said premises and shall remove or cause to be
removed from the said premises at his own expense the contents of said bin,
box, receptacle or vault at least once in seventy two (72) hours.
Every wooden box for the storage of manure shall be strongly framed and built,
shall have the bottom and inner surface of walls covered with sheet metal,
shall have a tightly fitting wooden cover so constructed as to be fly proof,
and shall be of a capacity to hold all the manure produced on the premises in
seventy two (72) hours.
Every metal receptacle for the storage of manure shall be a heavy metal
receptacle of sufficient thickness of metal and so made and brazed as to
maintain its form under heavy usage, shall be closed with a tight fitting cover
so as to be fly proof, and shall be of a capacity to hold all the manure
produced on the premises in seventy two (72) hours.
Every vault for the storage of manure shall be a strong masonry vault, the
walls and floor of which shall be at least six inches (6") thick, its surfaces,
outside and inside, smoothly finished, and its exterior corners rounded so far
as practicable, and said vault shall be provided with a fly proof cover or door
and shall be of a capacity to hold all the manure produced on the premises in
seventy two (72) hours.
Every bin, box, receptacle, or vault intended for the reception or storage of
manure shall be constructed under a permit issued by the Board of Health, for
which permit a fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be collected by said Building
Commissioner.
It shall be unlawful to accumulate or store manure in an open yard or lot or in
any wagon, car or vehicle, except while transporting manure from one place to
another.
Every bin, box, receptacle, vault, wagon or vehicle for the storage and
transportation of manure shall be maintained in good repair, dry and in clean
condition as to all its parts and surroundings. (1940 Code Sec. 10-16)
7-2-9: ANIMAL BEDDING AND STRAW:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed upon any
public way, or upon the roof of any building, or upon the surface of any lot or
parcel of ground, any straw, hay, shavings or other substance which has been
used as bedding for animals, for the purpose of drying such substance or
storing the same. It shall further be unlawful for any person to burn or cause
to be burned any such straw, hay, shavings or other substance which has been
used as bedding for animals, in any place other than a properly constructed
incinerator, and then only upon a permit issued in writing by the Building
Commissioner for that purpose. (1940 Code Sec. 10-17)
7-2-10: REFUSE IN VACATED BUILDINGS:
It shall be the duty of every person occupying or controlling any lot, building
or structure, or any portion thereof to remove or cause to be removed
therefrom, before vacating the same, all garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste
and manure. (1940 Code Sec. 10-18)
7-2-11: TRANSPORTATION OF REFUSE:
All manure, garbage or other offensive or nauseous substance may be loaded upon
railroad cars for immediate transportation from the Village to such place or
places only as shall be designated by the Building Commissioner, but no place
or places so designated shall be a nearer distance to any building occupied as
a dwelling than two hundred feet (200'). No person shall use or occupy any
place for the receipt, loading or dumping of manure, offal, garbage or any
other offensive or nauseous substance for immediate transportation without
first obtaining a written permit for such purpose from the Building
Commissioner. Any person that violates any provision of this Section shall,
upon conviction, be subject to a fine as in this Code provided.
No person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the carrying or
transporting of any garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste or manure shall cause
or permit such vehicle when in use for such purpose to stand or remain before
or near any building, structure or premises occupied by any person; nor shall
any person using any such vehicle cause or permit the use of an unreasonable or
unnecessary length of time in and about the loading or unloading of any such
vehicle when in use for such purposes, or cause or permit an unreasonable or
unnecessary length of time to be used in passing along any public way; nor
shall any person cause or permit any such cart or vehicle to be in a condition
needlessly or unnecessarily filthy or offensive.
Any person owning or controlling any refuse vehicle shall cause all such
vehicles, and all implements used in connection with the loading or unloading
thereof, when not in use, to be stored and kept in such place and in such
manner as not to create a nuisance, and shall cause all such vehicles and
implements to be thoroughly disinfected and put in an inoffensive condition
when so stored or not in use. Such vehicles and implements shall be thoroughly
disinfected at least once a week, whether in use or not, unless the same shall
not have been used since the last disinfection thereof.
No person owning or controlling any refuse vehicle shall cause or permit any
such vehicle to be so loaded, to be in such defective condition, so out of
repair, of such faulty construction or so improperly driven or managed that any
garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste, or manure with which such vehicle is
loaded, shall drop or fall on any public way or other place. Such vehicle and
any box, can or other receptacle carried thereon or therein, and in which any
of the substances described in this Section shall be carried, shall be so
constructed as to be strong and practically air and water tight, so as to
prevent the same from emitting any odor and so as to prevent any part of the
contents or load thereof from falling, leaking or spilling therefrom.
It shall be the duty of every person in possession or control of any such
vehicle to replace at once on such vehicle any part of the contents thereof
which shall or may have fallen, dropped or spilled from such vehicle, or from
any box or receptacle conveyed thereon, upon any public way or other place.
(1940 Code Sec. 10-19)
7-2-12: INDUSTRIAL REFUSE:
The owner, lessee, occupant or manager of every chemical factory, paint
factory, blacksmith or other shop, forge, coal yard, brick yard, foundry or
manufactory where like business is done, premises where tar or any compound
thereof is handled, manufactured or used or premises where oils or other
volatile combustibles are handled, manufactured or used shall cause all
rubbish, dirt and refuse to be removed to some proper place so that the same
shall not accumulate at any of the abovementioned premises or appurtenances
thereof and become filthy, hazardous and offensive, nor shall he permit the
accumulation of such industrial refuse from other locations upon the
aforementioned premises in the aforementioned manner; nor shall any such person
cause or allow any smoke, dirt, cinders, gas or offensive odor to escape from
any such building, structure, place, or premises which shall be offensive or
prejudicial to the health or dangerous to the life and property of any person
not being therein nor thereupon engaged, nor shall such person allow industrial
refuse of any sort to accumulate in such a manner as to constitute a fire
hazard. It is hereby declared to be a nuisance to permit any ashes, cinders,
rubbish, dirt or refuse to accumulate on any of the abovementioned premises, or
appurtenances thereof, and become filthy or offensive, or to cause or allow any
dense smoke, cinders, dirt, gas or offensive odor to escape from said premises
or allow or cause to allow industrial refuse of any sort to accumulate in such
fashion as to constitute a fire hazard. The Building Commissioner may summarily
abate said nuisance, and, in specific exception to Section
7-1-1 of this Code, abatement may be had or the general penalties of this Code
invoked without prior notice to said person or his employees. (1940 Code Sec.
10-20)
7-2-13: DECAYING ANIMAL MATTER:
It shall be unlawful for any person having the ownership or control of any
animal matter within the Village which is in process of decay so as to be
offensive or dangerous to the public health to permit the same to remain within
the Village or within one mile of the limits thereof, while in such condition
more than twelve (12) hours after such animal matter shall have come into such
offensive or dangerous condition, whether it be at an establishment for the
rendering or changing the character thereof or not. Any person violating any
provision of this Section shall be fined as in this Code provided. (1940 Code
Sec. 10-21)
7-2-14: DUMPING REFUSE; PERMIT:
The dumping or depositing anywhere within Village limits of garbage, ash,
miscellaneous waste, manure or other substance that may tend to create an
unsightly or dilapidated appearance, that may endanger the life and property of
residents, that may constitute a hazard, that may encroach upon the property of
another, that may be a source of the spread of disease, that may be scattered
by the wind, or that may decompose, or that may be filthy, noxious or of
unhealthful nature is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It shall be unlawful
for any person to dump or deposit or permit the dumping or depositing of refuse
of any kind whether it be industrial refuse or otherwise anywhere within the
Village limits and, in specific exception to Section
7-1-1 of this Title, the nuisance may be abated or the general penalties
provided for in this Code invoked without any further notice to such person.
Where, however, application has been made to the Building Commissioner for a
dumping permit accompanied by the consent of the owner of the property in
question and the Building Commissioner finds that the dumping will not in fact
be above the street grade and will not in fact constitute a nuisance within the
purport of the foregoing prior to the issuance of said permit the applicant
shall file a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with
good and sufficient sureties, approved by the Building Commissioner and
conditioned upon such person's complying with the regulations of this Chapter
pertaining to dumping. (1940 Code Sec. 10-22)
7-2-15: OPENING OFFENSIVE GROUND:
No ground or material filled with offensive matter or substance that will emit
or allow to arise through or from the same any offensive smell or deleterious
exhalation shall be opened or turned up, or the surface thereof removed,
between May 1 and October 1 of any year, except according to permit first
therefor obtained from the Building Commissioner. (1940 Code Sec. 10-23)
7-2-16: SUBSTANCES SCATTERED BY WIND:
No lime, ashes, coal, dry sand, hair, feathers or other substances that may be
scattered by the wind shall be sifted through a sieve, agitated or exposed. No
mat, carpet or cloth shall be shaken or beaten, nor any cloth, yarn, garment,
