material or substance be scoured, cleaned or hung, nor shall any business be
conducted over or in any public way, or where particles set in motion therefrom
will pass into any public way, or into any occupied premises. No usual or
reasonable precaution shall be omitted by any person to prevent fragments or
other substances from failing, or dust and light material from falling, into
any public way or into any place or building from any building or structure
while the same is being altered, repaired or demolished. (1940 Code Sec. 10-24)
7-2-17: REFUSE ON ROOF; AREAWAYS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, throw, deposit or cause to be
placed, thrown or deposited, any substance, papers, refuse or other article, or
any material, on the roof of any building, or in any light or air shaft, court,
or areaway that will cause the dissemination of dust or odors, or be productive
of a nuisance or a menace to the health, comfort or safety of any person or of
the community. No person in possession or control of any building shall permit
or allow the depositor accumulation on the roof of said building or in any
light or air shaft, court or areaway, of any waste material, refuse or other
object or thing that will cause a nuisance or be injurious to the health,
comfort or safety of any person or of the community.
It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner or his authorized
representative to make the inspections at least twice each year of the roofs,
light and air shafts, courts and areaways of all buildings where it has reason
to believe a nuisance exists or any of the regulations of this Code are being
violated. It shall be the duty of the person in possession or control of any
such building to allow the Building Commissioner or its authorized
representative entrance or access, at all reasonable times, to such building
for the purpose of inspection or for the making of such records as may be
necessary. (1940 Code Sec. 10-25)
7-2-18: ROOFERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in or conducting in the Village the
business of roofing of buildings, to throw dirt or roofing refuse from the roof
of any building upon any public way or upon adjoining property while repairing
or renewing roofs.
Every person engaged in or conducting in the Village the business of roofing of
buildings shall remove the dirt and roofing refuse from the roofs by lowering
it in buckets or containers or with ropes, pulleys, or other mechanical devices
while repairing or renewing roofs. (1940 Code Sec. 10-26)
CHAPTER 3
PRIVIES; CATCH BASINS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Construction; Location; Removal
7-3-2: New Construction
7-3-1: CONSTRUCTION; LOCATION; REMOVAL:
   (A)   No vault, privy, catch basin, cistern or cesspool shall be constructed
or rebuilt in the Village except in accordance with this Code and the
regulations of the Building Commissioner. The general privy accommodations of
any place of human habitation shall not be permitted within any such place of
habitation or under any sidewalk adjacent thereto. All cesspools shall be
watertight.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any privy vault or
allow the same to remain upon any premises abutting upon any public way or
public place in which is located a public sewer.
   (C)   It shall constitute and is hereby declared a nuisance for any person
to erect or maintain any privy as near as forty feet (40') to any public way,
dwelling, shop, school, factory, church or public hall or within one hundred
feet (100') of any well, unless the privy be furnished with a substantial vault
six feet (6') deep and made tight so that the contents cannot escape therefrom
and sufficiently secured and enclosed. Any person owning, erecting or
maintaining any privy in violation of this Section shall be subject to a fine
as in this Code provided.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for the owner, agent, occupant or person in
control of any lot, building, structure, premises or place within the Village
to permit or allow the contents of any tub or of any receptacle, cesspool,
privy, catch basin, vault, sink, water closet, cistern or anything in any room,
excavation, vat, building, premises or place to become a nuisance or offensive
so as to be dangerous or prejudicial to health.
   (E)   All privies or catch basins, any part of the contents of which are
above the surface, or within two feet (2') of the surface of the earth, and all
other privies or catch basins that are foul or emit smells and odors
prejudicial to the public health, are hereby declared nuisances, and the
Building Commissioner shall have power to abate the same.
   (F)   All putrid or offensive matter, and all night soil and the contents of
privies, catch basins, vaults and cesspools, and all obnoxious substances in
the Village shall be removed in accordance with the provisions of this Code.
All such privies, catch basins, vaults and cesspools, when cleaned, shall be
disinfected with freshly burned lime, and the work of such disinfection shall
be done by the person removing such contents.
   (G)   The owner, tenant or occupant of any building or premises in the
Village shall not employ, cause or permit any part of the contents of any
vault, privy, catch basin or cesspool (being thereon, and of which he has
control) to be removed, unless according to a permit or the regulations of the
Department of Public Works. No privy or other erection mentioned in this
Section shall be filled with or covered with dirt until the offensive contents
shall be removed.
   (H)   No person shall draw off or allow to run off into any ground, public
way or place of the Village, the contents or any part thereof, of any vault,
privy, cistern, cesspool or catch basin; nor shall any owner, tenant or
occupant of any building to which any vault, catch basin, privy or cesspool
shall appertain or be attached, permit the contents or any part thereof to flow
therefrom or to rise within two feet (2') of any part of the top, or allow such
contents to become offensive.
   (I)   No part of the contents of any privy, vault, sink or cesspool (except
substances other than excrements insoluble in water), or accumulation of any
offensive fluid, or any liquid or semi-liquid substances or material, being in
any excavation, cellar or place within the Village, shall be removed therefrom,
nor shall the same be transported through any public way of the Village unless
the same shall be removed and transported under a permit from the Building
Commissioner by means of an air tight iron wagon of a capacity of not less than
seventy (70) cubic feet, in such a manner as shall entirely prevent the escape
of noxious or offensive odors therefrom. All tools, pails and tubs used by the
scavengers shall be made from galvanized iron or other metal and shall be free
from all wood to prevent saturation of the night soil into them. (1940 Code
Sec. 10-27)
7-3-2: NEW CONSTRUCTION:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to begin the construction,
alterations or repair of any building or of any public or private works without
having provided proper and sufficient toilet facilities, consisting of water
closets, chemical closets, privies, or incinerators of a type to be approved by
the Building Commissioner for the use of employees engaged in the construction,
alteration or repair of such building or of such public or private works.
   (B)   There shall be at least one such water closet, chemical closet, privy
or incinerator for every thirty (30) employees or fraction thereof. Such toilet
facilities in due proportion shall be provided on at least every fifth floor of
a building.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful to install such water closets, chemical closet,
privy or incinerators without first having obtained a permit therefor from the
Building Commissioner and the same shall be installed and maintained in
accordance with the provisions and specifications of such permit. (1940 Code
Sec. 10-28)
CHAPTER 4
FUEL BURNING DEVICES
SECTION:
7-4-1: Application For Permit
7-4-2: Certificate From Commissioner
7-4-3: Annual Inspection
7-4-4: Chimney Repair
7-4-5: Fees
7-4-6: Smoke
7-4-7: Prosecutions
7-4-1: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to install, erect, reconstruct or maintain
any fuel burning plant, refuse burning plant or any chimney connected with any
fuel burning plant until the plans and specifications of the same have been
filed with and approved by the Building Commissioner and a permit issued by him
for such installation, erection, reconstruction or maintenance.
   (A)   The said plans shall show the type of installation and the amount of
work or heating to be done by such fuel burning plant, all appurtenances
thereto, and all provisions made to obtain complete combustion of the fuel and
to prevent smoke. Said plans and specifications shall contain a statement of
the amount and kind of fuel proposed to be used and shall show that the room or
premises in which the fuel burning plant shall be located is provided with
doors, windows, air shafts, fans and other means of ventilation sufficient to
prevent the temperature of such room, basement or other portion of a building
wherein such fuel burning apparatus is to be used, from rising to a point
higher than one hundred twenty degrees Fahrenheit (120°F), and sufficient to
provide that the atmosphere of any such room, basement or other part of the
building wherein such fuel burning apparatus may be located, may be changed
every ten (10) minutes. Such plans shall further show the dimensions of the
room in which such fuel burning apparatus is to be located and the location and
dimensions of all chimneys and smoke stacks used in connection with or as part
of said fuel burning plant. Upon the inspection and approval of such plans and
specifications, a duplicate set of said plans shall be left on file in the
office of the said Deputy Smoke Inspector in charge.
   (B)   The fees hereinafter provided shall be paid to the Building
Commissioner prior to the approval of the plans for installation. If such plans
and specifications shall show that proper provisions for the purpose of
securing complete combustion of the fuel to be used and for the purpose of
preventing and abating smoke have been made, a permit shall be issued for the
installation or for the construction, erection, reconstruction or maintenance
of such fuel burning plant upon payment of the permit fee.
   (C)   It shall be the duty of the Board of Trustees having charge of the
inspection of the premises wherein said fuel burning apparatus is located to
cooperate with the Building Commissioner in seeing that the execution of the
work covered by the said permit shall be done in conformity with the plans and
specifications submitted and approved, and the standards, rules and regulations
fixed by the Smoke Inspection and Abatement Commission. (1940 Code Sec. 10-31)
7-4-2: CERTIFICATE FROM COMMISSIONER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any new or reconstructed plant for
the production and generation of heat or power until he shall have first
procured a certificate from the Building Commissioner.
Such certificate shall state that the plant is so constructed that it will do
the work required and that it can be so managed that no dense smoke shall be
emitted, in violation of the provisions of this Code, from the chimney
connected with the furnace or firebox. (1940 Code Sec. 10-32)
7-4-3: ANNUAL INSPECTION:
An annual inspection shall be made of fuel burning equipment for which
certificates allowing use of the plant have been issued to determine that such
equipment will do the work required and can be so managed that no dense smoke
shall be emitted from the chimney connected with the furnace or firebox in
violation of the provisions of this Code. If, at the time of the annual
inspection or of any inspection subsequent to the issuance by the Department of
the certificate allowing use of the plant, it is found that the fuel burning
equipment is in such condition that it cannot do the work required or cannot be
so managed that no dense smoke will be emitted, in violation of the provisions
of this Code, from the chimney connected to the furnace or firebox, the Deputy
Smoke Inspector in charge of such equipment and of the defects found shall make
an order to correct, repair or replace the defective equipment. If, within ten
(10) days from the date of said notice, said order has not been complied with,
the Building Commissioner in charge may revoke the certificate allowing use of
the plant. (1940 Code Sec. 10-33)
7-4-4: CHIMNEY REPAIR:
No owner shall install, alter or repair any chimney or any furnace or device
which alteration, change or installation will affect the method or efficiency
of preventing and abating smoke, or alter or repair any brick work on or about
any high pressure boiler without first submitting the plans and specifications
to the Building Commissioner and securing a permit therefor. (1940 Code Sec.
10-34)
7-4-5: FEES:
Fees for the inspection of plans and issuing permits for the inspection of
furnaces or other fuel burning apparatus or devices, whether for initial
installation, repair or alteration, and for issuing certificates shall be
fifteen dollars ($15.00).
This Section shall not apply to furnaces or other fuel burning apparatus
devices installed or used to heat private residences, tenement or buildings
consisting of two (2) apartments or less.
The fee for the examination or inspection shall include the issuing of
certificate for operation, in case such certificate for operation is granted,
and shall be paid at the time the permit is secured.
Fees for annual inspection shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for low pressure
boilers and fifteen dollars ($15.00) for high pressure boilers, whether the
boiler is one type or another shall be determined in accordance with the rules
of the Heating, Piping and Air Conditioning Contractor's National Association
Code.
Where furnaces are other than boiler furnaces the fee shall be ten dollars
($10.00). (1940 Code Sec. 10-35)
7-4-6: SMOKE:
It shall be unlawful for any person owning or in charge of any smoke stack of
any locomotive, tar kettle, steam machine or contrivance, or of any open fire,
smoke stack or chimney of any building or premises to allow the emission of
dense smoke except for a period of or periods aggregating six (6) minutes in
any one hour at the time when the firebox is being cleaned out or a new fire
being built therein. Such emission of smoke is hereby declared to be a nuisance
and may be summarily abated by the Building Commissioner or by anyone whom he
may duly authorize for such purpose. Such abatement may be in addition to the
fine as in this Code provided.
No person shall cause or allow the escape from any smoke stack or chimney into
the open air of such quantities of ash dust, soot, cinders, acid or other
fumes, dirt or other material, or noxious gases in such place or manner as to
cause injury detriment, nuisance or annoyance to any person or to the public or
to endanger the comfort, repose, health or safety of any such person or the
public or in such a manner as to cause or have a natural tendency to cause
injury or damage to business or property.
All persons participating in any violation of this provision either as owners,
proprietors, lessees, agents, tenants, managers, superintendents, captains,
engineers, firemen, janitors or otherwise shall be severally liable therefor.
(1940 Code Sec. 10-36)
7-4-7: PROSECUTIONS:
Prosecutions for violations of this Chapter shall be instituted by the Building
Commissioner and shall be prosecuted in the name of the Village.
The issuance and delivery by the Building Commissioner of any permit or
certificate for the construction, alteration or repair of any plant or chimney
connected with a plant shall not be held to exempt any person to whom any such
permit has been issued or delivered, or who is in possession of any such
permit, from prosecution on account of the emission or issuance of dense smoke
caused or permitted by any such person. (1940 Code Sec. 10-37)
CHAPTER 5
AMBULANCE/VEHICLE FIRE SERVICE
SECTION:
7-5-1: Ambulance Outside Village Limits
7-5-2: Rates For Ambulance/Vehicle Fire Service
7-5-3: Written Authority
7-5-4: Owner Designated
7-5-5: Reimbursement For Emergency Response Services
7-5-1: AMBULANCE OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS:
The fire chief, or any member of the fire department acting in that capacity,
shall have the authority to send the village ambulance upon request within the
corporate limits of the village, or outside of the corporate limits of the
village pursuant to an agreement of such service entered into between the
village and the owner of property lying outside of the village, provided that
the ambulance and attendants thereto can be spared from service at the time the
request is made. (Ord. 16-07, 5-10-2016)
7-5-2: RATES FOR AMBULANCE/VEHICLE FIRE SERVICE:
   (A)   Nonresident Ambulance Fees: Whenever ambulance services are provided
by the Forest View fire department to individuals who are not residents of the
village of Forest View, or provided with ambulance service by the village or
any entity which provides emergency medical services to the village pursuant to
an agreement entered into by the village or mutual aid agreement with the
village, such nonresidents shall be charged the fees as follows:
 
BLS transport          $1,750.00
ALS transport          $1,750.00
ALS2 transport         $1,750.00
Treatment/no transport $250.00
 
These charges shall not apply:
      1.   When such service is provided pursuant to a contract between the
village and a private entity located outside the village limits; or
      2.   When the nonresident requires such service while a guest at the home
of a Forest View resident.
   (B)   Nonresident Fire Response Rates: The rate for responding to vehicle
fires to nonresidents of the village of Forest View shall be computed at the
maximum rate specified in 70 Illinois Compiled Statutes 705/11f(c) and charged
to the owner of the vehicle.
   (C)   Hospital Transport: The fire department shall transport persons from
Forest View to only one of the following hospitals:
      1.   Advocate Christ Medical Center, Oak Lawn, Illinois.
      2.   Hines VA, Hines, Illinois.
      3.   Hinsdale Hospital, Hinsdale, Illinois.
      4.   Mt. Sinai Hospital, Chicago, Illinois.
      5.   LaGrange Community Memorial General Hospital, La Grange, Illinois.
      6.   Loyola University Medical Center, Maywood, Illinois.
      7.   MacNeal Memorial Hospital, Berwyn, Illinois.
Provided, however, that in exceptional circumstances, the fire chief or medical
control may authorize the transportation of persons to other hospitals that
have specialist physicians or special equipment and facilities not available at
the abovementioned hospitals. Further, this restriction shall not apply
pursuant to a contract or mutual aid agreement outside the village limits.
   (D)   Right To Waive Fee: The Village Administrator or his designee reserves
the right to waive the ambulance services fee or any portion thereof. (Ord. 16-
07, 5-10-2016; amd. Ord. 22-33, 11-22-2022)
7-5-3: WRITTEN AUTHORITY:
Before any such ambulance/vehicle fire service shall be rendered, every
property owner shall by written instrument, filed with the village clerk,
undertake to pay all charges for services so rendered at the rate set forth
above and shall indemnify, keep and save harmless the village against any
claim, judgment or liability of any kind which the village may suffer or which
may accrue against, be charged to or be recovered from the village or any of
its officials from or by reason or on account of injuries to persons or
property during the performance of said ambulance/vehicle fire service between
the time said ambulance/fire apparatus and its attendants leave its quarters to
the time of its official return thereto. (Ord. 06-18, 11-14-2006)
7-5-4: OWNER DESIGNATED:
The property owner or owner of property for the purposes of this chapter shall
be deemed to be any person or entity which may occupy property or control same
although not the legal owner thereof in fact. (Ord. 80-4, 5-13-1980)
7-5-5: REIMBURSEMENT FOR EMERGENCY RESPONSE SERVICES:
   (A)   Definitions. As used in this Section, the following terms are hereby
given the meanings set forth below:
      1.   Advanced Life Support Services (ALS). An advanced level of pre-
hospital and inter-hospital emergency care and non-emergency medical services.
      2.   Basic Life Support Services. A basic level of pre-hospital and
inter-hospital emergency care and non-emergency medical services that includes
airway management, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), control of shock and
bleeding and splinting of fractures.
      3.   Emergency Medical Service Provider. The Fire Department providing
emergency medical services pursuant to dispatch under the E-911 system.
      4.   Emergency Medical Services (EMS). All life-safety services,
including, but not limited to, advanced life support, basic life support,
ambulance, extrication and medical-related transport.
      5.   Emergency Personnel. Members of the Fire Department during their
involvement in an emergency and non-emergency incident.
      6.   Emergency Response. Providing, sending or utilizing firefighting,
emergency medical and rescue services or related services and personnel by the
Fire Department.
      7.   Extrication. When one or more members of the Fire Department are
required to use hydraulic, gas powered, electric powered, air powered, or other
specialized rescue equipment to remove a person from a vehicle or other
structure.
      8.   Fire Department. Fire Department means the Village of Forest View
Fire Department.
      9.   Hazardous Material (Hazmat). Any material that poses an unreasonable
risk to the health and safety of the public, environment or emergency
personnel, if not properly controlled during handling, storage, manufacture,
processing, packaging, use, disposal or transportation, and shall include but
not be limited to: explosives, pyrotechnics, flammable gas, flammable
compressed gas, nonflammable compressed gas, flammable liquid, combustible
liquid, oxidizing material, poisonous gases, poisonous liquid, poisonous solid,
irritating material, etiological material, radioactive material, corrosive
material or liquefied petroleum gas.
      10.   Incendiary Act. A fire purposely set by a person or persons.
      11.   Incident. Any request for the services of the Fire Department.
      12.   Malicious Incident. An incident which is created by an individual's
intentional purpose to cause property damage, endanger lives, and/or cause the
response of emergency personnel for something other than an actual emergency.
      13.   Mileage Charge. A charge per mile from the patient pick up to the
hospital facility where the patient is transported.
      14.   Negligent/Careless Act. Failure to exercise the standard of care
that a reasonably prudent person would use under similar circumstances,
including actions which a reasonably prudent person would not do, including the
disregard of the safety of others.
      15.   Nonresident. A person who is not domiciled within the corporate
limits of the Village of Forest View.
      16.   Nonresidential Refusal. All persons who are nonresidents of the
Village who have received or accepted ambulance or life-safety services from
Emergency Personnel but have refused transportation by ambulance to a hospital.
      17.   Nonresidents Transported to Hospital. All persons who are
nonresidents of the Village who are transported by a Fire Department operated
ambulance from within the corporate limits of the Village to a hospital or
other authorized medical facility for medical care or attention.
      18.   Person. Any natural person(s), partnership, corporation, limited
liability partnership or corporation, association, firm, insurance carrier,
servicing agent or other legal entity.
      19.   Resident. A person who is domiciled within the corporate limits of
the Village of Forest View.
      20.   Resident Refusal. All persons who are residents of the Village who
have received or accepted ambulance and/or life-safety services from Emergency
Personnel but have refused transportation by ambulance to a hospital.
      21.   Residents Transported to Hospital. All persons who are residents of
the Village who are transported by Emergency Personnel from within the
corporate limits of the Village to a hospital or other authorized medical
facility for medical care or attention.
   (B)   Occurrences/Incidents Requiring Reimbursement. The following types of
occurrences or incidents are subject to the reimbursement fees set forth in
subsection (C) below.
      1.   Negligent/careless actions by persons that cause an incident
resulting in an emergency response.
      2.   Malicious or incendiary actions by persons that cause an incident
resulting in an emergency response.
      3.   Driving under the influence. Any person found guilty, including an
order of supervision or probation, of "DUI", who proximately causes any
incident resulting in an emergency response.
      4.   Salvage operations. Fire Department salvage operations including but
not limited to tarping personal property and smoke or water removal.
      5.   Fire company standby. When a fire company (engine, truck or
ambulance) is requested or required to stand by for a non-Village sponsored
event. No other fire company standby services shall be provided within the
Village other than through the Village's Fire Department unless the Fire
Department is unable to provide such services.
      6.   Extrication of persons from vehicles involved in traffic accidents.
      7.   Extinguishment of a motor vehicle fire.
      8.   Debris removal, Hazmat removal, fluid removal, or any other
mitigation or operational tasks performed by a fire company at the scene.
      9.   Non-court ordered non-residents who request a child seat
installation.
      10.   All court ordered installations of a child car seat regardless of
residency.
      11.   False alarms.
   (C)   Fee Schedule. Fees for the acts enumerated in subsection (B) above,
shall be charged to the responsible party in accordance with the following
schedule:
Motor vehicle incidents and other emergency services:
Motor Vehicle Incidents:
Level 1 - Basic response four hundred and thirty-five dollars ($435.00) per
hour - Hazardous materials assessment and scene stabilization.
Level 2 - Intermediate response four hundred and ninety-five dollars ($495.00)
per hour - Includes Level 1 services, plus clean up and material used
(sorbents) for hazardous fluid clean up and disposal.
Level 3 - Advanced response six hundred and five dollars ($605.00) per hour -
Car fire services including one or more of the following. Provide scene safety,
fire suppression, breathing air, rescue tools, hand tools, foam structure
protection and clean up of gasoline or other automotive fluids that are spilled
as a result of the accident/incident.
Add on services:
Extrication one thousand and five dollars ($1,005.00) per hour - includes heavy
rescue tools, ropes, airbags, cribbing etc.
Create a landing zone - four hundred dollars ($400.00) per hour.
Additional time on scene:
Fire Engine billed at four hundred dollars ($400.00) per hour.
Fire Truck billed at five hundred dollars ($500.00).
Miscellaneous equipment billed at three hundred dollars ($300.00) per hour.
Fire Investigation:
Two hundred and seventy-five dollars ($275.00) per hour. Includes scene safety,
investigation, source identification, K-9/Arson dog unit, identification
equipment, mobile detection unit fire and fire report.
Water Incidents:
Level 1 - Basic response four hundred dollars ($400.00) per hour, plus fifty
dollars ($50.00) per rescue person. Includes engine response, first responder
set-up and command, scene safety and investigation (including possible patient
contact, hazard control).
Fire Prevention and Protection:
Fire Inspections:
Initial Inspection for a commercial property: one (1) square foot up to ten
thousand (10,000) square feet of property with one (1) reinspection within
thirty (30( days: fifty dollars ($50.00); for each reinspection thereafter
until all violations are corrected: seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per
inspection.
Initial Inspection for a commercial property: ten thousand and one (10,001)
square feet and above of property with one (1) reinspection within thirty (30)
days: one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00); for each reinspection thereafter
until all violations are corrected: one hundred and seventy-five dollars
($175.00) per inspection.
Post-Fire Investigation:
Will be billed at two hundred and seventy-five dollars ($275.00) per hour.
Includes scene safety, investigation, source identification, K-9/Arson dog
unit, identification equipment, mobile detection unit fire and fire report.
Fire Alarms:
Nuisance Alarms shall be defined for this purpose as more than five (5) alarms
from one alarm position in a calendar month due to a system malfunction: Will
be billed at fifty dollars ($50.00) each alarm.
   (D)   Waiver of Fees. It is within the discretion of the Village
Administrator to waive or reduce any fee based on mitigating circumstances.
   (E)   Invoice/Payment. An invoice for the payment of the service fees set
forth in subsection (C) above, shall be sent to the responsible party's
insurance carrier, or to the responsible party directly if there is no
insurance involved. Payment shall be due upon the rendering of an invoice or
statement by the Village or its authorized billing and collection service
corporation or agent. (Ord. 80-4, 5-13-1980; amd. Ord. 22-33, 11-22-2022)

CHAPTER 7
MOTOR VEHICLE STORAGE
SECTION:
7-7-1: Nuisance Declared
7-7-2: Notice; Removal
7-7-3: Removal
7-7-4: Definition
7-7-5: Operable Motor Vehicles; Limitation On Number
7-7-6: Penalty
7-7-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
All inoperable motor vehicles, whether on public or private property, and in
view of the general public, are hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 93-1,
1-26-1993)
7-7-2: NOTICE; REMOVAL:
The owner of an inoperable motor vehicle, which is on open private property
under the control of the owner of the vehicle, shall cause such vehicle to be
removed and disposed of within fourteen (14) days from the issuance of a notice
to do so from the village 1 . (Ord. 00-10, 9-12-2000)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  9-2-12(B) of this code.
7-7-3: REMOVAL:
In the event an owner fails to remove and dispose of an inoperable motor
vehicle following the notice provided for in section
7-7-2 of this chapter, the village police department is hereby authorized and
directed to remove such inoperable motor vehicle or parts thereof. The owner of
the inoperable motor vehicle shall be entitled to a pre-tow hearing as provided
in subsection
9-4-3(C) and section
9-4-6 of this code. The owner of the inoperable motor vehicle shall be
responsible for all costs incurred by the village in removal, storage and
disposal. (Ord. 00-10, 9-12-2000)
7-7-4: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, "inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle
which for a period of at least thirty (30) days the engine, wheels or other
parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have
been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated, or in such a state of disrepair
that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own power. "Inoperable
motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered
temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to
perform ordinary service or repair operations. (Ord. 93-1, 1-26-1993)
7-7-5: OPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES; LIMITATION ON NUMBER:
The owner of property located within a residential zoning district of the
village shall not maintain on open private property a number of motor vehicles
exceeding the number of licensed drivers residing on the property, plus two
(2). For purposes of this section, "open private property" shall mean property
under the control of the owner, such that the vehicle or vehicles are visible
either from the street or from adjoining properties. "Motor vehicles" shall
include cars, trucks, minivans, four-wheel drive vehicles and similar vehicles,
but shall not include recreational vehicles, campers or boats. (Ord. 93-1, 1-
26-1993)
7-7-6: PENALTY:
Any person found in violation of any of the terms of this chapter shall be
fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum penalty
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day of violation shall be considered a separate
offense. The village may avail itself of any other administrative or judicial
remedy to prevent a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 93-1, 1-26-1993; amd. Ord.
95-23, 10-10-1995)
CHAPTER 8
ON-SITE RECYCLING FOR MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURES
SECTION:
7-8-1: Definitions
7-8-2: On-Site Multi-Family Structure Recycling Program
7-8-3: Recyclable Material Collection Requirements For Village Scavengers
7-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
MULTI-FAMILY PROPERTY: A property consisting of one or more "multi-family
structures".
MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURE: A building with more than one residential living unit.
OWNER: Any persons, corporation, partnership, or entity such as a condominium
or homeowners association, jointly or severally having an ownership interest in
a multi-family property or otherwise being responsible for solid waste
collection.
PRIVATE SCAVENGER: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the removal of
solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material from any location
with the Village not covered by either an exclusive collection contract between
the Village and a contracted hauler, or a franchise agreement between the
Village and a franchised hauler.
RECYCLABLE MATERIAL: A material which would otherwise be abandoned or discarded
but which can be utilized in the secondary material market.
RECYCLING: The process by which materials that would otherwise be disposed of
or discarded are collected, separated or processed and returned to the economic
mainstream in the form of raw materials or products.
SOURCE SEPARATION: A process that separates recyclable material from other
refuse prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. (Ord.
95-5, 3-28-1995)
7-8-2: ON-SITE MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURE RECYCLING PROGRAM:
   (A)   Program Requirements:
      1.   All "multi-family properties", as defined above, shall be required
to institute an on-site recycling program, with collection of recyclable
materials to be no less than one pickup per week.
      2.   Said program shall be instituted by a multi-family property on or
before May 1, 1995.
      3.   An acceptable recycling program shall include, but is not limited
to, the following components:
         (a)   Recyclable materials collections;
         (b)   Data collection including the hauler's quarterly report;
         (c)   Education campaign and materials; and
         (d)   Recycling program administration and maintenance.
   (B)   Specific Requirements:
      1.   Recycling collection areas shall be conveniently located and
maintained within each dwelling unit, and consist of separate containers for
the purpose of temporary storage of recyclables. Whenever possible, recycling
containers should be placed adjacent to solid waste collection containers.
      2.   Indoor collection/storage areas shall be established in accordance
with appropriate Village fire and/or safety codes.
      3.   Each individual dwelling unit shall maintain their own recycling
area, including the container, in a clean, sanitary, and litter-free manner.
      4.   On-site multi-family structure recycling programs are required to
collect the same recyclable materials collected through the Village residential
recycling program.
      5.   Recyclable materials must be source separated from other solid waste
prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. Separate
collection containers and collection vehicles shall be employed.
      6.   The contracted Village scavenger providing the on-site recycling
collection service shall be responsible for furnishing and maintaining
collection vehicles which are deemed necessary in the recycling program. The
contracted Village scavenger shall be responsible for the collection,
intermediate storage or transfer, transportation, and sale of recyclable
materials to a processor, broker, or market desired for reuse of materials.
      7.   The Village shall notify residents of the availability of recycling
services through a formal and ongoing educational campaign, and shall use their
best efforts to gain and maintain participation in the program.
      8.   It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized persons to remove or
damage any recyclable materials placed in designated containers, or the
containers themselves. Title to recyclable materials shall pass to the Village
scavenger when the materials are placed into the collection vehicle. (Ord. 95-
5, 3-28-1995)
7-8-3: RECYCLABLE MATERIAL COLLECTION REQUIREMENTS FOR VILLAGE SCAVENGERS:
   (A)   All Village contracted scavengers desiring to receive a scavenger
license to collect solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material
from multi-family properties in the Village must comply with all applicable
Federal, State, County and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. As a
condition of receiving, renewing and maintaining a scavenger license to collect
solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material from multi- family
properties within the Village, each licensee or applicant for such license
shall:
      1.   Obtain all permits and licenses required by Federal, State and
County laws, ordinances, rules and regulations and maintain the same in full
force and effect.
      2.   Provide collection and recycling services for all multi- family
properties in the residential area.
      3.   Failure to comply with the above provisions shall result in a denial
of receiving, renewing or maintaining a scavenger license until such time as
the applicant complies with all provisions set forth in this Section.
   (B)   Reporting Requirements:
      1.   The Village's exclusive recycling contractor shall submit a
quarterly report to both the Village and the West Cook County Solid Waste
Agency that contains the total weight or volume of recyclable materials
collected from multi-family properties it serves within the Village.
      2.   Quarterly reports submitted to the Village shall contain aggregate
totals concerning the information listed above for all multi-family properties
the contracted Village scavenger serves within the residential area.
      3.   Reports shall be due no later than twenty (20) days after the close
of each quarter. "Quarters" are defined as follows: First Quarter - January 1
through March 31; Second Quarter - April 1 through June 30; Third Quarter -
July 1 through September 30 and Fourth Quarter - October 1 through December 31.
Reports all follow the formate prescribed by the West Cook County Solid Waste
Agency.
   (C)   Implementation And Continuation Of Program Required:
      1.   Implementation of on-site multi-family structure recycling programs
shall be required as stated in subsection
7-8-2(A)2 of this Chapter. Such recycling programs shall be maintained in
effect regardless of any change of building ownership or Village scavenger
service. (Ord. 95-5, 3-28-1995)
CHAPTER 9
SPECIALIZED RESCUE TEAMS
SECTION:
7-9-1: Responsibility For Costs
7-9-2: Emergency Response Charges
7-9-3: Village Listed As Rescue Service
7-9-4: Fees Or Other Charges
7-9-5: Severability
7-9-6: Violation
7-9-1: RESPONSIBILITY FOR COSTS:
Notwithstanding any other provisions or rule of law, the following persons
shall be jointly, or jointly and severally liable for all costs of a
specialized rescue team as set forth in this chapter:
   (A)   The owner of the property on which the specialized emergency response
occurs;
   (B)   Any person involved in any activity which caused or contributed to the
causation of the emergency;
   (C)   In cases involving the rescue or recovery of an individual, the
individual and his/her employer if the person was in the village in furtherance
of the employer's interest; and
   (D)   In cases involving the rescue or recovery of property, the owner of
the property and anyone who had custody or control of the property at the time
of the emergency. (Ord. 03-10, 8-26-2003)
7-9-2: EMERGENCY RESPONSE CHARGES:
The charges for an emergency response of a specialized rescue team are as
follows for the purpose of tactical rescue, high angle rescue, confined space
rescue, below grade rescue, hazardous materials response and/or trench rescue:
   (A)   One hundred dollars ($100.00) per hour/per vehicle;
   (B)   Thirty five dollars ($35.00) per hour/per team member; and
   (C)   Cost of all materials or equipment necessary in providing the
response. (Ord. 03-10, 8-26-2003)
7-9-3: VILLAGE LISTED AS RESCUE SERVICE:
In addition to charges for a specialized rescue team response, if a person or
entity within the village requests that, pursuant to occupational safety and
health laws, the village or any intergovernmental agency to which the village
belongs be listed as the rescue service or as the backup rescue service on the
permit or a permit required confined space activity, the charge for such
service shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day. If a person or
entity lists the village as the rescue service or the backup rescue service
without notifying the village of Forest View, in writing, in advance of entry
into any permit required confined space, the person or entity shall be charged
one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per day for each day the permit
is outstanding. (Ord. 03-10, 8-26-2003)
7-9-4: FEES OR OTHER CHARGES:
Nothing in this chapter shall preclude the assessment of fees or other charges
pursuant to any other village ordinance or resolution. (Ord. 03-10, 8-26-2003)
7-9-5: SEVERABILITY:
The provisions and sections of this chapter shall be deemed severable and the
invalidity of any portion of this chapter shall not affect the validity of the
remainder. (Ord. 03-10, 8-26-2003)
7-9-6: VIOLATION:
Any person or entity that refuses to pay or fails to pay the above listed
charges within sixty (60) days of notice of the charge will be deemed to have
violated this chapter and will incur a fine, as determined elsewhere in this
code, for each offense, plus all legal fees and all costs incurred by the
village for enforcement. Such fees and costs shall include, but not be limited
to, attorney fees and costs of collection. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed for each day on which a violation occurs and continues. (Ord. 03-10,
8-26-2003)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Obstructions
8-1-2: Clay Holes
8-1-3: Railroad Ties; Combustible Material
8-1-4: Other Work Performed On A Right Of Way
8-1-1: OBSTRUCTIONS:
No person shall construct or maintain any bay window, bridge, wire, pipe or
other structure or device over any public way or other public place; or any
clock or post at the curb or any clock attached outside the face of any
building; or any loading platform switch track or pushcar track upon any public
way or other public place; or any tunnel or vault underneath the surface of any
public way or other public place; or install or maintain any wire, pipe or
conduit underneath the surface of any public way or other public place without
first having obtained specific authority by ordinance passed by the Board
authorizing such special privilege.
   (A)   To receive authority for erection of one of the aforementioned
structures written application shall be made to the Building Commissioner
accompanied by plans and specifications of the structure and a good sufficient
bond executed by the grantee, running to the Village, in the penal sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with sureties to be approved by said Commissioner
and conditional upon the faithful observances and performance of each condition
of the permit to be issued by the Board and conditioned further to indemnify,
keep and save harmless the Village against all liabilities, judgments, costs
and damages and expenses which may in any way come against the Village in
consequence of the granting of said permit or which may accrue against, be
charged to, or recovered from the Village by reason of any act or thing done by
virtue of the authority given in said permit. Said bond shall be kept in force
throughout the life of said permit and rights accruing under said permit shall
be cancelled whenever said bond lapses.
Upon receipt of said application together with accompanying documents the
Commissioner shall examine said application and determine whether: 1) the
erection of said structure will comply with the zoning and building provisions
of this Code, or 2) will not at any time be reasonably capable of constituting
a nuisance within the purport of the provisions of this Code. The Commissioner
shall submit said application to the Board together with his findings thereon.
Thereupon the Board shall examine the findings of the Commissioner and such
further information as it may otherwise acquire and make its own finding of
fact as to the conformity of said proposed structure with local ordinances. It
shall pass an ordinance enabling erection of the structure and cause the Clerk
to issue a permit thereon if it finds that the erection of the structure will
conform with local ordinances. Said permit shall be conditioned upon erection
of said structure in accordance with plans and specifications, payment of
appropriate fees and licenses, and shall be revokable upon a subsequent finding
by the Board that the proposed structure is not being built in conformity with
said plans or that there has been a failure to pay proper license and permit
fees.
   (B)   Annually it shall be the duty of the Commissioner of Buildings to
inspect said structures and ascertain whether or not said structure remains
sound and continues to be maintained in accordance with original plans and
specifications and upon submission of his annual report to the Clerk finding
the said structure is properly maintained in accordance thereto the Clerk, with
the requisites of this Section together with license fees pertaining thereto,
shall issue a license for the annual period. License fee for any year (or
portion thereof) in the event the structure is erected during a calendar year,
shall be as follows:
      1.   For erection of any structure protruding over any Village street,
way or place (said structure shall be not less than 12 feet from the surface of
the way or place): fifty cents ($0.50) for every lineal foot or portion thereof
so extended.
      2.   For erection of any loading platform switch track or pushcar track
upon any public way or other public place: two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per
lineal foot or portion thereof fronting on said way or place.
      3.   For erection of any post at any curb: ten dollars ($10.00).
      4.   For erection of any tunnel or vault under any public way or place
(said structure shall not interfere with existing public works): ten dollars
($10.00) for each foot of its diameter.
Failure to pay license fees provided for herein shall be an offense punishable
by fine.
   (C)   In case of the installation and maintenance of an overhead system for
the conduct of electrical current at more than six hundred (600) volts upon the
public ways and places of the Village, in addition to other requirements of
this Section, said system shall be erected and maintained in accordance with
the following standards:
      1.   Conductors: Where copper is used as a conducting medium, the
breaking stress shall be not less than one thousand two hundred thirty seven
(1,237) pounds. Vertical space between conductors shall be one foot (1') per
one hundred feet (100') of span length and minimum clearances shall be twenty
six inches (26") up to eleven (11) K.V., thirty eight inches (38") where
between eleven (11) K.V., and thirty three (33) K.V., fifty six inches (56")
where between thirty three (33) K.V. and sixty six (66) K.V., and ninety two
inches (92") where above sixty six (66) K.V.
      2.   The minimum clearances between conductors and poles shall be twelve
inches (12") up to eleven (11) K.V., fourteen inches (14") from thence to
thirty three (33) K.V., twenty eight inches (28") from thence to sixty six (66)
K.V. and forty two inches (42") where above sixty six (66) K.V. Minimum
clearances between conductors and poles shall be as above stated where pin
insulators are used. Where, however, suspension type insulators are used,
clearances shall be as above indicated, plus seventy five one-hundredths (0.75)
times the length of the suspension insulator string.
      3.   Insulators: Insulators shall be of porcelain and smoothly glazed,
where either a suspension or pin type insulator is used more than one shed
shall be utilized where the line is carrying more than ten thousand (10,000)
volts. The total thickness of the insulator shall be one-eighth inch (1/8") per
sixteen thousand five hundred (16,500) volts carried or fraction thereof.
      4.   Grounding: A ground wire shall be strung between poles and grounded
in earth every quarter mile or, as an alternative thereto, each and every pole
shall be separately grounded.
      5.   Poles: Poles shall be constructed in accordance with the
requirements of the National Electrical Code Handbook, 3rd Edition. Terms used
herein shall be in accordance with definitions in said Handbook. (1940 Code
Sec. 8-5)
8-1-2: CLAY HOLES:
The owner, lessee or person in possession of any real estate within the Village
upon which are located or situated any clay holes or other similar excavations
is hereby required to cause such clay holes or other excavations to be enclosed
with wooden or wire fences of not less than six feet (6') in height. When such
fences are of wire, only smooth or nonbarbed wire shall be used, and such fence
or fences shall consist of not less than eight (8) rows of wire, and such rows
of wire shall not be more than nine inches (9") apart. (1940 Code Sec. 5-13)
8-1-3: RAILROAD TIES; COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place, leave or suffer to be
thrown, placed or left any used railroad ties, refuse, or combustible material
in or upon any street, alley, parkway or other public place or upon any
railroad right of way, vacant, or unimproved lot or parcel of land in the
Village. (Ord. 72-77, 7-11-1972)
8-1-4: OTHER WORK PERFORMED ON A RIGHT OF WAY:
Whenever any work not specifically included in section
8-1-1 of this chapter is performed on a village right-of-way, the individual,
firm, or corporation performing such work shall first provide to the village a
cash bond in the amount of five hundred ($500.00) dollars. This cash bond shall
secure the cost to restore village right-of-way to at least as good a condition
as that existing prior to the construction under the permit, as determined by
the Village. If the Village determines to draw upon this cash bond, it will
provide the contractor with seven (7) days' notice specifying the reason for
such proposed draw. The contractor may, within said seven (7) day period,
appeal that determination to the Village Administrator. The decision of the
Village Administrator will be final. (Ord. 85-18, 11-12-1985; amd. Ord. 22-34,
12-13-2022)
CHAPTER 2
WATERWORKS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Water Rates
8-2-2: Billing And Payment
8-2-3: Turn On/Off Charge, And Connection Charge
8-2-4: Water Supplied Through Meters
8-2-5: Placement Of Meters
8-2-6: Defective Meters
8-2-7: Authority To Enter Premises
8-2-8: Water Service; Emergency And Temporary Construction
8-2-9: Obstruct Water Flow
8-2-10: Flushing Of Sanitary Sewers
8-2-11: Restricted Hours For Specified Uses
8-2-12: Emergency Proclamation
8-2-13: Regulation Of Potable Water Supply Wells Within The Corporate Limits Of
The Village Of Forest View
8-2-1: WATER RATES:
   Effective June 1, 2024, the following charges and rates for the use and for
the service supplied by the waterworks system of the village, based upon the
amount of water consumed, as shown by the water meters, as set forth
hereinafter:
   (A)   For each residential user, the quarterly charge for water service
shall be as follows:
 
For the first 9,000 gallons                                          $115.56
For excess over 9,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons                     $14.44
The minimum quarterly charge for residential water service shall be: $115.56
 
   (B)   For each commercial user, the monthly charge for water service shall
be as follows:
 
For the first 3,000 gallons                                       $89.58
For excess over 3,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons                  $14.44
The minimum monthly charge for commercial water service shall be: $89.58
 
   (C)   For each industrial (manufacturing) user, the monthly charge for water
shall be as follows:
 
For the first 9,000 gallons                                       $253.22
For excess over 9,000 gallons, per 1,000 gallons                  $14.44
The minimum monthly charge for industrial water service shall be: $253.22
 
   (D)   The rates and charges applicable to municipal and government users,
including the village, its offices, police and fires departments, shall be a
flat rate of one thousand three hundred ninety dollars and forty-four cents
($1,390.44) per month, irrespective of the quantity of water used. The Forest
View park district shall pay the monthly commercial rates as established and
amended from time to time for each metered water service.
   (E)   The village hereby authorizes the Metropolitan Water Reclamation
District of Greater Chicago to make connection to the potable water supply of
the village through the facilities of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation
District of Greater Chicago for domestic purposes only.
(Ord. 17-09, 5-23-2017; amd. Ord. 19-12, 5-28-2019; Ord. 21-03, 6-8-2021; Ord.
22-14, 5-10-2022; Ord. 23-03, 3-14-2023; Ord. 24-03, 3-12-2024; Ord. 25-09, 5-
13-2025)
8-2-2: BILLING AND PAYMENT:
   (A)   Charges: Charges for residential water service shall be billed on a
quarterly basis.
Billing periods shall be as follows:
      1.   February 1 through April 30
      2.   May 1 through July 31
      3.   August 1 through October 31
      4.   November 1 through January 31
Charges for industrial and commercial water service shall be billed monthly.
   (B)   Liability: The owner of the premises shall be liable to pay for the
service on said premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the
Village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises is severally
liable therefor to the Village. Application for village water service must be
made in the owner's name with the owner's current mailing address.
   (C)   Due Date: All bills for residential water service shall be payable not
later than the close of business on the last day of the month following the end
of the billing period. All bills for industrial and commercial water service
shall be payable not later than the close of business on the fifteenth day
following the end of the billing period. A penalty of ten percent (10%) shall
be added to the principal amount of any bill (including all arrearages) not
paid within said thirty (30) day period or fifteen (15) day period, as the case
may be. (Ord. 97-16, 7-22-1997)
   (D)   Delinquent Charges: Whenever any charges for water service, or service
charges for installation, disconnection, turnon or shutoff of water service
remain unpaid, in whole or in part, for thirty (30) days (15 days for
commercial/industrial customers), such charges shall be deemed delinquent. Once
an account has been deemed to be delinquent, the water clerk shall immediately
send a series of three (3) letters spaced seven (7) business days apart
notifying the customer of the delinquency. If the account is not paid after the
third letter has been sent, a fourth and final letter notifying the customer
that if after seven (7) business days, the account remains delinquent, water
service will be terminated. This process will take place only once during any
rolling twelve (12) month period beginning on the date the initial late notice
is sent. Subsequent delinquencies will only receive the fourth or final notice
providing for a disconnect after seven (7) business days. Whenever the premises
is occupied by a person or persons other than the owner, and the village has
previously received notice of this, the notice of delinquency shall be mailed
to the owner of the property if his/her address is known to the village.
   (E)   Disconnection Of Service For Nonpayment; Reinstatement Fee: The water
supply may be shut off from any premises for which the water bill remains
unpaid for thirty (30) days (15 days for commercial/industrial customers) after
the rendition of the bill for such service. If water service is discontinued
after the owner of the premises or his/her representative has failed to make
payment, water service shall not be reinstated until all past due bills and
penalties due thereon are paid in full, together with payment of a fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for shutoff of service for delinquency and a fee of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) for cost of reinstating service to the location.
The second shutoff and reinstatement is subject to surcharges of one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) each. A third such occurrence will result in surcharges
of two hundred dollars ($200.00) each and shall remain at this rate for any
subsequent disconnects.
   (F)   Delinquent Charges; Lien: Whenever any charges for water service or
service charges for installation, disconnection, turnon or shutoff of water
service remain unpaid, in whole or in part, for thirty (30) days (15 days for
commercial/industrial customers) such charges shall be deemed delinquent. After
the prescribed collection process has been followed and the account remains
delinquent, the water superintendent shall exercise his/her discretion to
initiate proceedings to place a lien upon the said property, by having the
village file a statement of lien claim with the Cook County recorder of deeds.
This statement of lien claim shall include the legal description of the
property to which service is provided; the amount unpaid including penalty; and
a notice that the village claims a lien for stated amount as well as for all
water service charges and penalties, subsequent to the period for which the
bill was rendered. Whenever the premises is occupied by a person or persons
other than the owner, and the village has previously received notice of this,
notice of delinquency and lien shall be mailed to the owner of the property if
his/her address is known to the village. The failure of the village to record
the lien with the Cook County recorder of deeds or to mail the notice of
delinquency and lien to the owner of the property or failure of the owner to
receive such notice, shall not affect the right of the village to foreclose the
lien for unpaid bills as mentioned herein. Property subject to a lien for
unpaid water charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds
of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is
the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by
bill in equity in the name of the village. The village attorney is hereby
authorized to initiate such proceedings against any property for which the bill
has remained unpaid for ninety (90) days after it has been rendered. (Ord. 05-
05, 9-27-2005)
   (G)   Severance And Restoration Of Water Service After Tampering: If it is
found that the water supply has been restored by persons other than water
department personnel to a building in violation of the provisions of the
waterworks ordinance, the village board shall have the authority to sever the
service through which the water is being supplied to any such building. No
water shall again be supplied to the premises until the charges of such
severing and also any other unpaid charges have been paid. The charges
hereinbefore provided shall be paid by the persons owning or occupying the
building at the time it is desired to have the water service restored,
irrespective of whether such person is being held responsible for any tampering
with the B box shutoff.
   (H)   Security Deposit: Whenever water service has been terminated due to
delinquency of payment, the water superintendent may require a security deposit
from the owner of the premises before restoring water service to the said
premises. The security deposit must be in the form of cash or certified check
and is not applicable to any future charges. (Ord. 97-16, 7-22-1997)
8-2-3: TURN ON/OFF CHARGE, AND CONNECTION CHARGE:
There shall be a service charge of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for turning
water on or for turning water off. In the event water service is terminated as
a result of a delinquent payment, said charges shall be increased to one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for the initial turnoff/turnon. Subsequent
delinquencies shall be increased to one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and two
hundred dollars ($200.00) respectively. In addition, there shall be a service
charge for each water or sewer connection made, which charge shall be based on
the diameter of the water or sewer service connection serving any property or
premises: (Ord. 05-05, 9-27-2005)
Connection Size Fee
Connection Size Fee

3" - 4"         75.00
5"              100.00
6"               
8"              150.00
10"             175.00
12"             200.00
