(Ord. 85-17, 11-12-1985)
8-2-4: WATER SUPPLIED THROUGH METERS:
All water consumers supplied by the village shall be supplied through meters
only, and shall pay for the water at the rate and in the manner specified by
this chapter. (Ord. 58-12, 12-9-1958)
8-2-5: PLACEMENT OF METERS:
All meters shall be placed in the basement of buildings where service pipes
enter the same and so as to afford easy access for examining and reading. Where
there is no basement, the meter shall be placed in a tile or concrete box
inside the curb line, not more than one foot (1') distant from the service
cock. The box shall be so constructed as to amply protect the meter against
frost, and shall be easily accessible to the employees of the village. (Ord.
58-12, 12-9-1958)
8-2-6: DEFECTIVE METERS:
If any water meter is out of order or cannot be read, the superintendent shall
be authorized to submit an estimated bill to said water user for the billing
period involved. (Ord. 61-37, 5-23-1961)
8-2-7: AUTHORITY TO ENTER PREMISES:
Water department personnel shall have free access to any premises whenever such
access is deemed necessary or advisable for inspection of the water supply
thereto. Whenever any person in charge or control of a building shall refuse
entry or do any act for the purpose of preventing access, the water
superintendent may terminate service to the said building. Water service shall
continue to be shut off until written notice has been given to the
superintendent that access will be permitted. (Ord. 93-32, 11-23-1993)
8-2-8: WATER SERVICE; EMERGENCY AND TEMPORARY CONSTRUCTION:
Special water service from fire hydrants or village mains may be provided for
emergency or temporary construction purposes. Application for such special
water service shall be made in writing addressed to the president and board of
trustees. Such special use of water shall not be permitted without the approval
and consent of the president and board of trustees.
Upon approval by the corporate authorities all such water use shall be metered
through appropriate village meters or measuring devices installed and
maintained by the village water department. (Ord. 76-16, 7-6-1976)
The cost of water service from fire hydrants for emergency construction
purposes shall be a service charge of ten dollars ($10.00) daily for every day
in use, plus the prevailing industrial water rates of forty five dollars five
cents ($45.05) for the first one thousand two hundred (1,200) cubic feet and
one dollar twenty cents ($1.20) per one hundred (100) cubic feet in excess of
one thousand two hundred (1,200) cubic feet.
The cost of water service from village mains for temporary construction
purposes shall be at the rate of two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per one
hundred (100) cubic feet. (Ord. 92-2, 1-28-1992)
8-2-9: OBSTRUCT WATER FLOW:
It shall be unlawful for any person to in any manner interfere with or obstruct
the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the water system of
the village; or to interfere with or obstruct any plant or water main, hydrant,
service pipe, connected with the said water system or plant, or to cause,
suffer or permit any of such things to be done. (Ord. 58-12, 12-9-1958)
8-2-10: FLUSHING OF SANITARY SEWERS:
The flushing of sanitary sewers with potable water is prohibited except when
performed through the use of a high velocity type sewer jet. (Ord. 77-22, 12-
20-1977)
8-2-11: RESTRICTED HOURS FOR SPECIFIED USES:
Between May 15 and September 15 water from the village water distribution
system shall not be used on any day between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00)
A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. (local time) when evapotranspiration is at
its highest, nor shall watering be done on the same property on consecutive
days, for the purpose of:
   (A)   Watering or sprinkling of gardens, lawns, trees, shrubs and other
outdoor plants, except that such restriction shall not prohibit the watering of
newly planted gardens (less than 3 months old), lawns, trees, shrubs and plants
with handheld watering devices; and
   (B)   New/replacement sprinkler systems shall be equipped with a WaterSense
labeled irrigation controller and shall be in compliance with section 2.5(g) of
the Illinois plumbing license law 1 .
   (C)   Filling swimming pools. (Ord. 15-11A, 10-13-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 320.
8-2-12: EMERGENCY PROCLAMATION:
Whenever the water supply of the village is diminished from any cause whatever
to an amount which in the opinion of the village president is or is likely to
become dangerous to the health and safety of the public, the village president
is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a proclamation in the form of a
public notice containing regulations on the use of water from the village water
distribution system. Such regulations may provide for the limited use of water,
limitations on days and hours of use for some or all purposes and the
prohibition of specified uses. Upon making said proclamation the village
president shall make the contents thereof known to the public by news release
to the local newspapers and radio media and may also notify the citizens in any
other practical manner that he shall devise. Further, the village president
shall immediately notify all members of the board of trustees of the nature of
the emergency and the regulations that have been imposed.
The emergency proclamation of the village president and the regulations imposed
thereby shall remain in full force and effect until one of the following shall
occur:
   (A)   The village president determines that the emergency no longer exists
and that the emergency proclamation and the regulations imposed thereby shall
no longer continue in effect.
   (B)   The president and board of trustees modify, repeal or make permanent
the emergency proclamation and the regulations imposed thereby by means of an
ordinance passed at any regular or special meeting of the corporate
authorities.
   (C)   The first regular meeting of the president and board of trustees
occurring more than thirty (30) days after the emergency proclamation of the
village president.
Any village employee or officer may at the direction of the village president
notify and warn any person of the effects of said proclamation and direct said
person to comply with the regulations imposed thereby. If any such person after
having first been warned about such regulations and such proclamation shall
continue to violate said regulations, they shall be deemed to be in violation
of this section and liable for the general penalty set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 77-22, 12-20-1977)
8-2-13: REGULATION OF POTABLE WATER SUPPLY WELLS WITHIN THE CORPORATE LIMITS OF
THE VILLAGE OF FOREST VIEW:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, unless the context
requires otherwise, the following terms shall be construed as herein defined:
    PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
   POTABLE WATER: Water which meets the requirements of applicable federal and
state laws and regulations for drinking, culinary, swimming, bathing and
domestic purposes.
   (B)   Private And Public Wells Prohibited Within The Corporate Limits Of The
Village Of Forest View:
      1.   No person (including the village and any other unit of government)
shall install any potable water supply well or use any well for the purpose of
obtaining a potable water supply, within the corporate limits of the village of
Forest View.
      2.   No person shall drill a well, within the corporate limits of the
village of Forest View, in order to obtain a potable water supply for use in or
outside the village. (Ord. 08-13, 8-12-2008)
CHAPTER 3
DRIVEWAYS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Supervision
8-3-2: Permit Necessary
8-3-3: Board Order
8-3-4: Width Of Aprons
8-3-5: Width Of Driveways
8-3-6: Grade
8-3-7: Withdrawal Of Permit
8-3-1: SUPERVISION:
The location, construction and maintenance of driveways shall be under the
direction and supervision of the Building Commissioner and the location and
construction of the same shall be in accordance with the plans and
specifications as approved by the said Commissioner. (1940 Code Sec. 6-6; amd.
Ord. 95-20, 9-12-1995)
8-3-2: PERMIT NECESSARY:
No person shall construct, build, establish or maintain any driveway over,
across or upon any public sidewalk or public parkway where such driveway is for
other than residence or dwelling house use, or where it is necessary to cut
down or alter any street, curb or where the driveway depresses or elevates the
established grade of public sidewalks or parkways without first obtaining an
order so to do from the Board of Trustees and a permit so to do as hereinafter
provided.
A driveway over sidewalk space which does not elevate or depress the existing
grade of sidewalks and parkways and which does not cut down or alter any street
curb and which is for residence or dwelling house use may be established,
built, constructed and maintained upon permit issued by the Building
Commissioner with the order of Board of Trustees; provided, that all other
requirements of this Chapter dealing with driveways shall be fully complied
with. (1940 Code Sec. 6-6; amd. Ord. 95-20, 9-12-1995)
8-3-3: BOARD ORDER:
All Board orders for driveways shall contain the name of the person making said
application for driveway, the location and dimensions of the proposed driveway,
the use to which it is to be devoted and whether in the building thereof it
will be necessary to cut down or alter the street curb or depress the existing
grade of sidewalks or parkways. Construction of driveways may not alter the
adjacent gutter flow as established by the Village.
No permit for a driveway shall be issued upon order of the Board of Trustees
until written application therefor has been made and the bond herein provided
for has been filed. (1940 Code Sec. 6-6; amd. Ord. 95-20, 9-12-1995)
8-3-4: WIDTH OF APRONS:
Parkway driveway aprons are to be the same width as the private property
driveway at the public sidewalk and extend to a gradual expansion in width of
no more than six (6) additional feet at the curb. (Ord. 95-20, 9-12-1995)
8-3-5: WIDTH OF DRIVEWAYS:
All private driveways fronting on 45th and 46th Streets shall extend no more
than three feet (3') wider than the east-west width of the garage. (Ord. 99-13,
6-22-1999)
8-3-6: GRADE:
Where driveways are to be built across the sidewalk space, unless otherwise
expressly authorized, they shall conform to the sidewalk grade. Such driveways
shall be six inches (6") in depth and a top or finishing layer two inches (2")
in depth. This work shall be done in the manner and material shall be of the
quality and proportions specified for Portland cement concrete walks. Provided,
however, that in the case of driveways across viaduct sidewalks, variations of
construction and materials to conform to existing condition may be made when
approved by the Commissioner of Public Works and the Commissioner of Buildings.
No drive shall be so constructed as to prevent free and unobstructed passage
on, over or across the same, or in such manner as to interfere with the proper
drainage and safe grading of the streets. Gradual approaches to the regular
sidewalk grade shall be made from the grade of the driveway. The slope of any
driveway and the approaches thereto shall not exceed one inch (1") to one foot
(1') horizontal in any direction. When any driveway is to be constructed of
brick, stone, block or similar material that will not permit a smooth, even
surface without numerous joints, provision for foot travel shall be made by
constructing "crossings" or strips of concrete parallel to the street (lot)
line across such driveways; the top of such strips of concrete shall be flush
and even with the adjoining parts of the driveway; they shall be not less than
nine inches (9") in depth, eighteen inches (18") wide and shall be spaced
thirty six inches (36") apart from center to center in line with the sidewalk
on said street. For walks six feet (6') wide, two (2) such crossings shall be
provided and an additional crossing shall be provided for each three feet (3')
additional in the width of the walk. (1940 Code Sec. 6-6)
8-3-7: WITHDRAWAL OF PERMIT:
Permits required by this Chapter shall contain conditions as follows: said
permit may be revoked by the Building Commissioner, or by an order passed by
the Village in which case the authority and privileges granted shall thereupon
cease and determine; upon the termination by revocation, expiration or
otherwise of the authority, rights and privileges granted by said permit, the
driveway therein authorized shall have been located, shall be restored to its
proper condition to the satisfaction of the Building Commissioner, so that the
said portion of the said sidewalk space used for said driveway shall be safe
for public travel and in the same condition as the remaining portion of said
sidewalk space, at the sole expense of the grantee therein, without cost or
expense of any kind whatsoever to the Village; provided, that in the event of
the failure, neglect or refusal on the part of said grantee to remove said
driveway when directed so to do, the Village may proceed to remove some and
charge the expense thereof to said grantee.
Such permits may be revoked by the said Commissioner, for failure or neglect to
comply with the provisions of this Chapter. (1940 Code Sec. 6-6; amd. Ord. 95-
20, 9-12-1995)
CHAPTER 4
CABLE TV FRANCHISE
SECTION:
8-4-1: Title
8-4-2: Definitions
8-4-3: Grant Of Authority
8-4-4: Indemnification
8-4-5: Franchise Fee
8-4-6: Programming And Services
8-4-7: Emergency Facilities
8-4-8: Construction And Maintenance
8-4-9: Rates
8-4-10: Franchise Term
8-4-11: Resolution Of Subscriber Complaints
8-4-12: Construction Bond
8-4-13: Public, Educational And Municipal Access
8-4-14: Public, Educational And Municipal Connections
8-4-15: Interface Of CATV Companies
8-4-16: Studio Facility
8-4-17: Governmental Approvals
8-4-18: Equal Opportunity Employer
8-4-19: Exercise Of Reasonable Police Power
8-4-20: Right To Inspect Books
8-4-21: Regulating Officer Of The Village
8-4-22: Surrender Right
8-4-23: Transfers
8-4-24: Acceptance
8-4-25: Unlawful Acts
8-4-26: Automatic Amendments
8-4-27: Prohibited Activities
8-4-28: Cable Advisory Committee
8-4-29: Subscriber Privacy
8-4-30: Severability
8-4-31: Effective Date
8-4-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known and may be cited as the CABLE TV FRANCHISE. (Ord.
79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Chapter, and when not inconsistent with the context,
words used herein in the present tense include the future; words in plural
include the singular, and vice versa. The word "shall" is always mandatory. The
captions supplied herein for each section are for convenience only; said
captions have no force of law, are not part of the Section, and are not to be
used constructing the language of the Section. The following terms and phrases,
as used herein, shall be given the meanings set forth below:
FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION OR FCC: The present Federal agency of that
name as constituted by the Communications Act of 1934, or any successor agency
created by the United States Congress.
GRANTEE: Cablevision of Chicago, its successors and assigns.
GROSS REVENUES: Shall include any and all compensation or receipts derived by
Grantee from the operation within the Village of the cable television system
authorized herein but shall not include any refunds or credits made to
subscribers or any taxes imposed on the services furnished by Grantee.
PERSON: An individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
REGULAR SUBSCRIBER SERVICES: Shall include the carriage of broadcast signals
and FCC mandated non-broadcast services, but shall not include "ancillary" or
"auxiliary" services, which include, but are not limited to, advertising,
leased channels and programming supplied on a per-program or per channel charge
basis, if any.
VILLAGE: The Village of Forest View, a Municipal Corporation under the laws of
the State of Illinois.
VILLAGE BOARD: The governing board of the Village of Forest View. (Ord. 79-24,
10-16-1979)
8-4-3: GRANT OF AUTHORITY:
There is hereby granted by the Village to Grantee the right and privilege to
construct, erect, operate and maintain, in, upon, along, across, above, over or
under the streets, alleys, easements, public ways and public places now laid
out or dedicated and all extensions thereof and additions thereto in the
Village, all poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes and other
conductors and fixtures necessary for the maintenance and operation in the
Village of a cable television system for the transmission of television signals
and other signals either separately or upon or in conjunction with any public
utility maintaining the same in the Village with all of the necessary and
desirable appliances and appurtenances pertaining thereto. Without limiting the
generality of the foregoing, this franchise and grant shall and does hereby
include the right in, over, under and upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys,
easements and public grounds and places in the Village to install, erect,
operate or in any way acquire the use of, as by leasing or licensing, all lines
and equipment necessary to a cable television system and the right to make
connections to subscribers and the right to repair, replace, enlarge and extend
said lines, equipment and connections. The rights herein granted for the
purposes herein set forth shall not be exclusive and the Village reserves the
right to grant a similar use of said streets, alleys, easements, public ways
and places to any person at any time during the period of this franchise;
provided, that nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the granting
of additional CATV franchises if, in the opinion of the Village Board it is in
the public interest to restrict such franchise to one or more. (Ord. 79-24, 10-
16-1979)
8-4-4: INDEMNIFICATION:
Grantee shall indemnify, defend and save the Village harmless from any and all
loss and costs, including reasonable attorneys' fees, sustained by the Village
on account of any suit, judgment, execution, claim or demand whatsoever against
the Village resulting from the action of the Grantee, its employees, agents or
independent contractors, in the construction, operation or maintenance of its
cable television system in the Village, and including costs and attorneys' fees
incurred by the Village in enforcing this provision; and for this purpose,
Grantee shall carry property damage and personal injury insurance with some
responsible insurance company or companies qualified to do business in the
State of Illinois. The Village shall be named as an additional insured for the
entire term of the franchise under the policy and shall be furnished with a
certificate of insurance which may not be cancelled except upon thirty (30)
days' prior written notice to the Village. The amounts of such insurance to be
carried for liability due to property damage shall be three hundred thousand
dollars ($300,000.00) as to any one occurrence; and against liability due to
injury to or death of persons, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) as to any
one person and three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) as to any one occurrence.
The Village may require periodic increases in the amount of such coverage, but
in no event shall such increases be greater than the cumulative increases in
the cost of living since the time of the last requested increase. The Village
shall notify Grantee, in writing, within twenty one (21) days after the
presentation of any claim or demand, either by suit or otherwise, made against
the Village on account of any action as aforesaid on the part of the Grantee.
Where any such claim or demand against the Village is made by suit or other
legal action, written notice thereof shall be given by the Village to Grantee
not less than five (5) days prior to the date upon which an answer to such
legal action is due or within twenty one (21) days after the claim or demand is
made upon the Village, whichever notice yields Grantee the larger amount of
time within which to prepare an answer. Failure by the Village to properly
notify Grantee in accordance with the foregoing of any such claim, suit or
demand against the Village shall release Grantee from its obligation to
indemnify the Village as provided herein, if the Grantee is prejudiced thereby.
(Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-5: FRANCHISE FEE:
The Grantee shall pay, as compensation to the Village a fee of three percent
(3%) of its gross revenues per calendar year. The said franchise fee shall be
payable in semi-annual installments and shall be accompanied by a statement
detailing the gross revenues for the six (6) month period in question. (Ord.
79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-6: PROGRAMMING AND SERVICES:
Grantee will install a state-of-the-art cable television system capable of
providing at least thirty six (36) channels of programming, and maintain said
system with the latest state-of-the-art equipment and technology.
Grantee will provide a basic service (Family Cable), consisting of at least
thirty six (36) channels of programming. In addition to many automated
services, such as local, State and international news, financial information,
including stock market quotes, comparison shopping, swap n' shop, etc., as well
as numerous broadcast television stations, this service will include motion
pictures without commercial interruption, blacked-out sporting events each
month, together with public, educational, governmental and leased channel
access. Incorporated herein by reference, and referred to as Exhibit "A" is a
listing of channel allocations for the Village and a description of the
services to be offered. In addition, the terms of the proposal heretofore
submitted by Grantor to the Village, dated August 20, 1979, and consisting of
ten (10) sections and exhibits, are incorporated herein. A copy of said
proposal is on file in the office of the Village Clerk.
Grantee will also provide programming, consisting of additional motion
pictures, night club entertainment and sporting events, as well as special
programs, such as ballet, opera and other cultural events, as they become
available.
The proposed cable system will be capable of two-way transmission. This
capability will be utilized to offer the residents of the Village a complete
security monitoring system including fire, police and medical emergency alerts.
The security system will be centrally monitored twenty four (24) hours a day.
(Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-7: EMERGENCY FACILITIES:
Subject to the applicable rules of the FCC, within six (6) months from the date
of a request in writing to Grantee by the Village, Grantee shall, without
charge, and as the state-of-the-art permits, provide public emergency broadcast
facilities whereby the Village can interrupt service on all channels in order
to make public emergency cablecasts. In no event shall Grantee be required to
provide such facilities until a plan for use of the said facilities has been
prepared and approved by the Board of the Village. The Village agrees to
indemnify and hold the Grantee harmless from any damages or penalties resulting
from the use of this service. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-8: CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE:
   (A)   Construction of the system shall commence within thirty (30) days
after all required utility company licenses have been obtained by Grantee and
service shall be available to every resident of the Village within six (6)
months thereafter, time being of the essence. Grantee shall expedite the
procurement of such licenses to the best of its ability, and the Village shall
actively assist Grantee to the fullest extent possible in obtaining reasonable
joint pole or conduit use agreements from the owners thereof.
   (B)   All Grantee's house connections, structures, poles, wire, cable,
coaxial cable, fixtures and appurtenances and other equipment shall be
installed, located, erected, constructed, reconstructed, replaced, removed,
repaired, maintained and operated in accordance with good engineering
practices, performed by experienced pole-line construction crews and so as not
to endanger or interfere with improvements the Village may deem proper to make,
or to interfere in any manner with the rights of any property owner, or to
unnecessarily hinder or obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic on Municipal
properties. Further, all such plant and equipment and all construction shall
meet all relevant specifications of the Federal Communications Commission, and
other applicable Federal, State and local aboveground regulations. Signals
shall be transmitted to the Village by cable lines, and no microwave receiver
or other receiving device shall be constructed in the Village without the
permission of the Village.
   (C)   Any opening or obstructions in or disturbances of the streets, public
ways, or other Municipal properties made by the Grantee in the exercise of its
rights under this Chapter shall be done in compliance with directions to be
provided by the Village President or his designee, and any relevant section of
the Village Code which regulates work in the public ways of the Village.
Further, the Village may require Grantee to install the system underground in
the Village where other public utilities have been installed underground. The
Grantee shall, at its own cost and expense, replace all paving, sidewalks,
driveways, parkways, or surfaces so disturbed in as good condition as before
work was commenced. No open cuts in streets, sidewalks or driveways shall be
allowed, except as approved by the Village Superintendent of Public Works.
   (D)   Upon failure of Grantee to commence, pursue, or complete any work
required by law or by the provisions of this Chapter to be done in any street
or other public place of Municipal property, within the time prescribed, and to
the satisfaction of the Village Board or its designee, the Village Board or its
designee may, at its option, cause such work to be done and the Grantee shall
pay to the Village the cost thereof in the itemized amounts reported by the
Village Board or its designee to the Grantee within thirty (30) days after
receipt of such itemized report.
   (E)   Grantee shall, on the request of any private party holding an
appropriate permit issued by the Village, temporarily raise or lower its lines
to permit the moving of any building or other structure, and the actual expense
of the same shall be paid by the party requesting the same, and Grantee shall
have the right and authority to require such payment in advance. Requests for
such temporary movement of facilities shall not be given less than forty eight
(48) hours before the requested relocation.
   (F)   Grantee shall have the authority to trim trees upon and overhanging
all streets, alleys, easements, sidewalks and public places of the Village in
conjunction with, and after consultation with the Village President or his
designee, so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming into
potentially hazardous contact with Grantee's equipment or facilities.
   (G)   Grantee shall, at its expense, protect, support, temporarily
disconnect, relocate in the same street or other public place or Municipal
property, or remove from the street or other public place or Municipal
property, any property of Grantee when required by the Village Board or its
designee by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street vacation,
freeway and street construction, change or establishment of street grade,
installation of sewers, drains, water pipes, power lines, signal lines, and
tracks, or any other type of structures or improvements by public agencies. If
existing aerial utilities are placed underground at some time in the future,
Grantee will, at its expense, install its system underground. (Ord. 79-24, 10-
16-1979)
8-4-9: RATES:
The rates for regular subscriber services shall be nondiscriminatory; provided
that nothing contained herein shall be deemed to prohibit reasonable
promotional rates which may, from time to time, be less than the standard rates
imposed. The rates and charges set forth in Exhibit "A" shall not be increased
for a period of two (2) years from the date that service is available to every
resident of the Village as provided in Section
8-4-8 of this Chapter. The rates for installation of equipment shall also be
nondiscriminatory; provided, however, that, Grantee may recover its costs of
extending service to any new area as part of its installation of equipment
charges even if such installation charges for subscribers living in the area
which is the subject of the extension of services is greater than the
subscribers in the areas where service was previously available. Except as
provided hereinabove, the Village shall not have the power to regulate the
rates charged by Grantee for a period of four (4) years from the effective date
of this Chapter. Within thirty (30) days following said four (4) year period,
the Grantee shall provide written notice to the Village of the option
hereinafter granted. Upon receipt of such notice, the Village, within a period
of ninety (90) days, may in its sole judgment, determine that it will in the
future exercise this option to regulate all future rate increases for Grantee's
regular subscription services or other services if such regulation is permitted
by law. In the event the Village determines that it shall regulate such rate,
Grantee shall not increase the said rate without the prior approval of the
Village. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-10: FRANCHISE TERM:
   (A)   This franchise shall take effect and be in full force from and after
acceptance by Grantee as provided in Section
8-4-24 of this Chapter, and the same shall continue in full force and effect
for a term of fifteen (15) years.
   (B)   Grantee shall have the option to renew this franchise for an
additional period of five (5) years. Should Grantee desire to exercise this
option, it shall so notify the Village in writing, not less than three (3)
months prior to expiration of this franchise. Upon exercise of this option by
Grantee, this franchise shall be renewed by the Village, and all of the terms
and provisions contained herein shall be controlling during the renewal period.
   (C)   In addition to all other rights and powers of the Village by virtue of
franchise or this Chapter, the Village may terminate and cancel the franchise
and all rights and privileges of the Grantee thereunder in the event that
Grantee either:
      1.   Substantially violates any material provision of the franchise or
this Chapter, any rule, order or determination of the Village Board made
pursuant thereto, where such violation shall remain uncured for a period of
thirty (30) days subsequent to receipt by Grantee of written notice of said
violation, except where such violation is not the fault of Grantee or is due to
excusable neglect; or
      2.   Attempts to evade any of the provisions of this Chapter or practices
any fraud or deception upon the Village.
Such termination and cancellation shall be made by resolution of the Village
Board duly adopted after sixty (60) days' notice to Grantee and shall in no way
affect any of the Village's rights under this Chapter or any provisions of law;
provided, however, that before the franchise may be terminated and cancelled
under this Section, Grantee shall be provided with an opportunity to be heard
at a public hearing before the Village Board, upon thirty (30) days' written
notice to Grantee of the time and place of the public hearing; provided further
that said notice shall affirmatively cite the reasons alleged to constitute
cause for revocation; and provided further that notice of said public hearing
shall be published in a local newspaper of general circulation at least twenty
(20) days before the date of the hearing.
In the event that forfeiture is imposed upon Grantee, it shall be afforded a
period of twelve (12) months within which to sell, transfer or convey this
cable television system to a qualified purchaser at fair market value. During
this twelve (12) month period, which shall run from the effective date of the
final order or decision imposing forfeiture, including any appeal, Grantee
shall have the right to operate this cable television system pursuant to the
provisions of this franchise. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-11: RESOLUTION OF SUBSCRIBER COMPLAINTS:
   (A)   Grantee shall maintain an office with telephone service in a place
reasonably accessible to residents of the Village, for so long as it continues
to operate the system hereunder, and hereby designates such office as the place
where all notices, directions, orders and requests may be served or delivered
under this franchise. Grantee shall file a notification with the Village
whenever such address is changed.
   (B)   All complaints against Grantee relating to its performance under this
franchise, including but not limited to those concerning quality of service,
equipment malfunctions, and billing disputes, shall be received at the
aforesaid office by duly authorized employees. All complaints so received will
be turned over to the head of the department to which the complaint relates.
The manager of the system shall establish a follow-up procedure for all
complaints other than those concerning equipment or system malfunction, so that
the resolution of all complaints shall be reviewed weekly. Grantee shall report
all complaints received to the City on an annual basis.
   (C)   Regarding complaints of equipment or system malfunction, Grantee shall
respond to such complaints within thirty six (36) hours after receipt thereof
and correct malfunctions as promptly as possible. Grantee shall provide a daily
pro-rata credit to any subscriber who is without service for any period in
excess of thirty six (36) hours due to the fault of Grantee. (Ord. 79-24, 10-
16-1979)
8-4-12: CONSTRUCTION BOND:
   (A)   Within thirty (30) days after the receipt of all necessary
governmental and utility company authorizations, Grantee shall deposit with the
Village a surety bond or the equivalent thereof in cash, marketable securities,
or a letter of credit from a banking institution, guaranteeing the timely
construction of the cable television system to be constructed pursuant to this
franchise.
   (B)   The value of the security bond posted hereunder shall be five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00). The Village shall have the right to require the Grantee to
increase the amount of such security, but in no event shall such security
exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   (C)   In the event that the deposit is forfeited to the Village in whole or
in part because of the failure of Grantee to perform as hereinabove set forth,
Grantee shall have twenty (20) business days after receipt of written notice
from the Village that such collateral has been forfeited in whole or in part,
to replace the collateral so forfeited.
   (D)   The surety shall remain in effect for a term of five (5) years or
until cable television services are available throughout the Village, whichever
occurs sooner.
   (E)   Anything contained herein to the contrary notwithstanding, there shall
be no default or forfeiture pursuant to the terms of this franchise if the
failure to perform by Grantee is caused by circumstances beyond the control of
Grantee. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-13: PUBLIC, EDUCATIONAL AND MUNICIPAL ACCESS:
Grantee shall provide and maintain the public, educational and Municipal access
channels, described in Exhibit "A" and incorporated herein by reference;
provided, however, that Grantee shall have the right in its discretion to
provide other programming upon any such channel during such time or times as
any such channel shall not be utilized for access purposes; further provided
that access programming shall take precedence over Grantee's nonaccess
programming on any such channel. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-14: PUBLIC, EDUCATIONAL AND MUNICIPAL CONNECTIONS:
Subject to the applicable rules and regulations of the FCC:
   (A)   Grantee shall without charge make one aerial connection for regular
subscriber services, as provided below into the internal distribution system of
each Village office building, police station, fire station, library and school
within the Village (hereinafter singly or collectively referred to as the
"Premises"). Grantee shall make a connection at one outlet in each such
premises for the purpose of enabling the said premises to distribute the
regular subscriber service. Where such premises consists of more than one
building, only one tie-in and connection shall be made.
   (B)   Grantee shall make such tie-in and connection at the location
designated by the appropriate official as the location of the "head-end" of the
internal distribution system of the premises. The responsibility of Grantee
shall terminate when the tie-in and connection to the internal distribution
system is completed, and the responsibility for performance of the internal
distribution system, and for distribution of the transmissions throughout such
system shall be solely that of the premises. Grantee makes no representation or
warranty as to the ability of such distribution system to carry the programs
transmitted over its cable system; however, Grantee will offer, without charge,
technical consulting services to the premises in order to make the internal
system work effectively for the purposes intended herein.
   (C)   The procedure for making such connections shall be as follows:
Connections will be made at the time when Grantee is serving the area within
which the premises is located. At such time, Grantee shall send written
notification of the provisions of this paragraph to such premises. Thereafter,
upon written request from the recipient official, Grantee will make the above
described tie-in and connection to the internal distribution system of such
premises. When Grantee is serving the area, but the building on the Premises to
be connected with an aerial installation is located more than five hundred feet
(500') from the nearest CATV cable, the cost of the aerial cable installation
beyond five hundred feet (500') will be paid by the premises. For underground
installations, Grantee shall charge the recipient its actual cost. Such costs
will be submitted to said premises, in writing, before installation is begun.
All such premises will be connected according to the orderly progress and
construction of the system. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-15: INTERFACE OF CATV COMPANIES:
Subject to the applicable rules and regulations of the FCC, in the event that
more than one franchise is issued within, or immediately adjacent to the
Village, and if such operating systems are contiguous and technically
compatible with Grantee, and have allocated access channels, Grantee shall
provide suitable interconnection facilities for one access channel at the
boundary of its service areas. In no event, however, shall Grantee be required
to interconnect with a cable system not having substantially the same access
provisions in its franchise as contained in this franchise, unless such system
agrees voluntarily to connect with Grantee, nor shall Grantee be required to
interconnect at any point beyond any area where it has trunk or feeder service.
In no event shall interconnection be required where the combined cable systems
include more than fifty (50) trunk amplifiers in cascade or as the state-of-
the-art then permits. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-16: STUDIO FACILITY:
Grantee shall establish and maintain a studio for local programming, consisting
of at least two (2) view finder cameras, switcher fader controls, audio system,
lighting system, film chain, two (2) video tape recorders and multiplexing
unit. All equipment shall be remotely controlled from a master control unit.
This facility shall be available on a time-sharing basis to the Village, its
agencies, public service organizations and schools lying wholly or partly
within the Village. The studio facility shall be provided as soon as reasonably
practicable, but in no event later than five (5) years from the date of
registration of this franchise with the FCC. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-17: GOVERNMENTAL APPROVALS:
Grantee shall register this franchise with the FCC within sixty (60) days of
the execution hereof. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-18: EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER:
Grantee hereby agrees that it will not refuse to hire or employ, nor will it
bar or discharge from employment, nor discriminate against any person in
compensation or in terms, conditions or privileges of employment, because of
age, race, creed, color, national origin or sex. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-19: EXERCISE OF REASONABLE POLICE POWER:
Nothing contained herein shall in any way be deemed to limit the right of the
Village to adopt, in addition to the provisions of this franchise and existing
applicable Chapters, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in
the exercise of its reasonable police power; provided, however, that such
regulations are reasonable and do not materially conflict with the terms and
conditions of this franchise. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-20: RIGHT TO INSPECT BOOKS:
Grantee hereby grants to the Village the right to inspect all of its books,
records, maps, plans, financial statements and other similar materials of
Grantee, including lists of formal subscriber complaints and trouble calls
received by Grantee, insofar as they relate to the terms and conditions of this
franchise and the performance of the obligations hereunder, upon reasonable
notice to Grantee and during normal business hours. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-21: REGULATING OFFICER OF THE VILLAGE:
The office or officer of the Village that bears the primary responsibility for
the continuing administration of the terms and conditions of this franchise is
the President or his designee. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-22: SURRENDER RIGHT:
Grantee may surrender this franchise at any time upon filing with the Village
Clerk of the Village a written notice of its intention to do so at least three
(3) months before the surrender date. On the surrender date specified in the
notice, all of the rights and privileges and all of the obligations, duties and
liabilities of Grantee in connection with this franchise shall terminate. (Ord.
79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-23: TRANSFERS:
All of the rights and privileges and all of the obligations, duties and
liabilities created by this franchise shall pass to and be binding upon the
successors of the Village and the successors and assigns of Grantee. There can
be no transfer or assignment of:
   (A)   The franchise or
   (B)   Any of the rights, privileges and immunities contained herein, without
the prior approval of the Village, and the Village hereby agrees that it will
not unreasonably withhold such approval. In the event that Grantee shall desire
to transfer or assign the franchise or any of the rights, privileges and
immunities contained therein, the Village shall have the right of first refusal
to assume such transfer or assignment upon the same terms and conditions. Such
right shall be exercised within sixty (60) days after receipt from Grantee of a
request to transfer or assign either the franchise or any of the rights,
privileges and immunities contained therein. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-24: ACCEPTANCE:
This Chapter shall become effective when accepted by Grantee and shall then be
and become a valid and binding contract between the Village and Grantee;
provided that these regulations shall be void unless Grantee shall, within
ninety (90) days after the final passage hereof file with the Village Clerk of
the Village a written acceptance of these regulations and the franchise herein
granted, agreeing that it will comply with all of the provisions and conditions
hereof, and that it will refrain from doing all of the things prohibited by
this Chapter. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-25: UNLAWFUL ACTS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to make any unauthorized
connection, whether physically, electrically, acoustically, inductively or
otherwise, with any part of Grantee's cable television system for the purpose
of enabling himself or others to receive any television signals, radio signals,
pictures, programs, sounds or any other information or intelligence transmitted
over Grantee's cable system without payment to Grantee or its lessee.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of the owner,
to wilfully tamper with, remove or injure any cable, wires or other equipment
used for the distribution of television signals, radio signals, pictures,
programs, sounds or any other information or intelligence transmitted over
Grantee's cable system.
   (C)   It shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed six (6)
months, or both, for any person to violate any of the provisions of this
Section. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-26: AUTOMATIC AMENDMENTS:
Upon written notification to Grantee by the Village from time to time, this
franchise shall be deemed automatically amended to include the terms and
conditions more favorable to the Village and agreed to by the Grantee in any
other franchise granted to it by a municipality in Cook or DuPage County,
except where such more favorable terms or conditions are due to the larger
number of street miles or the greater number of housing units contained in such
municipality. The Grantee shall furnish to the Village all franchise ordinances
or amendments thereto relating to franchises granted to it in such counties.
(Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-27: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
Grantee shall not require any resident of the Village to enter into a
television repair contract with Grantee or anyone designated by Grantee as a
condition to providing cable television service to any resident. (Ord. 79-24,
10-16-1979)
8-4-28: CABLE ADVISORY COMMITTEE:
Grantee shall work closely with the Board of Trustees or with any Village Cable
Advisory Committee created by the Village in all areas of mutual Grantee-
Village concerns, particularly in the following:
   (A)   Establishment of rules for accessibility to the facilities, equipment,
channels, studios and services of the system;
   (B)   Resolution of conflicts between the Grantee and public and private
users of the system;
   (C)   Semi-annual reviews of the system performance.
Any such Cable Advisory Committee shall be created by a separate Village
Ordinance. In no case, however, shall its functions contravene any of the
provisions contained in this franchise agreement. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-29: SUBSCRIBER PRIVACY:
Grantee shall not initiate or use any form, procedure or device for procuring
information or data from subscribers' terminals by use of the cable television
system without prior authorization from each subscriber so affected. Grantee
shall not sell or offer to sell, without prior authorization from each
subscriber so affected, any list designating subscribers' names or addresses to
any other party. Grantee shall not permit the installation of any special
terminal equipment in any subscriber's premises that will permit transmission
from subscribers' premises of two-way service without first obtaining
permission of the subscriber. (Ord. 79-24, 10-16-1979)
8-4-30: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this Chapter
is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any Federal or State
court or administration or governmental agency of competent jurisdiction,
specifically including the Federal Communications Commission, such portion
shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and such
holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. (Ord.
79-24, 10-16-1979)
